verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 1:1
verses.text: Letters By Theodoret:  Letters of the Blessed Theodoret,  Bishop of Cyrus.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 1:2
verses.text: I.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 1:3
verses.text: To an Unknown Correspondent.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 1:4
verses.text: In the words of the prophet we find the wise hearer mentioned with the excellent councillor.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 1:5
verses.text: I, however, send the book I have written on the divine Apostle, not as much to a wise hearer as to a just and clever judge.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 1:6
verses.text: When goldsmiths wish to find out if their gold is refined and unalloyed, they apply it to the touchstone; and just so I sent my book to your reverence, for I wish to know whether it is what it should be, or needs some fining down.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 1:7
verses.text: You have read it and returned it, but have said nothing to me on this point.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 1:8
verses.text: Your silence leads me to conjecture that the judge has given sentence of condemnation, but is unwilling to hurt my feelings by telling me so.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 1:9
verses.text: Pray dismiss any such idea, and do not hesitate to tell me your opinion about the book.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 2:1
verses.text: II.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 2:2
verses.text: To the Same.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 2:3
verses.text: When men love warmly, I doubt whether in the case of the children of those whom they love, they can be impartial judges.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 2:4
verses.text: Justice is carried away by affection.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 2:5
verses.text: Fathers fancy that their ugly boys are beautiful, and sons do not see the uncomeliness of their fathers.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 2:6
verses.text: Brother looks at brother in the light of affection rather than of nature.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 2:7
verses.text: It is thus that I am afraid your holiness has judged what I have written, and that the sentence has been delivered by warmth of feeling.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 2:8
verses.text: For truly the power of love is very great, and not seldom it keeps out of sight considerable errors in our friends.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 2:9
verses.text: It is because you have so much of it, my dear friend, that you have wreathed what I have written with your kindly praises.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 2:10
verses.text: All I can do is to ask your piety to beseech the good Lord to ratify your eulogy, and make the man you have praised something like the picture painted in the words of his admirers.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 3:1
verses.text: III.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 3:2
verses.text: To Bishop Irenaeus.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 3:3
verses.text: Comparisons of this kind are forbidden by the divine Apostle.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 3:4
verses.text: In his Epistle to the Romans he writes "Therefore judge nothing before the time until the Lord come who both will bring to light the hidden things of darkness and will make manifest the counsels of the heart: and then shall every man have praise of God".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 3:5
verses.text: And he is quite right; for we can see only outward deeds, but the God of all knows also the intention of the doers, and when He delivers his sentence judges not so much the work as the will.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 3:6
verses.text: So He will crown the divine Apostle who became to the Jews as a Jew, to them that were under the law as under the law, and to them that were without law as without law for his object in thus assuming an actor's mask was that he might do good to mankind.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 3:7
verses.text: His was no time-server's career.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 3:8
verses.text: The gain he got was loss, but he secured the good of them whom he taught.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 3:9
verses.text: As I said, then, the divine Paul bids us wait for the judgment of God.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 3:10
verses.text: But we are venturing on high themes; we are handling a theology passing understanding and words; not, like the unholy heretics, seeking blasphemous positions, but endeavouring to confute their impiety, and as far as in us lies to give praise to the Creator; we shall therefore do nothing unreasonable in attempting to reply to your enquiry.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 3:11
verses.text: You have suggested the case of an impious judge giving to two athletes of piety the alternative of sacrificing to demons, or flinging themselves into the sea.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 3:12
verses.text: You describe the one as choosing the latter and plunging without hesitation into the deep, while the other, refusing both, shews quite as much abhorrence of the worship of idols as his companion, but declines to commit himself to the waves, and waits for this fate to be violently forced upon him.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 3:13
verses.text: You have suggested these circumstances, and you ask which of these two took the better course.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 3:14
verses.text: I think that you will agree with me that the latter was the more praiseworthy.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 3:15
verses.text: No one ought to withdraw himself from life unbidden, but should await either a natural or a violent death.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 3:16
verses.text: Our Lord gave us this lesson when He bade those that are persecuted in one city flee to another and again commanded them to quit even this and depart to another.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 3:17
verses.text: In obedience to this teaching the divine Apostle escaped the violence of the governor of the city, and had no hesitation in speaking of the manner of his flight, but spoke of the basket, the wall, and the window, and boasted and glorified in the act.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 3:18
verses.text: For what looks discreditable is made honourable by the divine command.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 3:19
verses.text: In the same manner the Apostle called himself at one time a Pharisee and at another a Roman, not because he was afraid of death, but acting quite fairly in fight.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 3:20
verses.text: In the same way when he had learnt the Jews' plot against him he appealed to Caesar and sent his sister's son to the chief captain to report the designs hatched against him, not because he clung to this present life, but in obedience to the divine law.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 3:21
verses.text: For assuredly our Lord does not wish us to throw ourselves into obvious peril; and this is taught us by deed as well as by word, for more than once He avoided the murderous violence of the Jews.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 3:22
verses.text: And the great Peter, first of the Apostles, when he was loosed from his chains and had escaped from the hands of Herod, came to the house of John, who was surnamed Mark, and after removing the anxiety of his friends by his visit and bidding them maintain silence, betook himself to another house in the endeavour to conceal himself more effectually by the removal.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 3:23
verses.text: And we shall find just the same kind of wisdom in the old Testament, for the famous Moses, after playing the man in his struggle with the Egyptian and finding out the next day that the homicide had become known, ran away, travelled a long journey, and arrived at the land of Midian.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 3:24
verses.text: In like manner the great Elias when he had learnt Jezebel's threats did not give himself up to them which wished to kill him, but left the world and hurried to the desert.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 3:25
verses.text: And if it is right and agreeable to God to escape the violence of our enemies, surely it is much more right to refuse to obey them when they order a man to become his own murderer.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 3:26
verses.text: Our Lord did not give in to the devil when he bade Him throw Himself down, and when he had armed against Him the hands of the Jews by means of the scourge and the thorns and the nails, and the creature was urging Him to bring wholesale destruction on His wicked foes, the Lord Himself forbade, because He knew that His Passion was bringing salvation to the world, and it was for this reason that just before His Passion He said to His Apostles "Pray that ye enter not into temptation," and taught us to pray "Lead us not into temptation".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 3:27
verses.text: Now let us shift our ground a little, and we shall see our way more clearly.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 3:28
verses.text: Let us eliminate the sea from the argument, and suppose the judge to have given each of the martyrs a sword, and ordered the one who refused to sacrifice to cut off his own head; who in his senses would have endured to redden his hand with his own blood, become his own headsman, lift his hand against himself, in obedience to the judge's order?  Clearly your second martyr deserves the higher praise.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 3:29
verses.text: The former indeed deserves credit for his zeal, but the latter is adorned by right judgment as well.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 3:30
verses.text: I have answered you according to the measure of the wisdom given me; He who knows thoughts as well as acts, will shew which of the two was right in the day of His appearing.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 4:1
verses.text: IV.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 4:2
verses.text: Festal.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 4:3
verses.text: The Creator of our souls and bodies has given His bounty to both, and at one and the same time has overwhelmed us with good things that both heart and senses can feel.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 4:4
verses.text: At the time of the sacred feast He has given us the rain we so much longed for, that our celebration might be clear of sadness.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 4:5
verses.text: We have praised our bountiful Lord, and now as we are wont write a festal letter and address your piety with the request that you will aid us with your prayers.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 5:1
verses.text: V.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 5:2
verses.text: Festal.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 5:3
verses.text: The God who made us gives us care and sorrow after our sin.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 5:4
verses.text: But He has furnished us with divine occasions of consolation by appointing divine feasts.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 5:5
verses.text: The thoughts they suggest both remind us of God's gifts to us, and promise complete freedom from all our troubles.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 5:6
verses.text: Enjoying these good things and filled with cheerfulness, we address your magnificence, and, according to the custom of the festival, pay friendship's debt.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 6:1
verses.text: VI.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 6:2
verses.text: Festal.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 6:3
verses.text: Our loving Lord has allowed us, with the zeal of folks who love the Christ, to celebrate the divine feast of salvation and enjoy the fruit of the spiritual blessing that flows from it.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 6:4
verses.text: Since we know the disposition of your Piety toward us, we write to tell you this.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 6:5
verses.text: For they who have friendly thoughts to others are always pleased to hear cheering intelligence of them.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 7:1
verses.text: VII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 7:2
verses.text: To Theonilla.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 7:3
verses.text: Had I heard of the death of your dignity's most honourable husband I should have written long ago, and now my object in writing is not to lull your great sorrow to sleep by consolatory words.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 7:4
verses.text: They are unnecessary.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 7:5
verses.text: They who have learnt the wisdom of philosophers and consider what this life is, find reason strong enough to meet and break grief's rising surge.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 7:6
verses.text: And even while you are remembering your long companionship, reason recognises the divine decrees, and to meet the forces of the tears of sorrow marshals at once the course of nature, the law of God, and the hope of the resurrection.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 7:7
verses.text: Knowing this as I do, there is no necessity to use many words.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 7:8
verses.text: I only beseech you to avail yourself of good sense in the hour of need.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 7:9
verses.text: Think of the death of him who is gone as no more than a long journey, and wait for the promise of our God and Saviour.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 7:10
verses.text: For He who promised the resurrection cannot lie, and is the fount of truth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 8:1
verses.text: VIII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 8:2
verses.text: To Eugraphia.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 8:3
verses.text: It is needless for me to bring once more to bear upon your grief the spells of the spirit.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 8:4
verses.text: The mere mention of the sufferings that wrought our salvation is enough to quench distress, even at its worst.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 8:5
verses.text: Those sufferings were all undergone for humanity.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 8:6
verses.text: Our Lord did not destroy death to make one body victorious over death, but through that one body to effect our common resurrection, and make our hope of it a sure and certain hope.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 8:7
verses.text: And if even while our holy celebrations are bringing you manifold refreshment of soul, you cannot overcome your sense of sorrow, let me beg you, my honoured friend, to read the very words of the marriage contract which follow on the mention of the dowry, and to see how the wedding is preceded by the reminder of death.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 8:8
verses.text: Knowing as we do that men are mortal, and bethinking us of the peace of survivors, it is customary to lay down what are called conditions, and for no hesitation to be shewn at the mention of death before the joining together in marriage.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 8:9
verses.text: These are the plain words "If the husband should die first it is agreed that so and so be done; if this lot should first fall to the wife, so and so".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 8:10
verses.text: We knew all this before the wedding; we are waiting for it so to say everyday.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 8:11
verses.text: Why then take it amiss? The union must needs be broken either by the death of the husband or the departure of the wife.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 8:12
verses.text: Such is the course of life.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 8:13
verses.text: You know, my excellent friend, alike God's will and human nature; dispel then your despondency and wait for the fulfilment of the common hope of the just.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 9:1
verses.text: IX.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 9:2
verses.text: To an Anonymous Correspondent.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 9:3
verses.text: Your piety is annoyed and distressed at the sentence passed on me unjustly and without a trial.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 9:4
verses.text: I am comforted that you are so feeling.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 9:5
verses.text: Had I been justly condemned I should have been sorry at having given my judges reasonable grounds for what they have done, but, as it is, my conscience is quite clear, and I feel joyful and exultant and look forward to the remission of other sins on account of this injustice.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 9:6
verses.text: Naboth lives in men's memories only because he suffered that unjust death.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 9:7
verses.text: Only pray that we be not abandoned of God and let the enemy continue to do his worst.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 9:8
verses.text: God's good will is enough to make me very cheerful and if He is on my side I despise all my troubles as trifles.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 10:1
verses.text: X.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 10:2
verses.text: To the Learned Elias.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 10:3
verses.text: Legislators have made laws in aid of the oppressed, and advocates have practised the orator's arts to help them that stand in need of fair defence.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 10:4
verses.text: You, my friend, have studied eloquence and the law.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 10:5
verses.text: Now put your art in practice, and by it put down the oppressors, help them that are put down by them, and defend them with the law as with a shield.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 10:6
verses.text: Let no guilty client enjoy the benefit of your advocacy, even though he be your friend.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 10:7
verses.text: Now one of these guilty men is that villain Abraham.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 10:8
verses.text: After being settled for a considerable time on an estate belonging to the church, he then took several partners in his rascality, and has had no hesitation in owning his proceedings.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 10:9
verses.text: I have sent him to you with an account of his doings, the parties he has wronged, and the reverend sub-deacon Gerontius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 10:10
verses.text: I do not want you to deliver the guilty man to the authorities, but in the hope that when his victims have told you all they have had to put up with, and have made you, my learned friend, feel sympathy for their case, you may be induced to compel the wicked fellow to restore what he has stolen.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 11:1
verses.text: XI.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 11:2
verses.text: To Flavianus Bishop of Constantinople.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 11:3
verses.text: The Creator and Guide of the Universe has made you a luminary of the world, and changed the deep moonless night into clear noon.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 11:4
verses.text: Just as by the haven's side, the beacon light shews sailors in the night time the harbour mouth, so shines the bright ray of your holiness to give great comfort to all that are attacked for true religion's sake, and shews them the safe port of the Apostles' faith.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 11:5
verses.text: They that know it already are filled with comfort, and they that knew it not are saved from being dashed upon the rocks.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 11:6
verses.text: I indeed am especially bound to praise the giver of all good, because I have found a noble champion who drives away fear of men by the power of the fear of God, fights heartily in the front rank for the doctrines of the Gospel, and gladly bears the brunt of the apostolic war.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 11:7
verses.text: So to-day every tongue is moved in eulogy of your holiness, for it is not only the nurslings of true religion who admire the purity of your faith, but the praises of your courage are sung even by the enemies of the truth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 11:8
verses.text: Falsehood vanishes at truth's lightning flash.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 11:9
verses.text: I write thus knowing that the very reverend and pious Hypatius the reader, both readily obeys the bidding of your holiness, and constantly, my Lord, mentions your laudable deeds.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 11:10
verses.text: I salute you as holy and right dear to God.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 11:11
verses.text: I exhort you to support us with your prayers that we may lead the rest of our lives according to God's laws.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 12:1
verses.text: XII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 12:2
verses.text: To the Bishop Irenaeus.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 12:3
verses.text: Job, that famous tower of adamant and noble champion of goodness, was not shaken even by blows of continuous troubles of every sort and kind, but stood impregnable and firm.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 12:4
verses.text: At the end however of all his trials the righteous Law-giver explained the reason of them in the words, "Dost thou think that I answered thee for any other reason than that thou mightest appear just?" I think that these words are known to your piety which is able to support the many and various attacks of troubles and anxieties, and so far from shrinking from them, exhibits the strength and stability of your administration.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 12:5
verses.text: So the bountiful Lord, seeing the bravery and holiness of your soul, has refused to keep a worthy champion in concealment, and has brought him forth to the contest to adorn your venerable head with a crown of victory, and give your struggles as a high example of good service to the rest.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 12:6
verses.text: So, my dear friend, conquer in this battle too, and bear bravely the death of your son-in-law, my own dear friend.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 12:7
verses.text: Conquer in your wisdom the claims of kinsmanship and the memory of a noble and generous character, a memory which must always recall something beyond painter's art or rhetorician's skill.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 12:8
verses.text: Repel the assault of sorrow by the thought of Him who wisely administers all the affairs of men, with perfect knowledge of the future and right guidance of it for our good.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 12:9
verses.text: Let us join in the joy of him who has been delivered from this life's storms.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 12:10
verses.text: Let us rather give thanks because, wafted by kindly winds, he has cast anchor in the windless haven and has escaped the grievous shipwrecks whereof this life is full.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 12:11
verses.text: But need I say all this to one who is a tried gladiator of goodness? Need I, as it were, anoint for endurance one who is a trainer of other athletes? Still I write.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 12:12
verses.text: It is a comfort to myself to write as I do.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 12:13
verses.text: I am really and truly grieved when I remember an intimacy that I esteemed so highly.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 12:14
verses.text: Once more I praise the great Guide of all, Who both knows what would be good for us and guides our life accordingly.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 12:15
verses.text: I have dictated this after writing my former communication, on one of my friends in Antioch telling me that the end had come.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 13:1
verses.text: XIII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 13:2
verses.text: To Cyrus.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 13:3
verses.text: I had heard of the island of Lesbos, and its cities Mitylene, Methymna, and the rest; but I was ignorant of the fruit of the vine cultivated in it.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 13:4
verses.text: Now, thanks to your diligence, I have become acquainted with it, and I admire both its whiteness and the delicacy of its flavour.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 13:5
verses.text: Perhaps time may even improve it, unless it turns it sour; for wine, like the body, and plants, and buildings, and other things made by hand, is damaged by time.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 13:6
verses.text: If, as you say, it makes the drinker longlived, I am afraid it will be of little use to me, for I have no desire to live a long life, when life's storms are so many and so hard.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 13:7
verses.text: I was however much pleased to hear of the health of the monk.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 13:8
verses.text: Really my anxiety about him was quite distressing, and I wrongly blamed the doctors, for his complaint required the treatment they gave.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 13:9
verses.text: I have sent you a little pot of honey which the Cilician bees make from storax flowers.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 14:1
verses.text: XIV.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 14:2
verses.text: To Alexandra.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 14:3
verses.text: Had I only considered the character of the loss which you have sustained, I should have wanted consolation myself, not only because I count that what concerns you concerns me, be it agreeable or otherwise, but because I did so dearly love that admirable and truly excellent man.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 14:4
verses.text: But the divine decree has removed him from us and translated him to the better life.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 14:5
verses.text: I therefore scatter the cloud of sorrow from my soul, and urge you, my worthy friend, to vanquish the pain of your sorrow by the power of reason, and to bring your soul in this hour of need under the spell of God's word.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 14:6
verses.text: Why from our very cradles do we suck the instruction of the divine Scriptures, like milk from the breast, but that, when trouble falls upon us, we may be able to apply the teaching of the Spirit as a salve for our pain? I know how sad, how very grievous it is, when one has experienced the worth of some loved object, suddenly to be deprived of it, and to fall in a moment from happiness to misery.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 14:7
verses.text: But to them that are gifted with good sense, and use their powers of right reason, no human contingency comes quite unforeseen; nothing human is stable; nothing lasting; nor beauty, nor wealth, nor health, nor dignity; nor any of all those things that most men rank so high.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 14:8
verses.text: Some men fall from a summit of opulence to lowest poverty; some lose their health and struggle with various forms of disease; some who are proud of the splendour of their lineage drag the crushing yoke of slavery.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 14:9
verses.text: Beauty is spoilt by sickness and marred by old age, and very wisely has the supreme Ruler suffered none of these things to continue nor abide, with the intent that their possessors, in fear of change, may lower their proud looks, and, knowing how all such possessions ebb and flow, may cease to put their confidence in what is short lived and fleeting, and may fix their hopes upon the Giver of all good.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 14:10
verses.text: I am aware, my excellent friend, that you know all this, and I beg you to reflect on human nature; you will find that it is mortal, and received the doom of death from the beginning.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 14:11
verses.text: It was to Adam that God said "Dust thou art and to dust thou shalt return".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 14:12
verses.text: The giver of the law is He that never lies, and experience witnesses to His truth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 14:13
verses.text: Divine Scripture tells us "all men have one entrance into life and the like going out," and every one that is born awaits the grave.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 14:14
verses.text: And all do not live a like length of time; some men come to an end all too soon; some in the vigour of manhood, and some after they have experienced the trials of old age.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 14:15
verses.text: Thus, too, they who have taken on them the marriage yoke are loosed from it, and it must needs be that either husband first depart or wife reach this life's end before him.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 14:16
verses.text: Some have but just entered the bridal chamber when their lot is weeping and lamentation; some live together a little while.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 14:17
verses.text: Enough to remember that the grief is common to give reason ground for overcoming grief.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 14:18
verses.text: Besides all this, even they who are mastered by bitterest sorrow may be comforted by the thought that the departed was the father of sons; that he left them grown up; that he had attained a very high position, and in it, so far from giving any cause for envy, made men love him the more, and left behind him a reputation for liberality, for hatred of all that is bad, for gentleness and indeed for every kind of moral virtue.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 14:19
verses.text: But what excuse for despondency will be left us if we take to heart God's own promises and the hopes of Christians; the resurrection, I mean, eternal life, continuance in the kingdom, and all that "eye hath not seen, nor ear heard, neither have entered into the heart of man, the things which God hath prepared for them that love Him"? Does not the Apostle say emphatically, "I would not have you to be ignorant brethren concerning them which are asleep, that ye sorrow not even as others which have no hope"? I have known many men who even without hope have got the better of their grief by the force of reason alone, and it would indeed be extraordinary if they who are supported by such a hope should prove weaker than they who have no hope at all.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 14:20
verses.text: Let us then, I implore you, look at the end as a long journey.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 14:21
verses.text: When he went on a journey we used indeed to be sorry, but we waited his return.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 14:22
verses.text: Now let the separation sadden us indeed in some degree, for I am not exhorting what is contrary to human nature, but do not let us wail as over a corpse; let us rather congratulate him on his setting forth and his departure hence, because he is now free from a world of uncertainties, and fears no further change of soul or body or of corporeal conditions.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 14:23
verses.text: The strife now ended, he waits for his reward.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 14:24
verses.text: Grieve not overmuch for orphanhood and widowhood.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 14:25
verses.text: We have a greater Guardian whose law it is that all should take good care of orphans and widows and about whom the divine David says "The Lord relieveth the fatherless and widow, but the way of the wicked He turneth upside down".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 14:26
verses.text: Only let us put the rudders of our lives in His hands, and we shall meet with an unfailing Providence.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 14:27
verses.text: His guardianship will be surer than can be that of any man, for His are the words "Can a woman forget her sucking child that she should not have compassion on the son of her womb? Yet will I not forget thee".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 14:28
verses.text: He is nearer to us than father and mother for He is our Maker and Creator.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 14:29
verses.text: It is not marriage that makes fathers, but fathers are made fathers at His will.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 14:30
verses.text: I am now compelled thus to write because my bonds do not suffer me to hasten to you, but your most God-loving and most holy bishop is able unaided to give all consolation to your very faithful soul by word and by deed, by sight and by communication of thought and by that spiritual and God-given wisdom of his whereby I trust the tempest of your grief will be lulled to sleep.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 15:1
verses.text: XV.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 15:2
verses.text: To Silvanus the Primate.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 15:3
verses.text: I know that in my words of consolation I am somewhat late, but it is not without reason that I have delayed to send them, for I have thought it worth while to let the violence of your grief take its course.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 15:4
verses.text: The cleverest physicians will never apply their remedies when a fever is at its height, but wait for a favourable opportunity for using the appliances of their skill.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 15:5
verses.text: So after reckoning how sharp your anguish must be, I have let these few days go by, for if I myself was so distressed and filled with such sorrow by the news, what must not have been the sufferings of a husband and yoke-fellow, made, as the Scripture says, one flesh, at the violent sundering of the union cemented both by time and love? Such pangs are only natural; but let reason devise consolation by reminding you that humanity is frail and sorrow universal, and also of the hope of the resurrection and the will of Him who orders our lives wisely.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 15:6
verses.text: We must needs accept the decrees of inestimable wisdom, and own them to be for our good; for they who reflect thus piously shall reap piety's rewards, and so delivered from immoderate lamentations shall pass their lives in peace.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 15:7
verses.text: On the other hand they whom sorrow makes its slaves will gain nothing by their wailing, but will at once live weary lives and grieve the Guardian of us all.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 15:8
verses.text: Receive then, my most honoured friend, a fatherly exhortation "The Lord gave and the Lord hath taken away.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 15:9
verses.text: He hath done whatsoever pleased Him.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 15:10
verses.text: Blessed be the name of the Lord".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 16:1
verses.text: XVI.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 16:2
verses.text: To Bishop Irenaeus.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 16:3
verses.text: There is nothing good, it seems, in prospect for us, so, far from calming down, the tempest troubling the Church seems to rise higher every day.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 16:4
verses.text: The conveners of the Council have arrived and delivered the letters of summons to several of the Metropolitans including our own, and I have sent a copy of the letter to your Holiness to acquaint you how, as the poet has it, "Woe has been welded by woe".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 16:5
verses.text: And we need only the Lord's goodness to stay the storm.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 16:6
verses.text: Easy it is for Him to stay it, but we are unworthy of the calm, yet the grace of His patience is enough for us, so that haply by it we may get the better of our foes.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 16:7
verses.text: So the divine apostle has taught us to pray "for He will with the temptation also make a way to escape that ye may be able to bear it".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 16:8
verses.text: But I beseech your godliness to stop the mouths of the objectors and make them understand that it is not for them who stand, as the phrase goes, out of range, to scoff at men fighting in the ranks and giving and receiving blows; for what matters it what weapon the soldier uses to strike down his antagonists? Even the great David did not use a panoply when he slew the aliens' champion, and Samson slew thousands on one day with the jawbone of an ass.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 16:9
verses.text: Nobody grumbles at the victory, nor accuses the conqueror of cowardice, because he wins it without brandishing a spear or covering himself with his shield or throwing darts or shooting arrows.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 16:10
verses.text: The defenders of true religion must be criticized in the same way, nor must we try to find language which will stir strife, but rather arguments which plainly proclaim the truth and make those who venture to oppose it ashamed of themselves.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 16:11
verses.text: What does it matter whether we style the holy Virgin at the same time mother of Man and mother of God, or call her mother and servant of her offspring, with the addition that she is mother of our Lord Jesus Christ as man, but His servant as God, and so at once avoid the term which is the pretext of calumny, and express the same opinion by another phrase? And besides this it must also be borne in mind that the former of these titles is of general use, and the latter peculiar to the Virgin; and that it is about this that all the controversy has arisen, which would God had never been.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 16:12
verses.text: The majority of the old Fathers have applied the more honourable title to the Virgin, as your Holiness yourself has done in two or three discourses; several of these, which your godliness sent to me, I have in my own possession, and in these you have not coupled the title mother of Man with mother of God, but have explained its meaning by the use of other words.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 16:13
verses.text: But since you find fault with me for having left out the holy and blessed Fathers Diodorus and Theodorus in my list of authorities, I have thought it necessary to add a few words on this point.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 16:14
verses.text: In the first place, my dear friend, I have omitted many others both famous and illustrious.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 16:15
verses.text: Secondly this fact must be borne in mind, that the accused party is bound to produce unimpeachable witnesses, whose testimony even his accusers cannot impugn.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 16:16
verses.text: But if the defendant were to call into court authorities accused by the prosecutors, even the judge himself would not consent to receive them.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 16:17
verses.text: If I had omitted these holy men in compiling an eulogy of the Fathers, I should, I own, have been wrong, and should have proved myself ungrateful to my teachers.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 16:18
verses.text: But if when under accusation I have brought forward a defence, and have produced unimpeachable witnesses, why do men who are unwilling to see any of these testimonies lay me under unreasonable blame? How I reverence these writers is sufficiently shewn by my own book in their behalf, in which I have refuted the indictment laid against them, without fear of the influence of their accusers or even of the secret attack made upon myself.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 16:19
verses.text: These people who are so fond of foolish talk had better get some other excuse for their sleight of words.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 16:20
verses.text: My object is not to make my words and deeds fit the pleasure of this man or that man, but to edify the church of God, and please her bridegroom and Lord.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 16:21
verses.text: I call my conscience to witness that I am not acting as I do through care of material things, nor because I cling to the honour with all its cares, which I shrink from calling an unhappy one.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 16:22
verses.text: I would long ago have withdrawn of my own accord, did I not fear the judgment of God.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 16:23
verses.text: And now know well that I await my fate.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 16:24
verses.text: And I think that it is drawing near, for so the plots against me indicate.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 17:1
verses.text: XVII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 17:2
verses.text: To the Deaconess Casiana.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 17:3
verses.text: Had I only considered the greatness of your sorrow, I should have put off writing a little while, that I might make time my ally in my attempt to cure it, but I know the good sense of your piety, and so I make bold to offer you some words of consolation suggested partly by human nature, and partly by divine Scripture.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 17:4
verses.text: For our nature is frail, and all life is full of such calamities, and the universal Governor and Ruler of the World,—the Lord who wisely orders our concerns,—gives us by means of His divine oracles consolation of various kinds, of which the writings of the holy Evangelists and the divine utterances of the blessed prophets are full.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 17:5
verses.text: But I am sure it is needless to cull these passages, and suggest them to your piety, nurtured as you have been from the beginning in the inspired word, ruling your life in accordance with them, and needing no other teaching.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 17:6
verses.text: But I do implore you to remember those words that charge us to master our feelings, and promise us eternal life, proclaim the destruction of death, and announce the common resurrection of us all.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 17:7
verses.text: Besides all this, nay, before all this, I ask you to reflect that He who has bidden these things so be is the Lord, that He is a Lord all wise and all good, Who knows exactly what is best for us, and to this end guides all our life.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 17:8
verses.text: Sometimes death is better than life, and what seems distressing is really pleasanter than fancied joys.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 17:9
verses.text: I beg your piety to accept the consolation offered by my humility, that you may serve the Lord of all by nobly bearing your pain, and affording to men as well as women an example of true wisdom.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 17:10
verses.text: For all will admire the strength of mind which has bravely borne the attack of grief and broken the force of its violent assault by the magnanimity of its resolution.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 17:11
verses.text: And we are not without great comfort in the living likenesses of your departed son; for he has left behind him offspring worthy of deep affection, who may be able to stay the excess of our sorrow.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 17:12
verses.text: Lastly I implore you to remember in your grief what your bodily infirmity can endure, and to avoid increasing your sufferings by mourning overmuch; and I implore our Lord of His infinite resources to give you ground of consolation.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 18:1
verses.text: XVIII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 18:2
verses.text: To Neoptolemus.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 18:3
verses.text: Whenever I cast my eyes on the divine law which calls those who are joined together in marriage "one flesh," I am at a loss how to comfort the limb that has been sundered, because I take account of the greatness of the pang.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 18:4
verses.text: But when I consider the course of nature, and the law which the Creator has laid down in the words "Dust thou art and to dust thou shalt return," and all that goes on daily in all the world on land and sea—for either husbands first approach the end of life or this lot first befalls the wives—I find from these reflections many grounds of consolation; and above all the hopes that have been given us by our Lord and Saviour.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 18:5
verses.text: For the reason of the accomplishment of the mystery of the incarnation was that we, being taught the defeat of death, should no more grieve beyond measure at the loss by death of those we love, but await the longed-for fulfilment of the hope of the resurrection.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 18:6
verses.text: I entreat your Excellency to reflect on these things, and to overcome the pain of your grief; and all the more because the children of your common love are with you, and give you every ground of comfort.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 18:7
verses.text: Let us then praise Him who governs our lives wisely, nor rouse His anger by immoderate lamentation, for in His wisdom He knows what is good for us, and in His mercy He gives it.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 19:1
verses.text: XIX.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 19:2
verses.text: To the Presbyter Basilius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 19:3
verses.text: I have found the right eloquent orator Athanasius to be just what your letter described him.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 19:4
verses.text: His tongue is adorned by his speech, and his speech by his character, and all about him is brightened by his abundant faith.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 19:5
verses.text: Ever, most God-beloved friend, send us such gifts.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 19:6
verses.text: You have given me, be assured, very great pleasure through my intercourse with him.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 20:1
verses.text: XX.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 20:2
verses.text: To the Presbyter Martyrius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 20:3
verses.text: Natural disposition appears in us before resolution of character, and, in this sense, takes the lead; but disposition is overcome by resolution, as is plainly proved by the right eloquent orator Athanasius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 20:4
verses.text: Though an Egyptian by birth, he has none of the Egyptian want of self-control, but shews a character tempered by gentleness.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 20:5
verses.text: He is moreover a warm lover of divine things.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 20:6
verses.text: On this account he has spent many days with me, expecting to reap some benefit from his stay.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 20:7
verses.text: But I, as you know, most God-beloved friend, shrink from trying so to derive good from others, and am far from being able to impart it to those who seek it, and this not because I grudge, but because I have not the wherewithal, to give.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 20:8
verses.text: Wherefore let your holiness pray that what is said of me may be confirmed by fact, and that not only may good things be reported of me by word, but proved in deed.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 21:1
verses.text: XXI.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 21:2
verses.text: To the Learned Eusebius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 21:3
verses.text: The disseminators of this great news, with the idea that it would be very distasteful to me, fancied that they might in this way annoy me.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 21:4
verses.text: But I by God's grace welcomed the news, and await the event with pleasure.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 21:5
verses.text: Indeed very grateful to me is any kind of trouble which is brought on me for the sake of the divine doctrines.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 21:6
verses.text: For, if we really trust in the Lord's promises, "The sufferings of this present time are not worthy to be compared with the glory that shall be revealed in us".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 21:7
verses.text: And why do I speak of the enjoyment of the good things which are hoped for? For even if no prize had been offered to them that struggle for the sake of true religion, Truth alone by her own unaided force would herself have been sufficient to persuade them that love her to welcome gladly all perils in her cause.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 21:8
verses.text: And the divine Apostle is witness of what I say, exclaiming as he does, "Who shall separate us from the love of Christ? Shall tribulation, or distress, or persecution, or famine, or nakedness, or peril or sword? As it is written, 'For thy sake we are killed all the day long; we are accounted as sheep for the slaughter.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 21:9
verses.text: '"  And then to teach us that he looks for no reward, but only loves his Saviour, he adds straightway "Nay in all these things we are more than conquerors through him that loved us".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 21:10
verses.text: And he goes on further to exhibit his own love more clearly.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 21:11
verses.text: "For I am persuaded, that neither death, nor life, nor angels, nor principalities, nor powers, nor things present, nor things to come, nor height, nor depth, nor any other creature, shall be able to separate us from the love of God, which is in Christ Jesus our Lord".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 21:12
verses.text: Behold, my friend, the flame of apostolic affection; see the torch of love.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 21:13
verses.text: I covet not, he says, what is His.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 21:14
verses.text: I only long for Him; and this love of mine is an unquenchable love and I would gladly forego all present and future felicity, aye, suffer and endure again all kinds of pain so as to keep with me this flame in all its force.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 21:15
verses.text: This was exemplified by the divine writer in deed as well as in word and everywhere by land and sea he has left behind him memorials of his sufferings.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 21:16
verses.text: So when I turn my eyes on him and on the rest of the patriarchs, prophets, apostles, martyrs, priests, what is commonly reckoned miserable I cannot but hold to be delightful.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 21:17
verses.text: I confess to a feeling of shame when I remember how even they who never learnt the lessons we have learnt, but followed no other guide but human nature alone, have won conspicuous places in the race of virtue.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 21:18
verses.text: The famous Socrates, son of Sophroniscus, when under the calumnious indictment, not only treated the lies of his accusers with contempt, but expressed his cheerfulness in the midst of his troubles in the words, "Anytus and Meletus can kill me, but they cannot harm me".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 21:19
verses.text: And the orator of Paeania, who was as wise as he was eloquent, enriched both the men of his own day and them that should come after him with the saying: "to all the race of men the end of life is death, even though one shut himself up for safety in a cell; so good men are bound ever to put their hand to every honourable work, ever defending themselves with good hope as with a shield, and bravely to bear whatever lot may be given them by God".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 21:20
verses.text: Moreover a writer of earlier date than Demosthenes, I mean the son of Olorus, wrote many noble sentiments, and among them this "We must bear what the gods send us of necessity and the fortune of war with courage".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 21:21
verses.text: Why need I quote philosophers, historians, and orators? For even the men who gave higher honour to their mythology than to the truth have inserted many useful exhortations in their stories; as Homer in his poems introduces the wisest of the Hellenes preparing himself for deeds of valour, where he says  "He chid his angry spirit and beat his breast,  And said 'Forbear my mind, and think on this:  There hath been time when bitterer agonies  Have tried thy patience.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 21:22
verses.text: '"  Similar passages might easily be collected from poets, orators, and philosophers, but for us the divine writings are sufficient.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 21:23
verses.text: I have quoted what I have to prove how disgraceful it were for the mere disciples of nature to get the better of us who have had the teaching of the prophets and the apostles, trusting in the Saviour's sufferings and looking for the resurrection of the body, freedom from corruption, the gift of immortality and the kingdom of heaven.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 21:24
verses.text: So, my dear friend, comfort those who are discouraged at the stories bruited abroad, and if anybody is pleased at them, tell them that we are happy too, that we are exulting and dancing with joy, and that what they call punishment we are looking for as the kingdom of heaven itself.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 21:25
verses.text: To inform those who do not know in what mind we are, be assured, most excellent friend, that we believe, as we have been taught, in the Father, the Son, and the Holy Ghost.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 21:26
verses.text: There is no truth in the slander of some that we have been taught to believe, or have been baptized, or do believe, or teach others to believe, in two Sons.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 21:27
verses.text: As we know one Father and one Holy Ghost so we know one Son, our Lord Jesus Christ, the only begotten Son of God, God the Word who was made man.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 21:28
verses.text: We do not however deny the properties of the natures.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 21:29
verses.text: We hold them to be in error who divide the one Lord Jesus Christ into two Sons, and we also call them enemies of the truth who endeavour to confound the natures.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 21:30
verses.text: We believe an union to have been made without confusion, and we reckon some qualities to be proper to the manhood and others to the Godhead; for just as the man—I mean man in general—reasonable and mortal being, has a soul and has a body, and is reckoned to be one being, just so the distinction between the two natures does not divide the one man into two persons, but we recognise in the one man both the immortality of the soul and the mortality of the body, and acknowledge the invisible soul and the visible body, but, as I said, one being at once reasonable and mortal; so do we recognise our Lord and God, I mean the Son of God our Lord Christ, even after His incarnation, to be one Son; for the union is indivisible, as we know it is without confusion.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 21:31
verses.text: We acknowledge too that the Godhead is without beginning, and that the manhood is of recent origin; for the one nature is of the seed of Abraham and David, from whom descended the holy Virgin, but the divine nature was begotten of the God and Father before the ages without time, without passions, without severance.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 21:32
verses.text: But suppose the distinction between flesh and Godhead to be destroyed, what weapons shall we use in our war with Arius and Eunomius? How shall we undo their blasphemy against the only begotten? As it is, we apply the words of humiliation as to man, the words of exaltation and divinity as to God, and the setting forth of the truth is very easy to us.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 21:33
verses.text: But this disquisition on the faith is exceeding the limits of a letter.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 21:34
verses.text: Still even these few words are enough to show the character of the apostolic faith.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 22:1
verses.text: XXII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 22:2
verses.text: To Count Ulpianus.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 22:3
verses.text: It is said that what is faulty in men's ways may be brought to order and improved by words.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 22:4
verses.text: But I think that characters made beautiful by nature, themselves make words fair, though they stand in need of none, just as bodies naturally beautiful need no artificial colouring.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 22:5
verses.text: These qualities are conspicuous in the right eloquent orator Athanasius, and I have been the more pleased with him because he is an ardent lover of your Excellency, and is constantly sounding your praises.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 22:6
verses.text: Here, however, I have striven with him, and in enumerating your high qualities, have outdone him, for I know more about good deeds of yours than he.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 22:7
verses.text: I am however vexed at not being able to praise them all, and to see that my summary of your virtues falls short of what might be said in your praise, but if God grant it even to approach the truth you will hold the pre-eminence in every kind of virtue among all your contemporaries.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 23:1
verses.text: XXIII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 23:2
verses.text: To the Patrician Areobindas.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 23:3
verses.text: In distributing wealth and poverty among men the Creator and Governor of all gives no unjust judgment, but gives the poverty of the poor to the rich as a means of usefulness.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 23:4
verses.text: So He brings chastisement upon men not merely in the infliction of punishment for their faults, but to provide the wealthy with opportunities for shewing kindness to mankind.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 23:5
verses.text: This year the Lord has sent us scourges, far less than our sins, but enough to distress the husbandmen, of whose sufferings I lately made your magnificence acquainted through your own hinds.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 23:6
verses.text: Pity, I beseech you, the tillers of the ground, who have spent their toil with but very little result.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 23:7
verses.text: Be this bad year a suggestion of spiritual abundance, and do ye through the exercise of compassion gather in the harvest of the compassion of God.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 23:8
verses.text: On this account the excellent Dionysius has hurried to your greatness to tell you of the trouble, that he may receive the remedy.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 23:9
verses.text: He carries this letter, like a suppliant's branch of olive, in the hope that by its means he may receive greater kindness.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 24:1
verses.text: XXIV.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 24:2
verses.text: To Andreas Bishop of Samosata.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 24:3
verses.text: Your piety, nursling of God's love, longs, I am sure, for my society.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 24:4
verses.text: But I am all the more eager for yours in proportion as I know that from it more advantage will accrue to me.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 24:5
verses.text: Want somehow naturally makes our wishes the stronger, but the Lord of all is able to give us what we long for.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 24:6
verses.text: He rules all things Himself; knows what is sure to do us good, and never ceases to give every man this boon.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 24:7
verses.text: I really cannot tell you how much delighted I was with your letter, and the very honourable and devout deacon Thalassius increased my pleasure by telling me what I was very anxious to know, for what can be more welcome to me than news that all goes well with you? And what is it that so increases your welfare as the moderation of the great men among us? You have acted like a wise and active physician who does not wait to be sent for, but comes of his own accord to them that need his care.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 24:8
verses.text: This has given me great pleasure, and I have learnt by my own experience what the poet means when he says "laughing through her tears".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 24:9
verses.text: May the bountiful Giver of all good things grant your holiness to excel in them, and to make us emulous of what is praiseworthy in all good men.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 24:10
verses.text: Help us then my dear friend, and persuade him who can to grant our petition.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 25:1
verses.text: XXV.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 25:2
verses.text: Festal.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 25:3
verses.text: When the only begotten God had been made Man, and had wrought out our salvation, they who in those days saw Him from whom these bounties flowed kept no feast.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 25:4
verses.text: But in our time, land and sea, town and hamlet, though they cannot see their benefactor with eyes of sense, keep a feast in memory of all He has done for them; and so great is the joy flowing from these celebrations that the streams of spiritual gladness run in all directions.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 25:5
verses.text: Wherefore we now salute your piety, at once to signify the cheerfulness which the feast has caused in us, and to ask your prayers that we may keep it to the end.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 26:1
verses.text: XXVI.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 26:2
verses.text: Festal.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 26:3
verses.text: The fountains of the Lord's kindness are ever gushing forth with good things for them that believe; but some further good is conveyed by the celebrations which preserve the memory of the greatest of benefits to them that keep the feasts with more good will.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 26:4
verses.text: We have just now celebrated the rites and enjoyed their blessing, and thus salute your piety, for so the custom of the feast and law of love enjoins.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 27:1
verses.text: XXVII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 27:2
verses.text: To Aquilinus, Deacon and Archimandrite.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 27:3
verses.text: No one who has won the divine adoption weeps for orphanhood, for what guardian care can be more powerful than that of our Father which is on high, because of Him fathers of earth are fathers.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 27:4
verses.text: By His will some are made fathers by nature, some by grace.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 27:5
verses.text: To Him then let us hold fast and keep alive the memory of them that are dead.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 27:6
verses.text: For we shall be the better for the recollection of them that have lived well, rousing us to imitation of them.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 28:1
verses.text: XXVIII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 28:2
verses.text: To Jacobus, Presbyter and Monk.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 28:3
verses.text: They who have made the vigour of their manhood bright by virtuous industry hasten happily towards old age, gladdened by the recollection of their former victories, and for old age's sake rid of further struggle.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 28:4
verses.text: This joy I think your own piety possesses, and that you bear your old age the more easily for the recollection of the labours of your youth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 29:1
verses.text: XXIX.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 29:2
verses.text: To Apellion.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 29:3
verses.text: The sufferings of the Carthaginians would demand, and, in their greatness, perhaps out-task, the power of the tragic language of an aeschylus or a Sophocles.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 29:4
verses.text: Carthage of old was with difficulty taken by the Romans.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 29:5
verses.text: Again and again she contended with Rome for the mastery of the world, and brought Rome within danger of destruction.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 29:6
verses.text: Now the ruin has been the mere byplay of barbarians.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 29:7
verses.text: Now dignified members of her far-famed senate wander all over the world, getting means of existence from the bounty of kindly strangers, moving the tears of beholders, and teaching the uncertainty and instability of the lot of man.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 29:8
verses.text: I have seen many who have come thence, and I have felt afraid, for I know not, as the Scripture says, "what the morrow will bring forth".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 29:9
verses.text: Not least do I admire the admirable and most honourable Celestinianus, so bravely does he bear his misfortune, and makes the loss of his happiness an occasion for philosophy, praising the governor of all, and holding that to be good which God either ordains or suffers to be.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 29:10
verses.text: For the wisdom of divine Providence is unspeakable.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 29:11
verses.text: He is travelling with his wife and children, and I beg your excellency to treat him with an hospitality like that of Abraham.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 29:12
verses.text: With perfect confidence in your benevolence I have undertaken to introduce him to you, and I am telling him how generous is your right hand.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 30:1
verses.text: XXX.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 30:2
verses.text: To Aerius the Sophist.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 30:3
verses.text: Now is the time for your Academy to prove the use of your discussions.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 30:4
verses.text: I am told that a brilliant assemblage collects at your house, of which the members are both illustrious by birth and polished of speech, and that you debate about virtue and the immortality of the soul, and other kindred subjects.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 30:5
verses.text: Show now opportunely your nobility of soul and wealth of virtue, and receive the most admirable and honourable Celestinianus in the spirit of men who have learnt the rapid changes of human prosperity.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 30:6
verses.text: He was formerly an ornament of the city of Carthage, where he flung open the doors of his house to many priests, and never thought to need a stranger's kindness.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 30:7
verses.text: Be his spokesman, my friend, and aid him in his need of your voice, for he cannot suffer the advice of the poet which bids him that needeth speak though he be ashamed.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 30:8
verses.text: Persuade I beg you any of your society who are capable of so doing to emulate the hospitality of Alcinous, to remove the poverty which has unexpectedly befallen him, and to change his evil fortune into good.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 30:9
verses.text: Let them praise our kindly Lord for making us wise by other men's calamities, not having sent us to strangers' houses and having brought strangers to our doors.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 30:10
verses.text: To men that shew kindness He promises to give what words cannot express and no intelligence can understand.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 31:1
verses.text: XXXI.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 31:2
verses.text: To Domnus Bishop of Antioch.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 31:3
verses.text: The most admirable and honourable Celestinianus is a native of the famous Carthage, and of an illustrious family in that city.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 31:4
verses.text: Now he has been exiled from it.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 31:5
verses.text: He is wandering in foreign parts, and has to look to the benevolence of them that love God.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 31:6
verses.text: He carries with him a burden from which he cannot escape and which increases his care—I mean his wife, his children and his servants, for whom he is at great expense.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 31:7
verses.text: I wonder at his spirit.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 31:8
verses.text: For he praises the great Pilot as though he were being borne by favourable breezes, and cares nothing for the terrible storm.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 31:9
verses.text: From his calamity he has reaped the fruit of piety, and this thrice blessed gain has been brought him by his misfortune; for while he was in prosperity he never accepted this teaching, but when the evil day left him bare, among the rest of his losses he lost his impiety too, and now possesses the wealth of the faith, and for its sake thinks little of his ruin.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 31:10
verses.text: I therefore beseech your holiness to let him find a fatherland in these foreign parts, and to charge them that abound in riches to comfort one who once was endowed like themselves, and to scatter the dark cloud of his calamity.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 31:11
verses.text: It is only right and proper that among men of like nature, where all have erred, they that have escaped chastisement should bring comfort to them that have fallen on evil days, and by their sympathy for these latter propitiate the mercy of God.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 32:1
verses.text: XXXII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 32:2
verses.text: To the Bishop Theoctistus.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 32:3
verses.text: If the God of all had forthwith inflicted punishment on all that err he would utterly have destroyed all men.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 32:4
verses.text: But He spares; He is a merciful Judge; and therefore some He chastises, and to others He gives the lesson of the punishment of the chastised.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 32:5
verses.text: An instance of this merciful dealing has been shewn in our times.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 32:6
verses.text: Exiles from what was once known as Libya, but is now called Africa, have been brought by Him to our doors, and by shewing us their sufferings He moves us to fear, and by fear rouses us to sympathy; thus He accomplishes two ends at once, for He both benefits us by their chastisement, and to them by our means brings comfort.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 32:7
verses.text: This comfort I now beg you to give to the very admirable and honourable Celestinianus, a man who once was an ornament of the Africans' chief city, but now has neither city nor home, nor any of the necessaries of life.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 32:8
verses.text: Now it is proper that those who in the jurisdiction of your holiness have been entrusted with the pastoral care of souls should bring before their fellow citizens what is for their good, for indeed they need such teaching.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 32:9
verses.text: For this reason, as we know, the divine Apostle in his Epistle to Titus writes "Let ours also learn to maintain good works for necessary uses," for if our city, solitary as it is, and with only a small population, and that a poor one, succours the strangers, much rather may Beroea, which has been nurtured in true religion, be expected to do so, especially under the leadership of your holiness.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 33:1
verses.text: XXXIII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 33:2
verses.text: To Stasimus,Count and Primate.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 33:3
verses.text: To narrate the sufferings of the most honourable and dignified Celestinianus would require tragic eloquence.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 33:4
verses.text: Tragic writers set forth fully the ills of humanity, but I can only in a word inform your excellency that his country is Libya, so long on all men's tongues, his city the far famed Carthage, his hereditary rank a seat in her famous council, his circumstances affluent.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 33:5
verses.text: But all this is now a tale, mere words stripped bare of realities.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 33:6
verses.text: The barbarian war has deprived him of all this.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 33:7
verses.text: But such is fortune; she refuses to remain always with the same men and hastens to change her abode to dwell with others.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 33:8
verses.text: I beg to introduce this guest to your excellency, and beseech you that he may enjoy your far famed beneficence.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 33:9
verses.text: I beg also that through your excellency he may become known to all those who are in office and opulence, in order that you may both become a means of advantage to them and win the higher reward from our merciful God.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 34:1
verses.text: XXXIV.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 34:2
verses.text: To the Count Patricius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 34:3
verses.text: All kinds of goodness are praiseworthy, but all are made more beautiful by loving kindness.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 34:4
verses.text: For it we earnestly pray the God of all; through it alone we obtain forgiveness when we err; it makes wealth stoop to the poor, and because I know that your Excellency is richly endowed with it I confidently commend to you the admirable and excellent Celestinianus, once lord of vast wealth and possessions and suddenly stripped of all, but bearing his poverty as easily as few men bear their riches.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 34:5
verses.text: The subject of the tragedy involving the fall of his fortunes is the barbarian invasion of Libya and Carthage.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 34:6
verses.text: I have introduced him to your greatness; pray suggest his case to others, and move them to pity.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 34:7
verses.text: You will win greater gain by giving many a lesson in loving kindness:.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 35:1
verses.text: XXXV.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 35:2
verses.text: To the Bishop Irenaeus.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 35:3
verses.text: You are conspicuous, my Lord, for many forms of goodness, and your holiness is beautified in an especial degree by loving-kindness, by contempt of riches, and by a generosity that gushes forth for the help of them that need.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 35:4
verses.text: I know too that you deem worthy of more than ordinary attention those who have been brought up in prosperity and have fallen from it into trouble.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 35:5
verses.text: Knowing this as well as I do I venture to make known to you the very admirable and excellent Celestinianus.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 35:6
verses.text: He was once well known in Carthage for wealth and position, now stripped of these he is favourably known by his piety and philosophy, for he bears what men call misfortune with resignation because it has brought him to the salvation of his soul.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 35:7
verses.text: He came to me with a letter which described his former prosperity, and after he had passed several days with me I proved the truth of what was said of him by experience.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 35:8
verses.text: I have therefore no hesitation in commending him to your Holiness, and begging you to make him known to the well-to-do men of the city.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 35:9
verses.text: It is probable that when they have learnt what has befallen him, in fear of a like fate befalling themselves, they will endeavour to escape judgment by shewing mercy.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 35:10
verses.text: He has no resource but to go about begging, as he is put to the greater expense because he has with him his wife and children, and the domestics who with him escaped the violence of the barbarians.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 36:1
verses.text: XXXVI.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 36:2
verses.text: To Pompianus, Bishop of Emesa.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 36:3
verses.text: I know very well that your means are small and your heart is great, and that in your case generosity is not prevented by limited resources.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 36:4
verses.text: I therefore introduce to your holiness the admirable and excellent Celestinianus, once enjoying much wealth and prosperity, but now escaped from the hands of the barbarians with nothing but freedom, and having no means of livelihood except the mercy of men like your piety.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 36:5
verses.text: And cares crowd round him, for travelling with him are his wife, children and servants, whom he has brought with him from no motives but those of humanity, for he cannot think it right to dismiss them when they refuse to abandon him.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 36:6
verses.text: I beg you of your goodness to make him known to our wealthy citizens, for I think that, after being informed by your holiness and seeing how soon prosperity may fall away, they will bethink them of our common humanity, and, in imitation of your magnanimity, will give him such help as they can.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 37:1
verses.text: XXXVII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 37:2
verses.text: To Salustius the Governor.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 37:3
verses.text: When rulers keep the scales of justice true, and let them hang in even balance, they confer all kinds of benefits upon their subjects; if they are also gifted with prudence and further show loving-kindness to him that needs it, manifold advantages accrue from their rule to them that live under it.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 37:4
verses.text: Having enjoyed these good things through your excellency, and having experienced them in your former administration, they have now been moved with joy at the information that to your munificence the helm of government has been entrusted.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 37:5
verses.text: I pray that they may gain yet greater good, that your excellency may win still higher praise, and that the encomiums of your eulogists may be vindicated by the addition to all your other honourable titles to fame of that colophon of good things—true religion.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 37:6
verses.text: As I was compelled to pass several days in Hierapolis I hoped to have the pleasure of meeting your excellency, and persistently enquired of new comers if the insignia of office had been conveyed to you.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 37:7
verses.text: But I was compelled by the divine feast of salvation to return in haste to the city entrusted to me.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 37:8
verses.text: Now however that I have received your excellency's letter, with very great pleasure I return your salutation, and without delay have sent, as you requested, the honourable and pious deacon who is by God's grace a water-finder.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 37:9
verses.text: May the Lord in His loving kindness grant him both to do good service to the city and increase your excellency's glory.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 38:1
verses.text: XXXVIII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 38:2
verses.text: Festal.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 38:3
verses.text: The divine feast of salvation has brought us the founts of God's good gifts, the blessing of the Cross, and the immortality which sprang from our Lord's death, the resurrection of our Lord Jesus Christ which gives promise of the resurrection of us all.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 38:4
verses.text: These being the gifts of the feast, such its exhibition of the bounty of divine grace, it has filled us with spiritual gladness.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 38:5
verses.text: But encompassed as we are on every side by many and great calamities, the brightness of the feast is dimmed, and lamentation and wailing are mingled with our psalmody.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 38:6
verses.text: Such sorrows does sin bring forth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 38:7
verses.text: It is sin which has filled our life with pangs; it is on account of sin that death is lovelier to us than life; it is on account of sin that when we think in imagination of that incorruptible tribunal we shudder even at the life to come.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 38:8
verses.text: So may your piety pray that God's loving-kindness may light on us, and that this gloomy and terrible cloud may be dispersed and sunshine again quickly give us joy.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 39:1
verses.text: XXXIX.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 39:2
verses.text: Festal.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 39:3
verses.text: My wish was to write in cheerful terms and sound the note of the spiritual joy of the feast, but I am prevented by the multitude of our sins, which are bringing on us the judgment of God.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 39:4
verses.text: For who indeed can be so insensible as not to perceive the divine wrath? May your piety then pray that affairs may undergo a change for the better; that so we too may change the style of our letter, and write words of cheerfulness instead of those of wailing.
