verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 40:1
verses.text: XL.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 40:2
verses.text: To Theodorus the Vicar.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 40:3
verses.text: The custom of the feast bids me write a festal letter, but the cloud of our calamities suffers me not to gather the usual happy fruit from it.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 40:4
verses.text: Who is so stony-hearted as not to be shocked and affrighted at the anger and grief of the Lord? Who is not stirred to the memory of faults? Who does not look for the righteous sentence? All this dims the brightness of the feast, but the Lord is full of loving-kindness, and we trust He will not actually fulfil His threats, but will look mercifully on us, scatter our sadness, open the springs of mercy, and shew His wonted long suffering.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 40:5
verses.text: I salute your greatness, and beseech you to send me news of the health I sincerely trust you are enjoying.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 41:1
verses.text: XLI.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 41:2
verses.text: To Claudianus.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 41:3
verses.text: The divine Celebration has as usual conferred on us its spiritual boons; but the sour fruits of sin have not suffered us to enjoy them with gladness.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 41:4
verses.text: They have had their usual results; in the beginning they caused thorns, caltrops, sweats, toil and pain to sprout; at the present moment sin sets the earth quaking against us, and makes nations rise against us on every side.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 41:5
verses.text: And we lament because we force the good Lord, who is wishful to do us good, to do us ill, and compel Him to inflict punishment.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 41:6
verses.text: Yet when we bethink us of the unfathomable depths of His pity we are comforted, and trust that the Lord will not cast off His people, neither will He forsake His inheritance.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 41:7
verses.text: While saluting your magnificence I beseech you to give me news of your much-wished for health.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 42:1
verses.text: XLII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 42:2
verses.text: To Constantius the Prefect.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 42:3
verses.text: Did no necessity compel me to address a letter to your greatness, I might haply be found guilty of presumption, for neither taking due measure of myself nor recognising the greatness of your power.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 42:4
verses.text: But now that all that is left of the city and district which God has committed to my charge is in peril of utterly perishing, and certain men have dared to bring calumnious charges against the recent visitation, I am sure your magnificence will pardon the boldness of my letter when you enquire into the necessity of the case, my own object in writing.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 42:5
verses.text: I groan and lament at being compelled to write against a man over whose errors one ought to throw a veil, because he is of the clerical order.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 42:6
verses.text: Nevertheless I write to defend the cause of the poor whom he is wronging.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 42:7
verses.text: After being charged with many crimes and excluded from the Communion, pending the assembly of the sacred Synod, in alarm at the decision of the episcopal council he has made his escape from this place, thereby trampling, as he supposed, on the laws of the Church, and, by his contempt of the sentence of excommunication has laid bare his motive.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 42:8
verses.text: He has undertaken an accusation not even fit for men of mean crafts, and in consequence of his ill-feeling towards the illustrious Philip has proceeded against the wretched tax-payers.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 42:9
verses.text: I feel that it is quite needless for me to mention his character, his course of life from the beginning and the greatness of his wrong-doings, but this one thing I do beseech your Excellency, not to believe his lies, but to ratify the visitation, and spare the wretched tax-payers.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 42:10
verses.text: Aye, spare the thrice wretched decurions who cannot exact the moneys demanded of them.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 42:11
verses.text: Who indeed is ignorant of the severity of the taxation of the acres among us? On this account most of our landowners have fled, our hinds have run away, and the greater part of our lands are deserted.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 42:12
verses.text: In discussing the land there will be no impropriety in our using geometrical terms.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 42:13
verses.text: Of our country the length is forty milestones, and the breadth the same.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 42:14
verses.text: It includes many high mountains, some wholly bare, and some covered with unproductive vegetation.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 42:15
verses.text: Within this district there are fifty thousand free jugers, and besides that ten thousand which belong to the imperial treasury.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 42:16
verses.text: Now only let your wisdom consider how great is the wrong.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 42:17
verses.text: For if none of the country had been uncultivated, and it had all furnished easy husbandry for the hinds, they would nevertheless have sunk under the tribute, unable to endure the severity of the taxation.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 42:18
verses.text: And here is a proof of what I say.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 42:19
verses.text: In the time of Isidorus of glorious memory, fifteen thousand acres were taxed in gold, but the exactors of the Comitian assessment, unable to bear the loss, frequently complained, and by offerings besought your high dignity to let them off two thousand five hundred for the unproductive acres, and your excellency's predecessors in this office ordered the unproductive acreage to be taken off the unfortunate decurions, and an equivalent number to be substituted for the Comitian; and not even thus are they able to complete the tale.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 42:20
verses.text: So with many words I ask your favour, and beseech your magnificence to put aside the false accusations that are made against the wretched tax-payers, to stem the tide of distress in this unhappy district, and let it once more lift its head.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 42:21
verses.text: Thus you will leave an imperishable memory of honour to future generations.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 42:22
verses.text: I am joined in my supplication to you by all the saints of our district, and especially by that right holy and pious man of God, the Lord Jacobus, who holds silence in such great esteem that he cannot be induced to write, but he prays that our city, which is made illustrious by having him as neighbour and is protected by his prayers, may receive the boon which I ask.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 43:1
verses.text: XLIII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 43:2
verses.text: To the Augusta Pulcheria.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 43:3
verses.text: Since you adorn the empire by your piety and render the purple brighter by your faith, we make bold to write to you, no longer conscious of our insignificance in that you always pay all due honour to the clergy.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 43:4
verses.text: With these sentiments I beseech your majesty to deign to show clemency to our unhappy country, to order the ratification of the visitation which has been several times made, and not to accept the false accusations which some men have brought against it.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 43:5
verses.text: I beseech you to give no credit to him who bears indeed the name of bishop, but whose mode of action is unworthy even of respectable slaves.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 43:6
verses.text: He has been himself under serious charges and subject to the bann of excommunication under the most holy and God-beloved archbishop of Antioch, the Lord Domnus, pending the summoning of the episcopal council for the investigation of the charges against him.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 43:7
verses.text: He has now made his escape, and betaken himself to the imperial city, where he plies the trade of an informer, attacking the country which is his mother country with its thousands of poor, and, for the sake of his hatred to one, wags his tongue against all.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 43:8
verses.text: Out of regard to what is becoming to me I will say nothing as to his character and education, and indeed he shows only too plainly what he has at present in hand.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 43:9
verses.text: But of the district I will say this, that when the whole province had its burdens lightened, this portion, although it bore a very heavy share of the burden, never enjoyed the benefit of relaxation.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 43:10
verses.text: The result is that many estates are deprived of husbandmen; nay, many are altogether abandoned by their owners, while the wretched decurions have demands made on them for these very properties, and, being quite unable to bear the exaction, betake themselves some to begging, and some to flight.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 43:11
verses.text: The city seems to be reduced to one man, and he will not be able to hold out unless your piety supplies a remedy.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 43:12
verses.text: But I am in hopes that your serenity will heal the wounds in the city and add yet this one more to your many good deeds.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 44:1
verses.text: XLIV.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 44:2
verses.text: To the PatricianSenator.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 44:3
verses.text: Thanks be to the Saviour of the world because to your greatness He is ever adding dignity and honour.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 44:4
verses.text: The reason of my not writing up to this time to exhibit the delight which I have felt at the colophon of your honour, has been my wish not to trouble your magnificence.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 44:5
verses.text: At the moment of my now thus writing, the district which Providence has committed to my care stands as the proverb has it on a razor's edge.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 44:6
verses.text: You will remember the visitation which was made at the time when we first were benefited by your presence among us; how it was with difficulty established in the time of the most excellent prefect the Lord Florentius; and how it was confirmed by the present holder of the office.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 44:7
verses.text: An individual who bears the name of bishop, but of ways unworthy even of stage players, has fled from the episcopal synod at a time when he was lying under sentence of excommunication and is endeavouring to calumniate and discredit the visitation, while through his hatred to the illustrious Philip he assails the truth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 44:8
verses.text: I therefore beseech your excellency to make his lies of none effect, and that the visitation lawfully confirmed may remain undisturbed.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 44:9
verses.text: It is indeed becoming to your greatness to reap the fruit of this good deed among the rest, to receive the acclamations of those whom you are benefiting, and so to do honour at once to the God of all and to his true servant the very man of God the Lord Jacob, who joins with me in sending you this supplication.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 44:10
verses.text: Had it been his wont to write he would have written himself.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 45:1
verses.text: XLV.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 45:2
verses.text: To the Patrician Anatolius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 45:3
verses.text: Your greatness knows full well how all the inhabitants of the East feel towards your magnificence, as sons feel towards an affectionate father.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 45:4
verses.text: Why then have you shewn hate to them that love you, deprived them of your kindly care, and driven them all to weeping and lamentation by putting your own advantage before the service of others? In truth I think there is not one of them that fear the Lord who is not much grieved at losing your official sway, and I think that even all the rest, although they have not right knowledge about divine things, when they reflect on the kindnesses you have conferred, share in these sentiments of distress.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 45:5
verses.text: I for my part am specially sorry when I bethink me of your dignity and your unaffected character, and I pray the God of all ever to bestow on you the bulwark of His invincible right hand, and supply you with abundance of all kinds of blessings.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 45:6
verses.text: We beseech your excellency no less when absent than when present to extend to us your accustomed protection, and to undo the rage of that unworthy bishop of ours whose purposes are perfectly well known to your greatness.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 45:7
verses.text: He is endeavouring, as I am informed, to work the entire ruin of our district, and has accepted the part of an informer to culumniate the recent visitation, and this when all in a word know that the taxation of our district is very heavy, and that in consequence many estates have been abandoned by the husbandmen.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 45:8
verses.text: But this man, in contempt of his excommunication, and in flight from the holy synod, has thrust out his tongue against the unhappy poor.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 45:9
verses.text: May your magnificence then consent to look to it that the truth be not vanquished by a lie.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 45:10
verses.text: And I bring the same supplication about the Cilicians.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 45:11
verses.text: For we cease not to wail till the iniquity be undone.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 45:12
verses.text: The Lord, who promises to reward even a drop of water, will requite you for this trouble.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 46:1
verses.text: XLVI.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 46:2
verses.text: To the Learned Petrus.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 46:3
verses.text: Nothing is able to stay the praiseworthy purpose of them that highly esteem what is right.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 46:4
verses.text: That this is the case is confirmed by the grief shown by your magnificence at the news you have lately received, and your refusal to overlook the attack that right has suffered.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 46:5
verses.text: You have opportunely put away your distress, and righteously stopped the mouth of the enemy of the truth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 46:6
verses.text: No sooner did we hear of this, and found true philosophy so coupled with rhetorical skill, than we felt the more warmly disposed towards your excellence.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 46:7
verses.text: Now we beseech you the more earnestly to counteract this fine fellow's lies and confirm the comfort given to the unhappy poor.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 47:1
verses.text: XLVII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 47:2
verses.text: To Proclus, Bishop of Constantinople.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 47:3
verses.text: A year ago, thanks to your holiness, the illustrious Philip governor of our city was delivered from serious danger.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 47:4
verses.text: After entering into the enjoyment of the security which he owed to your kindness, he filled our ears with your praises.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 47:5
verses.text: But all your labour a certain most pious personage was endeavouring to make null and void.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 47:6
verses.text: The visitation made several times twelve years ago he calumniates, and has adopted a style of slander which would be unbecoming even in a respectable slave.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 47:7
verses.text: Now I beseech your sanctity to put a stop to his lies, and to induce the illustrious praefects to ratify the decision which they duly and mercifully gave.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 47:8
verses.text: As a matter of fact our city was taxed more severely than all the cities of the provinces, and after every city had been relieved ours continued to this day assessed at over sixty-two thousand acres.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 47:9
verses.text: At last the occupants of that seat of honour were with difficulty induced to send inspectors of the district; their report was first received by Isidorus of famous memory and confirmed by the glorious and Christ-loving lord Florentius, and the whole matter was very carefully enquired into by our present ruler, whose equity adorns the throne, and he confirmed the assessment by an imperial decree.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 47:10
verses.text: But this truth-loving person, all for his hatred of one single individual, the excellent Philip, has declared war against the poor.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 47:11
verses.text: Under these circumstances I implore your holiness to array the forces of your righteous eloquence against his eloquence of wrong, to throw your shield over the truth which is attacked and at once prove her strength and the futility of lies.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 48:1
verses.text: XLVIII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 48:2
verses.text: To Eustathius, Bishop of Berytus.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 48:3
verses.text: I have gladly received the accusation, although I have no difficulty in disproving the indictment.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 48:4
verses.text: I have written not three letters only but four; and I suspect one of two things; either those who promised to convey the letters did me wrong in the matter of their delivery, or else your piety, though in receipt of them, is yet anxious for more, and so gets up a charge of idleness against me.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 48:5
verses.text: I, as I said before, am not distressed at the accusation, for it is plain proof to me of the warmth of your affection.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 48:6
verses.text: Continue then to ply your craft, cease not to prefer your complaint and so to cause pleasure to myself.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 49:1
verses.text: XLIX.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 49:2
verses.text: To Damianus,Bishop of Sidon.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 49:3
verses.text: It is the nature of mirrors to reflect the faces of them that gaze into them, and so whoever looks at them sees his own form.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 49:4
verses.text: This is the same too with the pupils of the eyes, for they shew in them the likeness of other people's features.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 49:5
verses.text: Of this your holiness furnishes an instance, for you have not seen my ugliness, but have beheld with admiration your own beauty.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 49:6
verses.text: I really have none of the qualities which you have mentioned.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 49:7
verses.text: It is nevertheless my prayer that your words may be vindicated by actual fact, and I beseech your piety by your prayers to cause it to come to pass that your praises may not fall to the ground through having no reality to correspond with them.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 50:1
verses.text: L.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 50:2
verses.text: To the Archimandrite Gerontius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 50:3
verses.text: The characters of souls are often depicted in words and their unseen forms revealed; so now your reverence's letter exhibits the piety of your holy soul.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 50:4
verses.text: Your waiting for that sentence, your anxiety, your search for advocates and preparation for a defence, clearly indicate your soul's zeal about divine things.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 50:5
verses.text: We on the contrary are in a manner inactive and sleepy; we are nurtured in idleness, and stand in need of much assistance from prayers.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 50:6
verses.text: Give them to us, O man beloved of God, that now at all events we may wake up and give some care to the soul.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 51:1
verses.text: LI.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 51:2
verses.text: To the Presbyter Agapius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 51:3
verses.text: The works of virtue are admirable in themselves, but yet more admirable do they appear if they find an eloquence able to report them well.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 51:4
verses.text: Neither of these advantages has been lacking in the case of the bishop beloved of God, the lord Thomas, for he himself has contributed his own labours on behalf of piety, and has found in your holiness a tongue to bestow meet praise on those labours.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 51:5
verses.text: Coming as he did with such testimony in his favour we have been all the more delighted to see him, and, after enjoying his society for a short space, have dismissed him to his charge.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 52:1
verses.text: LII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 52:2
verses.text: To Ibas, Bishop of Edessa.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 52:3
verses.text: It is, I think, of His providential care for our common salvation that the God of all brings on some men certain calamities, that chastisement may prove to be to them that have erred a healing remedy; to virtue's athletes an encouragement to constancy; and to all who look on a beneficial exemplar.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 52:4
verses.text: For it is natural that when we see others punished we should be filled with fear ourselves.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 52:5
verses.text: In view of these considerations I look on the trouble of Africa as a general advantage.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 52:6
verses.text: In the first place when I bear in mind their former prosperity and now look on their sudden overthrow, I see how variable are all human affairs, and learn a twofold lesson;—not to rejoice in felicity as though it would never come to an end, nor be distressed at calamities as hard to bear.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 52:7
verses.text: Then I recall the memory of past errors, and tremble lest I fall into like sufferings.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 52:8
verses.text: My main motive in now writing to you is to introduce to your holiness the very God-beloved bishop Cyprianus, who starting from the famous Africa is now compelled, by the savagery of the barbarians, to travel in foreign lands.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 52:9
verses.text: He has brought a letter to us from the very holy bishop the lord Eusebius, who wisely rules the Galatians.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 52:10
verses.text: When your piety has received him with your wonted kindness I beg you to send him with a letter to whatever pious bishops you may think fit so that while he enjoys their kindly consolation he may be the means of their receiving heavenly and lasting benefits.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 53:1
verses.text: LIII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 53:2
verses.text: To Sophronius, Bishop of Constantina.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 53:3
verses.text: Since I know, O God-beloved, how generous and bountiful is your right hand, I put a coveted boon within your reach; for just as men hungry for this world's gain are annoyed at the sight of them that stand in need of pecuniary aid, so the liberal are delighted, because the riches they reach after are heavenly.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 53:4
verses.text: A man who furnishes this excellent opportunity is the God-beloved bishop Cyprianus, formerly known among them that minister to others, but now, while he gives a deplorable account of the African calamities, he has to look to the benevolence of others, and depends on the bounty of pious souls.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 53:5
verses.text: I hope that he too will enjoy your brotherly kindness, and will be forwarded with letters to other havens of refuge.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 54:1
verses.text: LIV.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 54:2
verses.text: Festal.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 54:3
verses.text: By our divine and saving celebrations both the down-hearted are cheered, and the joyous made yet more joyful.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 54:4
verses.text: This I have learnt by experience, for, when whelmed in the waves of despair, I have risen superior to the surge at sight of the haven of the feast.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 54:5
verses.text: May your piety pray that I may be wholly rescued from this storm, and that our loving Lord may grant me forgetfulness of my sorrow.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 55:1
verses.text: LV.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 55:2
verses.text: Festal.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 55:3
verses.text: We are much distressed, for we are gifted with the nature not of rocks but of men, but the recollection of the Lord's Epiphany has been to me a very potent medicine; so at once I write, according to the custom of the feast, and salute your magnificence with a prayer that you may live in prosperity and repute.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 56:1
verses.text: LVI.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 56:2
verses.text: Festal.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 56:3
verses.text: My grief is now at its height and my mind is seriously affected by it, but I have thought it right to fulfil the custom of the feast, so now I take my pen to salute your reverence and pay the debt of affection.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 57:1
verses.text: LVII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 57:2
verses.text: To the Praefect Eutrechius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 57:3
verses.text: Besides other boons the Ruler of the universe has granted to us that of hearing of your excellency's honour, and of congratulating at once yourself on your elevation and your subjects on so gentle a rule.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 57:4
verses.text: I have thought it wrong to give no expression to my satisfaction and to refrain from manifesting it by letter.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 57:5
verses.text: Your magnificence knows quite well how warm is our affection towards you—an affection most warmly reciprocated.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 57:6
verses.text: And being so filled with love we beseech the Giver of all good things ever to pour on you His manifold gifts.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 58:1
verses.text: LVIII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 58:2
verses.text: To the Consul Nomus.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 58:3
verses.text: I am divided in mind at the idea of sending a letter to your greatness.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 58:4
verses.text: On the one hand I know how everything depends on your judgment; I see you under the weight of public anxieties, and so think it better to be silent.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 58:5
verses.text: On the other hand, being well aware of the breadth and capacity of your intelligence, I cannot bear to say nothing, and am afraid of being charged with negligence.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 58:6
verses.text: I am moreover stimulated by the longing regret left with me by the short taste I had of your society.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 58:7
verses.text: My full enjoyment of it was prevented by the disease and death of that most blessed man, so now I think writing will be a comfort.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 58:8
verses.text: I pray the Master of all to guide your life that it be ever borne on favourable breezes and so we may reap the benefit of your kindly care.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 59:1
verses.text: LIX.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 59:2
verses.text: To Claudianus.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 59:3
verses.text: Sincere friendships are neither dissolved by distance of place nor weakened by time.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 59:4
verses.text: Time indeed inflicts indignities on our bodies, spoils them of the bloom of their beauty, and brings on old age; but of friendship he makes the beauty yet more blooming, ever kindling its fire to greater warmth and brightness.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 59:5
verses.text: So separated as I am from your magnificence by many a day's march, pricked by the goad of friendship I indite you this letter of salutation.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 59:6
verses.text: It is conveyed by the standard-bearer Patroinus, a man who on account of his high character is worthy of all respect, for he endeavours with much zeal to observe the laws of God.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 59:7
verses.text: Deign, most excellent sir, to give us by him information of your excellency's precious health, and of the desired fulfilment of your promise.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 60:1
verses.text: LX.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 60:2
verses.text: To Dioscorus, Bishop of Alexandria.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 60:3
verses.text: Among many forms of virtue by which we hear that your holiness is adorned (for all men's ears are filled by the flying fame of your glory, which speeds in all directions) special praise is unanimously given to your modesty, a characteristic of which our Lord in His law has given Himself as an ensample, saying, "Learn of me; for I am meek and lowly in heart;" for though God is high, or rather most high He honoured at His incarnation the meek and lowly spirit.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 60:4
verses.text: Looking then to Him, sir, you do not behold the multitude of your subjects nor the exaltation of your throne, but you see rather human nature, and life's rapid changes, and follow the divine laws whose observance gives us the kingdom of heaven.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 60:5
verses.text: Hearing of this modesty on the part of your holiness, I take courage in a letter to salute a person sacred and dear to God, and I offer prayers whereof the fruit is salvation.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 60:6
verses.text: Occasion is given me to write by the very pious presbyter Eusebius, for when I heard of his journey thither I immediately indited this letter to call upon your holiness to support us by your prayers, and by your reply to give us a spiritual feast, sending to us who are hungry the blessed banquet of your words.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 61:1
verses.text: LXI.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 61:2
verses.text: To the Presbyter Archibius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 61:3
verses.text: I did not let the two letters which I had just received from you go unheeded, but wrote without delay, and gave my letter to the very devout presbyter Eusebius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 61:4
verses.text: In consequence of some delay, it was for the time postponed, for the weather kept the vessels within the harbour, inasmuch as it indicated a coming storm at sea and bade sailors and pilots wait awhile.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 61:5
verses.text: So I discharged this debt for the time, not that I may cease to be a debtor but that I may increase the debt.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 61:6
verses.text: For this obligation becomes many times greater by being discharged, inasmuch as they who try to observe the laws of friendship increase the potency of its love, and, blowing sparks into a flame, kindle a greater warmth of affection, while all who are fired thereby strive to surpass one another in love.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 61:7
verses.text: Receive then my defence, my venerable friend; forgive me; and send me a letter to tell me how you are.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 62:1
verses.text: LXII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 62:2
verses.text: To the Presbyter John.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 62:3
verses.text: A saying of one of the men who used to be called wise was, "Live unseen".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 62:4
verses.text: I applaud the sentiment, and have determined to confirm the word by deed, for I see no impropriety in gathering what is good from others, just as bees, it is said, gather their honey and draw forth the sweet dew from bitter herbs as well as from them that are good to eat, and I myself have seen them settling on a barren rock and sucking up its scanty moisture.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 62:5
verses.text: Far more reasonable is it for them that are credited with reason to harvest what is good from every source; so, as I said, I try to live unseen, and above all men am I a lover of peace and quiet.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 62:6
verses.text: On his recent return from your part of the world the very pious presbyter Eusebius announced that you had held a certain meeting, and that in the course of conversation mention had been made of me, and that your piety spoke with praise of my insignificant self.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 62:7
verses.text: I have therefore deemed it ungrateful, and indeed unfair, that he who spoke thus well and kindly of me should fail to be paid in like coin; for although we have done nothing worthy of praise still we admire the intention of them that thus praise us, for such praise is the off-spring of affection.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 62:8
verses.text: Wherefore I salute your reverence, using as a means of conveyance of my letter him who has brought to me the unwritten words which you have spoken about me.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 62:9
verses.text: When, most pious sir, you have received my letter, write in reply.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 62:10
verses.text: You were first in speech; I in writing; and I answer speech by letter.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 62:11
verses.text: It remains now to you to answer letter for letter.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 63:1
verses.text: LXIII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 63:2
verses.text: Festal.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 63:3
verses.text: We have enjoyed the wonted blessings of the Feast.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 63:4
verses.text: We have kept the memorial Feast of the Passion of Salvation; by means of the resurrection of the Lord we have received the glad tidings of the resurrection of all, and have hymned the ineffable loving kindness of our God and Saviour.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 63:5
verses.text: But the storm tossing the churches has not suffered us to take our share of unalloyed gladness.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 63:6
verses.text: If, when one member is in pain the whole body is partaker of the pang, how can we forbear from lamentation when all the body is distressed? And it intensifies our discouragement to think that these things are the prelude of the general apostasy.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 63:7
verses.text: May your piety pray that since we are in this plight we may get the divine succour, that, as the divine Apostle phrases it, we may "be able to withstand the evil day".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 63:8
verses.text: But if any time remain for this life's business, pray that the tempest may pass away, and the churches recover their former calm, that the enemies of the truth may no more exult at our misfortunes.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 64:1
verses.text: LXIV.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 64:2
verses.text: Festal.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 64:3
verses.text: When the Master underwent the Passion of salvation for the sake of mankind, the company of the sacred Apostles was much disheartened, for they knew not clearly what was to be the Passion's fruit.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 64:4
verses.text: But when they knew the salvation that grew therefrom, they called the proclamation of the Passion glad tidings, and eagerly offered it to all mankind.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 64:5
verses.text: And they that believed, as being enlightened in mind, cheerfully received it, and keep the Feast in memory of the Passion, and make the moment of death an opportunity for entertainment and festivity.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 64:6
verses.text: For the close connexion with it of the resurrection does away with the sadness of death, and becomes a pledge for the resurrection of all.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 64:7
verses.text: After just now taking part in this celebration, we send you these tidings of the feast as though they were some fragrant perfume, and salute your piety.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 65:1
verses.text: LXV.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 65:2
verses.text: To the General Zeno.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 65:3
verses.text: To be smitten by human ills is the common lot of all men; to endure them bravely and rise superior to their attack is no longer common.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 65:4
verses.text: The former is of human nature; the latter depends upon resolution.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 65:5
verses.text: It is on this account that we wonder how the philosophers resolved on the noblest course of life and conquered their calamities by wisdom.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 65:6
verses.text: And philosophy is produced by our reason's power, which rules our passions and is not led to and fro by them.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 65:7
verses.text: Now one of human ills is grief, and it is this which we exhort your excellency to overcome, and it will not be difficult for you to rise victorious over this feeling, if you consider human nature, and take to heart the uselessness of sorrow.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 65:8
verses.text: For what gain will it be to the departed that we should wail and lament? When, however, we reflect upon the common birth, the long years of intercourse, the splendid service in the field, and the far-famed achievements, let us reflect that he who was adorned by them was a man subject to the law of death; that moreover all things are ordained by God, who guides the affairs of men in accordance with His sacred knowledge of what will be for their good.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 65:9
verses.text: Thus have I written so far as the limits of a letter would allow me, beseeching your eminence for all our sakes to preserve your health, which is wont to be maintained by cheerfulness and ruined by despondency.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 65:10
verses.text: Wherefore in my care for the advantage of us all I have penned this letter.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 66:1
verses.text: LXVI.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 66:2
verses.text: To Aerius the Sophist.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 66:3
verses.text: She that gave you birth and nurtured you invites you to the longed-for feast.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 66:4
verses.text: The holy shrine is crowned by a roof; it is fitly adorned; it is eager for the inhabitants for whom it was erected.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 66:5
verses.text: These are Apostles and Prophets, loud-voiced heralds of the old and new covenant.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 66:6
verses.text: Adorn, therefore, the feast with your presence; receive the blessing which swells forth from it, and make the feast more joyous to us.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 67:1
verses.text: LXVII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 67:2
verses.text: To Maranas.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 67:3
verses.text: It was thy work, my good Sir, to call the rest also to the feast of the dedication.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 67:4
verses.text: Through thy zeal and energy the holy temple has been built, and the loud-voiced heralds of the truth have come to dwell therein, and guard them that approach thither in faith.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 67:5
verses.text: Nevertheless I write and signify the season of the feast.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 68:1
verses.text: LXVIII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 68:2
verses.text: To Epiphanius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 68:3
verses.text: It was my wish to summon you to the feast of holy Apostles and Prophets, not only as a citizen, but as one who shares both my faith and my home.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 68:4
verses.text: But I am prevented by the state of your opinions.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 68:5
verses.text: Therefore I put forward no other claims than those of our country, and I invite you to participate in the precious blessing of the holy Apostles and Prophets.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 68:6
verses.text: This participation no difference of sentiment hinders.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 69:1
verses.text: LXIX.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 69:2
verses.text: To Eugraphia.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 69:3
verses.text: Had I not been unavoidably prevented, I should no sooner have heard that your great and glorious husband had fallen asleep than I should straightway have hurried to your side.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 69:4
verses.text: I have enjoyed at your hands many and various kinds of honour, and I owe you full many thanks.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 69:5
verses.text: When hindered, much against my will, from paying my debt, I deemed it ill-advised to send you a letter at the very moment, when your grief was at its height; when it was impossible for my messenger to approach your excellency, and when grief prevented you from reading what I wrote.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 69:6
verses.text: But now that your reason has had time to wake from the intoxication of grief, to repress your emotion, and to discipline the license of sorrow, I have made bold to write and to beseech your excellency to bethink you of human nature, to reflect how common is the loss you deplore, and, above all, to accept the divine teaching, and not let your distress go beyond the bounds of your faith.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 69:7
verses.text: For your most excellent husband, as the Lord Himself said, "is not dead but sleepeth"—a sleep a little longer than he was wont.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 69:8
verses.text: This hope has been given us by the Lord; this promise we have received from the divine oracles.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 69:9
verses.text: I know indeed how distressing is the separation, how most distressing; and especially so when affection is made stronger by sympathy of character and length of time.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 69:10
verses.text: But let your grief be for a journey into a far country, not for a life ended.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 69:11
verses.text: This kind of philosophy is particularly becoming to them that be brought up in piety, and it is of this philosophy that I beseech you, my respected friend, to seek the adornment.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 69:12
verses.text: And I do not offer you this advice as a man labouring himself under insensibility; in truth my heart was grieved when I learnt of the departure of one I loved so well.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 69:13
verses.text: But I call to mind the Ruler of the world and His unspeakable wisdom, which ordains everything for our good.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 69:14
verses.text: I implore your holiness to take these reflections to heart, to rise superior to your sorrow, and praise God who is the Master of us all.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 69:15
verses.text: It is with ineffable providence that He guides the lives of men.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 70:1
verses.text: LXX.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 70:2
verses.text: To Eustathius, Bishop of aegae.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 70:3
verses.text: The story of the noble Mary is one fit for a tragic play.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 70:4
verses.text: As she says herself, and as is attested by several others, she is a daughter of the right honourable Eudaemon.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 70:5
verses.text: In the catastrophe which has overtaken Libya she has fallen from her father's free estate, and has become a slave.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 70:6
verses.text: Some merchants bought her from the barbarians, and have sold her to some of our countrymen.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 70:7
verses.text: With her was sold a maiden who was once one of her own domestic servants; so at one and the same time the galling yoke of slavery fell on the servant and the mistress.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 70:8
verses.text: But the servant refused to ignore the difference between them, nor could she forget the old superiority: in their calamity she preserved her kindly feeling, and, after waiting upon their common masters, waited upon her who was reckoned her fellow slave, washed her feet, made her bed, and was mindful of other like offices.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 70:9
verses.text: This became known to the purchasers.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 70:10
verses.text: Then through all the town was noised abroad the free estate of the mistress and the servant's goodness.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 70:11
verses.text: On these circumstances becoming known to the faithful soldiers who are quartered in our city (I was absent at the time) they paid the purchasers their price, and rescued the woman from slavery.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 70:12
verses.text: After my return, on being informed of the deplorable circumstances, and the admirable intention of the soldiers, I invoked blessings on their heads, committed the noble damsel to the care of one of the respectable deacons, and ordered a sufficient provision to be made for her.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 70:13
verses.text: Ten months had gone by when she heard that her father was still alive, and holding high office in the West, and she very naturally expressed a desire to return to him.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 70:14
verses.text: It was reported that many messengers from the West are on the way to the fair which is now being held in your parts.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 70:15
verses.text: She requested to be allowed to set out with a letter from me.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 70:16
verses.text: Under these circumstances I have written this letter, begging your piety to take care of a noble girl, and charge some respectable person to communicate with mariners, pilots, and merchants, and commit her to the care of trusty men who may be able to restore her to her father.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 70:17
verses.text: There is no doubt that those who, when all hope of recovery has been lost, bring the daughter to the father, will be abundantly rewarded.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 71:1
verses.text: LXXI.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 71:2
verses.text: To Zeno, General and Consul.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 71:3
verses.text: Your fortitude rouses universal admiration, tempered as it is by gentleness and meekness, and exhibited to your household in kindliness, to your foes in boldness.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 71:4
verses.text: These qualities indicate an admirable general.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 71:5
verses.text: In a soldier's character the main ornament is bravery, but in a commander prudence takes precedence of bravery; after these come self-control and fairness, whereby a wealth of virtue is gathered.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 71:6
verses.text: Such wealth is the reward of the soul which reaches after good, and with its eyes fixed on the sweetness of the fruit, deems the toil right pleasant.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 71:7
verses.text: For to virtue's athletes the God of all, like some great giver of games, has offered prizes, some in this life, and some in that life beyond which has no end.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 71:8
verses.text: Those in this present life your excellency has already enjoyed, and you have achieved the highest honour.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 71:9
verses.text: Be it also the lot of your greatness to obtain too those abiding and perpetual blessings, and to receive not only the consul's robe, but also the garment that is indescribable and divine.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 71:10
verses.text: Of all them that understand the greatness of that gift this is the common petition.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 72:1
verses.text: LXXII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 72:2
verses.text: To Hermesigenes the Assessor.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 72:3
verses.text: At the time when men were whelmed in the darkness of ignorance, all did not keep the same feasts, but celebrated distinct ceremonies in different cities.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 72:4
verses.text: In aelis were the Olympian games, at Delphi the Pythian, at Sparta the Hyacinthian, at Athens the Panathenaic, the Thesmophoria, and the Dionysian.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 72:5
verses.text: These were the most remarkable, and further some men celebrated the revel feast of some daemons and some of others.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 72:6
verses.text: But now that those mists have been scattered by intellectual light, in every land and sea mainlanders and islanders together keep the feast of our God and Saviour, and whithersoever any one may wish to travel abroad, journey he either towards rising or towards setting sun, everywhere he will find the same celebration observed at the same time.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 72:7
verses.text: There is no longer necessity, in obedience to the law of Moses which was adapted to the infirmity of the Jews, to come together into one city and keep the feast in memory of our blessings, but every town, every village, the country and the farthest frontiers, are filled with the grace of God, and in every spot divine shrines and precincts are consecrated to the God of all.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 72:8
verses.text: So through every town we observe our several festivals and communicate with one another in the feast.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 72:9
verses.text: It is the same God and Lord who is honoured in our hymns and to whom our mystic sacrifices are offered.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 72:10
verses.text: On this account, as is well known, we neighbours address one another by letter and signify the joy that comes to us in the feast.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 72:11
verses.text: So now do I to you and offer the festal salutation to your excellency.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 72:12
verses.text: You will without doubt reply and honour the custom of the feast.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 73:1
verses.text: LXXIII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 73:2
verses.text: To Apollonius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 73:3
verses.text: Themistocles the son of Neocles, the far-famed and admirable general, is described by the admiring historian as endowed with natural virtue alone.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 73:4
verses.text: Of Pericles, however, the son of Xanthippus, it is said that he also derived ability from his education to charm his hearers by his persuasive eloquence, and was gifted with the power alike of knowing what measures should be taken and of enforcing them by word of mouth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 73:5
verses.text: In writing about him there is no impropriety in my using his own words.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 73:6
verses.text: These things illustrate your magnificence, for God, our Creator, hath given you natural capacity, and your education makes its brilliance the more conspicuous.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 73:7
verses.text: Nothing then is wanting to the full complement of your high qualities save only knowledge of their Author; be but this added, and the tale of virtues which we shall have will be complete.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 73:8
verses.text: Thus I write to you on receiving news of your arrival, beseeching the Giver of all good to grant a beam of light to your soul's eye, to show you the greatness of His boon, to kindle your love of that possession, and to grant the longed for favour to him that longs for it.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 74:1
verses.text: LXXIV.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 74:2
verses.text: To Urbanus.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 74:3
verses.text: It has been granted to us by our generous Lord once again to enjoy the feast and to send to your excellency the festal salutation.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 74:4
verses.text: We pray that you may be well and prosperous, and share the ineffable and divine boon which to them that approach supplies the seeds of the blessings hoped for, and gives the symbols of the life and kingdom that have no end.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 74:5
verses.text: These things we beseech the loving Lord to impart to you, for it is natural for friends to ask that their friends may be blessed.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 75:1
verses.text: LXXV.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 75:2
verses.text: To the Clergy of Beroea.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 75:3
verses.text: I perceive that it is with reason that I am well disposed to your reverences, for I have been assured by your kindly letter that my affection was returned.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 75:4
verses.text: For this affection of mine towards you I have many reasons.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 75:5
verses.text: First of all there is the fact that your father, that great and apostolic man, was my father too.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 75:6
verses.text: Secondly I look upon that truly religious bishop, who now rules your church, as I might on a brother both in blood and in sympathy.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 75:7
verses.text: Thirdly there is the near neighbourhood of our cities, and fourthly our frequent intercourse with one another, which naturally begets friendship and increases it when it is begotten.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 75:8
verses.text: If you like, I will name yet a fifth, and that is that we have the same close connexion with you as the tongue has with the ears, the former uttering speech, and the latter receiving it; for you most gladly listen to my words, and I am delighted to let fall my little drop upon you.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 75:9
verses.text: But the colophon of our union is our harmony in faith; our refusal to accept any spurious doctrines; our preservation of the ancient and apostolic teaching, which has been brought to you by hoary wisdom and nurtured by virtue's hardy toil.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 75:10
verses.text: I beseech you therefore to take greater care of the flock, to preserve it unharmed for the Shepherd, and boldly to utter the famous words of the patriarch "that which was born of beasts I offered not unto Thee".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 76:1
verses.text: LXXVI.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 76:2
verses.text: To Uranius, Governor of Cyprus.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 76:3
verses.text: True friendship is strengthened by intercourse, but separation cannot sunder it, for its bonds are strong.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 76:4
verses.text: This truth might easily be shewn by many other examples, but it is enough for us to verify what I say by our own case.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 76:5
verses.text: Between me and you are indeed many things, mountains, cities, and the sea, yet nothing has destroyed my recollection of your excellency.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 76:6
verses.text: No sooner do we behold any one arriving from those towns which lie on the coast, than the conversation is turned on Cyprus and on its right worthy governor, and we are delighted to have tidings of your high repute.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 76:7
verses.text: And lately we have been gratified to an unusual degree at learning the most delightful news of all: for what, most excellent sir, can be more pleasing to us than to see your noble soul illuminated by the light of knowledge? For we think it right that he who is adorned with many kinds of virtue should add to them also its colophon, and we believe that we shall behold what we desire.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 76:8
verses.text: For your nobility will doubtless eagerly seize the God-given boon, moved thereto by true friends who clearly understand its value, and guided to the bountiful God "Who wills all men to be saved and to come to the knowledge of the truth," netting men by men's means to salvation, and bringing them that He captures to the ageless life.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 76:9
verses.text: The fisherman indeed deprives his prey of life, but our Fisher frees all that He takes alive from death's painful bonds, and therefore "did he shew himself upon earth, and conversed with men," bringing men His life, conveying teaching by means of the visible manhood, and giving to reasonable beings the law of a suitable life and conversation.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 76:10
verses.text: This law He has confirmed by miracles, and by the death of the flesh has destroyed death.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 76:11
verses.text: By raising the flesh He has given the promise of resurrection to us all, after giving the resurrection of His own precious body as a worthy pledge of ours.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 76:12
verses.text: So loved He men even when they hated Him that the mystery of the oeconomy fails to obtain credence with some on account of the very bitterness of His sufferings, and it is enough to show the depths of His loving kindness that He is even yet day by day calling to men who do not believe.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 76:13
verses.text: And He does so not as though He were in need of the service of men,—for of what is the Creator of the universe in want?—but because He thirsts for the salvation of every man.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 76:14
verses.text: Grasp then, my excellent friend, His gift; sing praises to the Giver, and procure for us a very great and right goodly feast.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 77:1
verses.text: LXXVII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 77:2
verses.text: To Eulalius, Bishop of Persian Armenia.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 77:3
verses.text: I know that Satan has sought to sift you as wheat, and that the Lord has allowed him so to do that He may shew the wheat, and prove the gold, crown the athletes, and proclaim the victors' names.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 77:4
verses.text: Nevertheless I fear and tremble, not indeed distressed for the sake of you who are noble champions of the truth, but because I know that it comes to pass that some men are of feebler heart.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 77:5
verses.text: If among twelve apostles one was found a traitor, there is no doubt that among a number many times as great any one might easily discover many falling short of perfection.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 77:6
verses.text: Thus reflecting I have been confounded and filled with much discouragement, for, as says the divine Apostle, "whether one member suffer all the members suffer with it".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 77:7
verses.text: We are members one of another," and form one body, having the Lord Christ for head".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 77:8
verses.text: Yet one consolation I have in my anxiety, when I bethink me of your holiness.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 77:9
verses.text: For brought up as you have been in the divine oracles, and taught by the arch-shepherd what are the good shepherd's marks, there is no doubt that you will lay down your life for the sheep.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 77:10
verses.text: For, as the Lord says, "he that is an hireling" when he sees "the wolf coming," "fleeth because he is an hireling, and careth not for the sheep," but "the good shepherd giveth his life for the sheep".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 77:11
verses.text: Just so it is not in peace that the best general shews his inborn valour, but in time of war, by at once stimulating others and himself exposing himself to peril for his men.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 77:12
verses.text: For it would be preposterous that he should enjoy the dignity of his command, and, in the hour of need, run out of danger's way.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 77:13
verses.text: Thus the thrice blessed prophets ever acted, making light of the safety of their bodies, and, for the sake of the Jews who hated and rejected them, underwent all kinds of peril and toil.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 77:14
verses.text: Of them the divine apostle says "they were stoned, they were sawn asunder, were tempted, were slain by the sword; they wandered about in sheepskins and goatskins, being destitute, afflicted, tormented, of whom the world was not worthy; they wandered in deserts and mountains, and in dens and caves of the earth".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 77:15
verses.text: Thus the divine apostles travelled preaching over all the world, without home, bed, bedding, board, or any of the necessaries of life, but scourged, racked, imprisoned, and undergoing countless kinds of death.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 77:16
verses.text: And all this they underwent, not for the sake of their friends, but voluntarily facing these perils for the sake of the men who were persecuting them.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 77:17
verses.text: A far stronger claim is made on you now to accept the peril at present assailing you, for the sake of fellow-believers and brothers and children.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 77:18
verses.text: This affection is shown even by unreasoning animals, for sparrows may be seen fighting with all their force in behalf of their brood, and putting out in their defence all the strength they have; other kinds of birds moreover undergo danger for their young.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 77:19
verses.text: But why do I speak of birds? Bears too, and leopards, wolves, and lions, voluntarily suffer any pain for the safety of their offspring, for instead of fleeing from the hunter they will await his attack and do battle for their young.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 77:20
verses.text: I have adduced these instances not as though anointing your piety for endurance and courage by the example of brute beasts, but to console myself in my despondency, and to be assured that you will not leave Christ's flock without a shepherd when wolves make their attack, but will invoke the Lord of the flock to help you and will heartily do battle in its behalf.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 77:21
verses.text: A crisis like this proves who is a shepherd and who a hireling; who diligently feeds the flock and who on the other hand feeds on the milk and thinks little of the safety of the sheep.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 77:22
verses.text: "But God is faithful, who will not suffer you to be tempted above that ye are able; but will with the temptation also make a way to escape that ye may be able to bear it".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 77:23
verses.text: But one thing I do beseech your reverence, and that is to have greater heed of the unsound; and not only to strengthen the unstable but also to raise the fallen, for shepherds by no means neglect those of their flock who have fallen sick, but keep them apart from the rest, and try in every possible way to restore them, and so must we do.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 77:24
verses.text: We must make them that are slipping stand up, and give them a helping hand and a word of encouragement.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 77:25
verses.text: When they are bitten we must heal them; we must not give up the attempt to save them nor leave them in the devil's maw.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 77:26
verses.text: Thus ever acted the divine Apostle Paul; and when the Galatians, after receiving the baptism of salvation, and the gift of the divine Spirit, fell away into the sickness of Judaism, and received circumcision, he wailed and lamented more exceedingly than the most affectionate mother, and tended them and freed them from that infirmity.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 77:27
verses.text: We can hear him exclaiming, "My little children, of whom I travail in birth again until Christ be formed in you".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 77:28
verses.text: So too the teacher of the Corinthians, who had committed that abominable fornication, he both chastised as might a father, and very skilfully treated, and after cutting him off in the first Epistle, readmitted him in the second and says, "So that contrariwise ye ought rather to forgive him and comfort him lest perhaps such a one should be swallowed up with overmuch sorrow".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 77:29
verses.text: And again, "Lest Satan should get an advantage of us for we are not ignorant of his devices".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 77:30
verses.text: In the same manner too those who partook of things offered to idols he properly rebuked, suitably exhorted, and freed from their grievous error.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 77:31
verses.text: Wherefore our Lord Jesus Christ permitted the first of the apostles, whose confession He had fixed as a kind of groundwork and foundation of the Church, to waver to and fro, and to deny Him, and then raised Him up again.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 77:32
verses.text: And thus He gave us two lessons: not to be confident in our own strength, and to strengthen the unstable.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 77:33
verses.text: Reach out, therefore, I beseech you, a hand to them that are fallen, "draw them out of the horrible pit, out of the miry clay, and set their feet upon a rock," and "put a new song into their mouth, even praise unto our God," that their example of life may become an example of salvation, that "many shall see it and fear and shall trust in the Lord".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 77:34
verses.text: Let them be prevented from participating in the holy mysteries, but let them not be kept from the prayer of the catechumens, nor from hearing the divine Scriptures and the exhortation of teachers, and let them be prohibited from partaking of the sacred mysteries, not till death, but during a given time, till they recognise their ailment, covet health, and are properly contrite for having abandoned their true Prince and deserted to a tyrant, and for having left their benefactor and gone over to their foe.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 77:35
verses.text: The same lessons are given us by the precepts of the holy and blessed Fathers.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 77:36
verses.text: I write as I do, not to teach you piety, but to remind you as a brother might, knowing well that even the best of pilots in the moment of the storm needs monition even from his men.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 77:37
verses.text: So the great and famous Moses, renowned throughout the world, who did those mighty works of wonder, did not refuse the counsel of Jethro, a man still sunk in idolatrous error; for he did not regard his impiety, but acknowledged the soundness of his advice.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 77:38
verses.text: Moreover I implore your piety to offer earnest prayer to God in my behalf that for the remaining days of my life I may live in accordance with His laws.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 77:39
verses.text: Thus have I written by the most honourable and religious presbyter Stephanus, whom on account of the goodness of his character I have seen with great pleasure.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 78:1
verses.text: LXXVIII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 78:2
verses.text: To Eusebius, Bishop of Persian Armenia.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 78:3
verses.text: Whenever anything happens to the helmsman, either the officer in command at the bows, or the seaman of highest rank, takes his place, not because he becomes a self-appointed helmsman, but because he looks out for the safety of the ship.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 78:4
verses.text: So again in war, when the commander falls, the chief tribune assumes the command, not in the attempt to lay violent hands on the place of power, but because he cares for his men.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 78:5
verses.text: So too the thrice blessed Timothy when sent by the divine Paul took his place.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 78:6
verses.text: It is therefore becoming to your piety to accept the responsibilities of helmsman, of captain, of shepherd, gladly to run all risk for the sake of the sheep of Christ, and not to leave His creatures abandoned and alone.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 78:7
verses.text: It is rather yours to bind up the broken, to raise up the fallen, to turn the wanderer from his error, and keep the whole in health, and to follow the good shepherds who stand before the folds and wage war against the wolves.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 78:8
verses.text: Let us remember too the words of the patriarch Jacob; "In the day the drought consumed me and the frost by night and my sleep departed from my eyes.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 78:9
verses.text: The rams of thy flock I have not eaten.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 78:10
verses.text: That which was born of beasts I brought not unto thee.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 78:11
verses.text: I bare the loss of it.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 78:12
verses.text: Of my hand didst thou require it, whether stolen by day or stolen by night".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 78:13
verses.text: These are the marks of the shepherd; these are the laws of the tending of the sheep.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 78:14
verses.text: And if of brute cattle the illustrious patriarch had such care, and offered this defence to him who trusted them to his charge, what ought not we to do who are entrusted with the charge of reasonable sheep, and who have received this trust from the God of all, when we remember that the Lord for them gave up His life? Who does not fear and tremble when he hears the word of God spoken through Ezekiel? "I judge between shepherd and sheep because ye eat the fat and clothe yourselves with the wool and ye feed not the flocks".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 78:15
verses.text: And again, "I have made thee a watchman unto the house of Israel; when thou speakest not to warn the wicked from his wicked way, the same wicked man shall die in his iniquity but his blood shall I require at thine hand".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 78:16
verses.text: With this agree the words spoken in parables by the Lord.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 78:17
verses.text: "Thou wicked and slothful servant…Thou oughtest to have put my money to the exchangers, and then at my coming I should have received the same with usury".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 78:18
verses.text: Up then, I beseech you, let us fight for the Lord's sheep.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 78:19
verses.text: Their Lord is near.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 78:20
verses.text: He will certainly appear and scatter the wolves and glorify the shepherds.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 78:21
verses.text: "The Lord is good unto them that wait for Him, to the soul that seeketh Him".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 78:22
verses.text: Let us not murmur at the storm that has arisen for the Lord of all knoweth what is good for us.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 78:23
verses.text: Wherefore also when the Apostle asked for release from his trials He would not grant his supplication but said, "My grace is sufficient for thee, for my strength is made perfect in weakness".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 78:24
verses.text: Let us then bravely bear the evils that befall us; it is in war that heroes are discerned; in conflicts that athletes are crowned; in the surge of the sea that the art of the helmsman is shewn; in the fire that the gold is tried.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 78:25
verses.text: And let us not, I beseech you, heed only ourselves, let us rather have forethought for the rest, and that much more for the sick than for the whole, for it is an apostolic precept which exclaims "Comfort the feeble minded, support the weak".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 78:26
verses.text: Let us then stretch out our hands to them that lie low, let us tend their wounds and set them at their post to fight the devil.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 78:27
verses.text: Nothing will so vex him as to see them fighting and smiting again.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 78:28
verses.text: Our Lord is full of loving-kindness.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 78:29
verses.text: He receives the repentance of sinners.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 78:30
verses.text: Let us hear His own words: "As I live saith the Lord I have no pleasure in the death of the wicked, but that the wicked turn from his way and live".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 78:31
verses.text: So He prefaced His words with an oath, and He who forbids oaths to others swore Himself to convince us how He desires our repentance and salvation.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 78:32
verses.text: Of this teaching the divine books, both the old and the new, are full, and the precepts of the holy Fathers teach the same.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 78:33
verses.text: But not as though you were ignorant have I written to you; rather have I reminded you of what you know, like those who standing safe upon the shore succour them that are tossed by the storm, and shew them a rock, or give warning of a hidden shallow, or catch and haul in a rope that has been thrown.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 78:34
verses.text: "And the God of peace shall bring Satan under your feet shortly" and shall gladden our ears with news that you have passed from storm to calm, at His word to the waves "Peace be still".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 78:35
verses.text: And do you too offer prayers for us, for you who have undergone peril for His sake can speak with greater boldness.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 79:1
verses.text: LXXIX.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 79:2
verses.text: To Anatolius the Patrician.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 79:3
verses.text: The Lord God has given your excellency to us to be at the present time a source of very great comfort, and has afforded us a meet haven for the storm.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 79:4
verses.text: We have therefore confidence in informing your lordship of our distress.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 79:5
verses.text: Not long ago we acquainted your excellency that the right honourable Count Rufus had shewn us an order written in the imperial handwriting commanding the gallant general to provide with prudence and diligence for our residence at Cyrus, and not to suffer us to depart to another city, on the ground that we are endeavouring to summon synods to Antioch, and are disturbing the orthodox.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 79:6
verses.text: Now I make known to you that in obedience to the imperial letter I have come to Cyrus.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 79:7
verses.text: After an interval of six or seven days they sent the devoted Euphronius, the commander, with a letter begging me to acknowledge in writing that the imperial order had been shown me.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 79:8
verses.text: I therefore promised to remain in Cyrus and its adjacent district, and to tend the sheep entrusted to my care.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 79:9
verses.text: I therefore beseech your excellency to make exact enquiry, both whether these orders had really been issued, and for what reason.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 79:10
verses.text: I am indeed conscious of many other sins, but I do not know that I have erred either against the Church of God, or against public order.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 79:11
verses.text: And I write as I do, not because I take it ill to have to live at Cyrus, for in truth she is dearer to me than any of the most famous cities, because my office in her has been given me by God.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 79:12
verses.text: But the fact of my being bound to her not by preference but by compulsion does seem somewhat grievous, and besides it does give a handle to the wicked to grow bold and to refuse to obey our exhortations.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 79:13
verses.text: Under these circumstances I beseech your lordship, if no order of the kind has really been issued, to let me know; but if the letter really comes from the victorious emperor, tell his pious majesty not readily to believe calumnies, nor give ear to accusers alone, but to demand an account from the accused.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 79:14
verses.text: Though really the evidence of the facts alone was quite enough to persuade his piety that the charges against me were false.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 79:15
verses.text: For when did I ever make myself offensive about anything to his serene majesty or his chief officers? Or when was I ever obnoxious to the many and illustrious owners here? It is on the contrary well known to your excellency that I have spent a considerable portion of my ecclesiastical revenues in erecting porticoes and baths, building bridges, and making further provision for public objects.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 79:16
verses.text: But if any persons take it ill that I mourn over the ruin of the churches of Phoenicia, be it known to your lordship that it is impossible for me not to grieve when I see the horn of the Jews exalted on high and the Christians in tears and sorrow, though they send them to the very ends of the earth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 79:17
verses.text: We cannot fight against the apostolic decrees, for we remember the word of the Apostle which says, "We ought to obey God rather than men," and more terrible to us than any of the pains of this life is the "judgment seat of Christ" the Lord, before whom we shall all stand to render an account of our words and of our deeds.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 79:18
verses.text: On account of that judgment seat the hardships of this present life must be endured.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 79:19
verses.text: For them that suffer wrong the hope of what is to come is consolation enough, but to us the loving Lord has given further comfort in you, most excellent sir, whose life is bright with piety and faith.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 80:1
verses.text: LXXX.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 80:2
verses.text: To the Prefect Eutrechius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 80:3
verses.text: I have been much astonished that no information has been sent me by your lordship of the plots against me.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 80:4
verses.text: To counteract them would very likely have been a difficult matter to any one not having the means of convicting their promoters of lies; but to give information of what was going on needed not so much power as friendliness, and we had hoped that when your excellency had been summoned to the imperial city, and had been chosen to adorn the prefect's exalted seat, every tempest of the Church would be calmed down.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 80:5
verses.text: But we suffer from such disturbances as we did not see even in the beginning of the dispute.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 80:6
verses.text: The churches of Phoenicia are in trouble; in trouble are those of Palestine, as all unanimously report; and the distress is proved by the letters of the most pious bishops.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 80:7
verses.text: All the saints among us groan and every pious congregation is lamenting.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 80:8
verses.text: While looking for a cessation of our former troubles we have been afflicted with new ones.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 80:9
