verses.text: I myself have been forbidden to quit the coasts of Cyrus, if the dispatch is true which has been shewn me, and which is said to be an autograph of our victorious emperor.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 80:10
verses.text: It runs as follows "Since so and so the bishop of this city is continually assembling synods and this is a cause of trouble to the orthodox, take heed with proper diligence and wisdom that he resides at Cyrus, and does not depart from it to another city".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 80:11
verses.text: I have accepted the sentence, and remain still.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 80:12
verses.text: Your lordship can bear witness to my sentiments, for you know how on my arrival at Antioch I departed in a hurry, on account of those who wished to detain me there.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 80:13
verses.text: And those were unquestionably wrong who gave both their ears to my calumniators and would not keep one for me.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 80:14
verses.text: Even to murderers, and to them that despoil other men's beds, an opportunity is given of defending themselves, and they do not receive sentence till they have been convicted in their own presence, or have made confession of the truth of the charges on which they are indicted.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 80:15
verses.text: But a high priest who has held the office of bishop for five and twenty years after passing his previous life in a monastery, who has never troubled a tribunal, nor yet on any single occasion been prosecuted by any man, is treated as a mere plaything of calumny, without being allowed even the common privilege of grave-robbers of being questioned as to the truth of the accusations brought against them.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 80:16
verses.text: Yet they have done wrong; I have done no wrong.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 80:17
verses.text: But I am ready for even more serious troubles.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 80:18
verses.text: Though they be ever so much annoyed at my bewailing the calamities of Phoenicia I shall not cease so to do so long as I behold them.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 80:19
verses.text: The only judgment that is awful to me is the judgment of God.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 80:20
verses.text: For them, nevertheless, I pray that from the God of all they may obtain forgiveness; for your excellency, that you may ever live in honour, excel in all good things, speak boldly against lies, and fight on the side of the truth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 80:21
verses.text: And let the contrivers of this plot know that, though I depart to the uttermost ends of the earth, God will not suffer the confirmation of impious doctrines, but will nod His head and destroy them that bow down to doctrines of abomination.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 81:1
verses.text: LXXXI.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 81:2
verses.text: To the Consul Nomus.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 81:3
verses.text: For but a brief portion of a day I enjoyed the society of your lordship, for I was deprived by unavoidable circumstances of what I so earnestly desired.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 81:4
verses.text: I had hoped that our short interview would have kindled good will and friendly intercourse, but I was disappointed.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 81:5
verses.text: I have now written you two letters, without receiving any reply; and by the imperial decree I am forbidden to travel beyond the boundaries of Cyrus.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 81:6
verses.text: For this apparent punishment cause there is none, except the fact of my convening an episcopal synod.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 81:7
verses.text: No indictment was published; no prosecutor appeared; the defendant was not convicted; but the sentence was given.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 81:8
verses.text: We submit, for we know the reward of the wronged.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 81:9
verses.text: I am aware however that Festus the Procurator who was entrusted with the government of the Jews when they demanded the death of the divine Paul, publicly replied, "It is not lawful to us Romans to deliver any man before that he which is accused have the accusers face to face, and have license to answer for himself concerning the crime laid against him".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 81:10
verses.text: Now these words were spoken by one who was no believer in our Master, Christ, but was a slave to the errors of polytheism.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 81:11
verses.text: I was never asked whether I was assembling synods or not, or for what reason I was assembling them, or what umbrage this could give, either to the Church or to the government; yet just as though I had been a very guilty criminal I am prohibited from visiting other cities; while to every one else every city lies open, and that not only to Arians and Eunomians, but to Manichees and Marcionists, to them that are sick with the unsoundness of Valentinus and Montanus, aye to pagans and Jews, while I, a foremost champion of the teaching of the Gospels, am from every city excluded.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 81:12
verses.text: Some however maintain that I do not adhere to it.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 81:13
verses.text: Then let there be a council: let there be assembled there the godly bishops who are capable of judging: then let there be assembled those in office and in rank who have been instructed in divine lore.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 81:14
verses.text: Let me state what I hold, and let the judges declare what opinion is agreeable to the teaching of the Apostles.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 81:15
verses.text: I have not thus written from any desire to see the great city, nor from trying to travel to any other.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 81:16
verses.text: In fact I rather love the quiet of them whose wish is to administer the churches in a monastic state.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 81:17
verses.text: I should like your excellency to know that neither in the time of the blessed and sainted Theodotus, nor in that of John of blessed memory, nor in that of the very holy lord bishop Domnus, did I of my own accord enter Antioch; five or six times I was invited but I with difficulty assented, and when I did assent it was in obedience to the canon of the Church which orders him who is summoned to a synod and refuses to be present to be held guilty.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 81:18
verses.text: And when I appeared, what thing unpleasing to God did I do? Was it that I removed from the sacred lists the names of such and such a man guilty of unspeakable wickedness? Was it that I ordained to the priesthood men of character and of honourable life? Was it that I preached the gospel to the people? If these things are worthy of indictment and punishment, I gladly welcome yet severer punishments for their sake.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 81:19
verses.text: My accusers compel me to speak.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 81:20
verses.text: Even before my conception my parents promised to devote me to God; from my swaddling-band, they devoted me according to their promise and educated me accordingly; the time before my episcopate I spent in a monastery and then was unwillingly consecrated bishop.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 81:21
verses.text: Five and twenty years I so lived that I was never summoned to trial by any one nor ever brought accusation against any.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 81:22
verses.text: Not one of the pious clergy who were under me ever frequented a court.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 81:23
verses.text: In so many years I never took an obol nor a garment from any one.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 81:24
verses.text: Not one of my domestics ever received a loaf or an egg.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 81:25
verses.text: I could not endure the thought of possessing anything save the rags I wore.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 81:26
verses.text: From the revenues of my see I erected public porticoes; I built two large bridges; I looked after the public baths.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 81:27
verses.text: On finding that the city was not watered by the river running by it, I built the conduit, and supplied the dry town with water.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 81:28
verses.text: But not to mention these matters I led eight villages of Marcionists with their neighbourhood into the way of truth; another full of Eunomians and another of Arians I brought to the light of divine knowledge, and, by God's grace, not a tare of heresy was left among us.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 81:29
verses.text: All this I did not effect with impunity; many a time I shed my blood; many a time was I stoned by them and brought to the very gates of death.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 81:30
verses.text: But I am a fool in my boasting, yet my words are spoken of necessity, not of consent.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 81:31
verses.text: Once the thrice blessed Paul was compelled to act in the same way to stop the mouths of his accusers.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 81:32
verses.text: Yet I put up with seeming ignominy and count it high honour, for I hear the voice of the Apostle crying, "All that will live godly in Christ Jesus shall suffer persecution".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 81:33
verses.text: But I beseech your excellency to give heed to the affairs of the Church, and calm the storm that has arisen, for in fact not even at the beginning of the dispute was the Church beset by such confusion.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 81:34
verses.text: No one informs you of the greatness of the peril, of the lamentations of the Christians in Phoenicia and of the wails of our holiest monks.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 81:35
verses.text: Wherefore I have written to you at some length, that on learning the agitation of the Church your excellency might stay it, and reap the fruits of the benefit which such action will produce.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 82:1
verses.text: LXXXII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 82:2
verses.text: To Eusebius, Bishop of Ancyra.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 82:3
verses.text: I had hoped at this time to hear frequently from your holiness.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 82:4
verses.text: Suffering as I do under charges which are plain calumny I stand in need of brotherly consolation.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 82:5
verses.text: For they who are now renewing the heresy of Marcion, Valentinus, Manes, and of the other Docetae, annoyed at my publicly pillorying their heresy, have endeavoured to deceive the imperial ears, by calling me a heretic and falsely accusing me of dividing into two sons our one Lord Jesus Christ, the divine Word made man.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 82:6
verses.text: Their utterances did not meet with the success that they expected.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 82:7
verses.text: A despatch was therefore written to the right honourable and glorious commander and consul, containing indeed no accusation of heresy, but certain other charges no less unfounded.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 82:8
verses.text: They alleged that I was endeavouring to assemble frequent synods at Antioch; that certain persons thereupon took umbrage; that for this reason I ought to desist from these proceedings and manage the churches entrusted to my charge.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 82:9
verses.text: When this communication was shewn me I caught at the sentence as an opportunity of good.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 82:10
verses.text: For in the first place I gained the rest I so much longed for; furthermore I trust in the wiping out of the stains of the many errors I have committed, on account of the wrong devised against me by the enemies of truth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 82:11
verses.text: Even in this present life our supreme Ruler very plainly shews us what care He takes of them that suffer wrong.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 82:12
verses.text: While I have been remaining at rest, prisoned within the boundaries of my own country; while throughout the East all men have been distressed and have been bitterly lamenting though compelled to silence by the terror that has fallen on them (for what has befallen me has stricken terror into the hearts of all) the Lord has stooped from heaven, has convicted my calumniators of their falsehood, and laid bare their impious intent.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 82:13
verses.text: They armed even Alexandria against me and by means of their worthy instruments are dinning into all men's ears that I am preaching two sons instead of one.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 82:14
verses.text: I, on the contrary, am so far from holding this abominable opinion, that, on finding some of the holy fathers of the Nicene Council opposing in their treatises the madness of Arius and forced in their struggle against their opponents to make too marked a distinction, I have objected, and refused to admit such distinction, for I know how the exigencies of the distinction result in exaggeration.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 82:15
verses.text: And lest any one should suppose that I am speaking as I do through fear, let any one who likes get hold of my ancient writings written before the Council of Ephesus, and those written after it twelve years ago.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 82:16
verses.text: For by God's grace I interpreted all the Prophets and the Psalms and the Apostles: I wrote long ago against the Arians, the Macedonians, the sophistry of Apollinarius and the madness of Marcion: and in every one of my books by God's grace the mind of the Church shines clear.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 82:17
verses.text: Moreover I have written a book on the Mysteries, another on Providence, another on the Questions of the Magi, a life of the Saints, and besides these, not to name every one in detail, many more.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 82:18
verses.text: I have enumerated them not for ambition's sake, but to challenge my accusers and my judges to put any of my writings they may choose to the test.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 82:19
verses.text: They will find that by God's grace I hold no other opinion than just that which I have received from holy Scripture.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 82:20
verses.text: When, then, your holiness has heard this from me, I beg you to inform the ignorant and to persuade the unbridled tongues that revile me and all who are deceived by them, not to believe what they have heard of me from my calumniators.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 82:21
verses.text: Beg them to believe rather the Lawgiver when he exclaims "Men shall not receive a false report".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 82:22
verses.text: Ask them to wait till the facts are proved.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 82:23
verses.text: My prayer is that the churches may enjoy a calm and that this long and painful storm may vanish away.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 82:24
verses.text: But if the multitude of our sins suffer not this to come to pass; if for their sakes we are delivered to the sifter; we pray that we may share the perils undergone for the faith, in order that since we have not the confidence that comes from this life, at least for guarding the faith in its integrity we may meet with pity and pardon in the day of the appearance of the Lord.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 82:25
verses.text: And for this we beseech your holiness to join us in our prayers.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 83:1
verses.text: LXXXIII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 83:2
verses.text: Of Theodoretus, Bishop of Cyrus, to Dioscorus, Archbishop of Alexandria.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 83:3
verses.text: To them that suffer under false accusation the greatest comfort is given by the words of Scripture.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 83:4
verses.text: When such a sufferer is wounded by the lying words of an unbridled tongue, and feels the sharp stings of distress, he remembers the story of the admirable Joseph, and as he beholds that model of chastity, an exemplar of every kind of virtue, suffering, under a calumnious charge, imprisoned and fettered for invading another man's bed, and spending a long time in a dungeon, his pain is lightened by the remedy that the story furnishes.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 83:5
verses.text: So again when he finds the gentle David, hunted as a tyrant by Saul, and then catching his enemy and letting him go unharmed, an anodyne is given him in his distress.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 83:6
verses.text: But when he sees the Lord Christ Himself, Maker of the ages, Creator of all things, very God, and Son of the very God, called a gluttonous man and a wine bibber by the wicked Jews, it is not only consolation but rather great joy that is given him in that he is deemed worthy of sharing the sufferings of the Lord.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 83:7
verses.text: Thus I was compelled to write when I read the letters of your holiness to the most pious and sacred archbishop Domnus, for there was contained in them the statement that certain men have come to the illustrious city administered by your holiness, and have accused me of dividing the one Lord Jesus Christ into two sons, and this when preaching at Antioch, where innumerable hearers swell the congregation.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 83:8
verses.text: I wept for the men who had the hardihood to contrive the vain calumny against me.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 83:9
verses.text: But I grieved, and, my Lord, forgive me, forced as I am by pain to speak, that your pious excellency did not reserve one ear unbiassed for me instead of believing the lies of my accusers.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 83:10
verses.text: Yet they were but three or four or about a dozen while I have countless hearers to testify to the orthodoxy of my teaching.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 83:11
verses.text: Six years I continued teaching in the time of Theodotus bishop of Antioch, of blessed and sacred memory, who was famous alike for his distinguished career and for his knowledge of the divine doctrines.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 83:12
verses.text: Thirteen years I taught in the time of bishop John of sacred and blessed memory, who was so delighted at my discourses as to raise both his hands and again and again to start up: your holiness in your own letters has borne witness how, brought up as he was from boyhood with the divine oracles, the knowledge which he had of the divine doctrines was most exact.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 83:13
verses.text: Besides these this is the seventh year of the most pious lord archbishop Domnus.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 83:14
verses.text: Up to this present day, after the lapse of so long a time, not one of the pious bishops, not one of the devout clergy has ever at any time found any fault with my utterances.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 83:15
verses.text: And with how much gratification Christian people hear our discourses your godly excellency can easily learn, alike from those who have travelled thence hither, and from those who reached your city from us.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 83:16
verses.text: All this I say not for the sake of boasting, but because I am forced to defend myself.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 83:17
verses.text: It is not the fame of my sermons to which I am calling attention; it is their orthodoxy alone.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 83:18
verses.text: Even the great teacher of the world who is wont to style himself last of saints and first of sinners, that he might stop the mouths of liars was compelled to set forth a list of his own labours; and in shewing that this account of his sufferings was of necessity, not of free will, he added "I am become a fool in glorying; ye have compelled me".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 83:19
verses.text: I own myself wretched—aye thrice wretched.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 83:20
verses.text: I am guilty of many errors.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 83:21
verses.text: Through faith alone I look for finding some mercy in the day of the Lord's appearing.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 83:22
verses.text: I wish and I pray that I may follow the footprints of the holy Fathers, and I earnestly desire to keep undefiled the evangelic teaching which was in sum delivered to us by the holy Fathers assembled in council at the Bithynian Nicaea.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 83:23
verses.text: I believe that there is one God the Father and one Holy Ghost proceeding from the Father: so also that there is one Lord Jesus Christ, only begotten Son of God, begotten of the Father before all ages, brightness of His glory and express image of the Father's person, on account of man's salvation, incarnate and made man and born of Mary the Virgin in the flesh.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 83:24
verses.text: For so are we taught by the wise Paul "Whose are the Fathers and of whom as concerning the flesh Christ came, who is over all, God blessed for ever.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 83:25
verses.text: Amen," and again "Concerning His Son Jesus Christ our Lord which was made of the seed of David according to the flesh and declared to be the Son of God with power according to the spirit of holiness".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 83:26
verses.text: On this account we also call the holy Virgin "Theotokos," and deem those who object to this appellation to be alienated from true religion.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 83:27
verses.text: In the same manner we call those men corrupt and exclude them from the assembly of the Christians, who divide our one Lord Jesus Christ into two persons or two sons or two Lords, for we have heard the very divine Paul saying "One Lord, one faith, one baptism" and again "One Lord Jesus Christ by Whom are all things" and again "Jesus Christ the same yesterday and to-day and for ever" and in another place—"He that descended is the same also that ascended up far above all heavens".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 83:28
verses.text: And countless other passages of this kind may be found in the Apostle's writings, proclaiming the one Lord.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 83:29
verses.text: So too the divine Evangelist exclaims, "And the Word was made flesh and dwelt among us and we beheld His glory, the glory as of the only begotten of the Father, full of grace and truth".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 83:30
verses.text: And his namesake exclaimed, "After me cometh one who is preferred before me for He was before me".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 83:31
verses.text: And when he had shewn one person, he expressed both the divine and the human, for the words "man" and "comes" are human, but the phrase "He was before me" expresses the divine.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 83:32
verses.text: But nevertheless he did not recognise a distinction between Him who came after and Him who was before, but owned the same being to be eternal as God, but born man, after himself, of the Virgin.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 83:33
verses.text: Thus too, the thrice blessed Thomas, when he had put his hand on the flesh of the Lord, called Him Lord and God, saying "My Lord and my God".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 83:34
verses.text: For through the visible nature he discerned the invisible.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 83:35
verses.text: So do we know no difference between the same flesh and the Godhead but we own God the Word made man to be one Son.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 83:36
verses.text: These lessons we have learnt alike from the holy Scripture and from the holy Fathers who have expounded it, Alexander and Athanasius, loud voiced heralds of the truth, who have been ornaments of your apostolic see; from Basil and from Gregory and the rest of the lights of the world; and that, in our endeavour to shut the mouths of them that dare to oppose the blessed Theophilus and Cyril, we use their works, our own writings testify.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 83:37
verses.text: For we are most anxious by the medicines supplied by very holy men to heal them that deny the distinction between the Lord's flesh and the Godhead, and who maintain at one moment that the divine nature was changed into flesh, and at another that the flesh was transmuted into nature of Godhead.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 83:38
verses.text: For they clearly instruct us in the distinction between the two natures, and proclaim the immutability of the divine nature, calling the flesh of the Lord divine as being made flesh of God the Word; but the doctrine that it was transmuted into nature of Godhead they repudiate as impious.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 83:39
verses.text: I think that your excellency is well aware that Cyril of blessed memory often wrote to me, and when he sent his books against Julian to Antioch, and in like manner his book on the scapegoat, he asked the blessed John, bishop of Antioch, to shew them to the great teachers of the East; and in compliance with this request the blessed John sent us the books.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 83:40
verses.text: I read them with admiration, and I wrote to Cyril of blessed memory; and he wrote back to me praising my exactitude and kindness.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 83:41
verses.text: This letter I have preserved.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 83:42
verses.text: That I twice subscribed the writings of John of blessed memory concerning Nestorius my own hand bears witness, but this is the kind of thing whispered about me by men who try to conceal their own unsoundness by calumniating me.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 83:43
verses.text: Therefore I implore your holiness to turn your back on the liars; to give heed to the Church's quiet and either to heal by salutary medicines them that are trying to destroy the doctrines of the truth, or, if they refuse to accept your treatment, to expel them from the fold, to the end that the sheep may be spared from contagion.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 83:44
verses.text: I beg you to give me your customary salutation.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 83:45
verses.text: That I have written you my true sentiments is proved by my works on the holy Scriptures and against the Arians and Eunomians.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 83:46
verses.text: I will in addition write yet a brief word.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 83:47
verses.text: If any one refuses to confess the holy Virgin to be "Theotokos," or calls our Lord Jesus Christ bare man, or divides into two sons Him who is one only begotten and first born of every creature, I pray that he may fall from hope in Christ, and let all the people say amen, amen.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 83:48
verses.text: Now that I have thus spoken, deign, my lord, to give me your sacred prayers, and to cheer me by a letter in reply telling me that your holiness has turned your back on my accusers.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 83:49
verses.text: I and my household salute all thy brotherhood in piety in Christ.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 84:1
verses.text: LXXXIV.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 84:2
verses.text: To the Bishops of Cilicia.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 84:3
verses.text: Your piety has heard of the calumnies directed against me.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 84:4
verses.text: The opponents of the truth allege that I divide our one Lord Jesus Christ, the only begotten Son of God, into two sons, and it is said by some that a ground for their calumny is derived from a handful of men among you who hold these opinions, and who divide God the Word made man into two sons.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 84:5
verses.text: They ought to listen to those words of the Apostle which openly declare "one Lord Jesus Christ by whom are all things," and again "one Lord, one faith, one baptism".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 84:6
verses.text: They ought to have followed the Master's teaching, for the Lord Himself says "And no man hath ascended up to heaven, but he that came down from heaven, even the Son of man which is in Heaven".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 84:7
verses.text: And again "If ye shall see the Son of Man ascend up where He was before".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 84:8
verses.text: And the tradition of holy baptism teaches us that there is one Son, just as there is one Father and one Holy Ghost.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 84:9
verses.text: I hope then that your piety will deign, if there really are any, though I cannot believe it, who disobey the apostolic doctrines to close their mouths, to rebuke them as the laws of the Church require, and teach them to follow the footsteps of the holy Fathers and preserve undefiled the faith laid down at Nicaea in Bithynia by the holy and blessed Fathers, as summing up the teaching of Evangelists and Apostles.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 84:10
verses.text: For it becomes you who love God to give heed both to God's glory and our common credit, and not to overlook the attacks which are made upon us all through the ignorance or contentiousness of these few men—if they really are guilty, and if they are not, like ourselves, suffering from the whetted tongues of false accusers.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 84:11
verses.text: Deign to remember us in your prayers to God, for so the law of love ordains.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 85:1
verses.text: LXXXV.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 85:2
verses.text: To the Bishop Basil.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 85:3
verses.text: The chief good is said by the divine Paul to be love, and by love he ordered the nurslings of the faith to be fed.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 85:4
verses.text: Of this love your piety possesses great wealth, and so has told me what was befitting and given me pleasant news.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 85:5
verses.text: For to them that fear the Lord what can be pleasanter than the health and harmony of the doctrines of the truth? Be well assured, most godly sir, that we were much delighted to hear the intelligence of our common friend; and in proportion to our previous distress at hearing that he described the nature of flesh and of Godhead as one, and openly attributed the passion of salvation to the impassible Godhead, so were all rejoiced to read the letters of your holiness, and to learn that he maintains in their integrity the properties of the natures and denies both the change of God the Word into flesh, and the mutation of the flesh into the nature of Godhead, maintaining on the contrary that in the one Son, our Lord Jesus Christ, God the Word made man, the properties of either nature abide unconfounded.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 85:6
verses.text: We praise the God of all for the harmony of divine faith.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 85:7
verses.text: We have however written to either Cilicia, although our intelligence is imperfect, as to whether there are really any opponents of the truth, and have charged the godly bishops to search and examine if there are any who divide the one Lord Jesus Christ into two sons, and either to bring them to their senses by admonition, or cut them off from the roll of the brethren.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 85:8
verses.text: For in fact we equally repudiate both those who dare to assert one nature of flesh and Godhead, and those who divide the one Lord Jesus Christ into two sons and strive to go beyond the definitions of the Apostles.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 85:9
verses.text: But let your holiness be well assured that we are disposed to peace.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 85:10
verses.text: For if the prophet says, "With them that hate peace I was peaceful," much more readily do we welcome the peace of God.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 85:11
verses.text: Some of those men who have been fed on lies have hurried to Alexandria and patched up calumnies against me, with the result that the godly bishop of that city, led away by their statements, although he had been fully informed by my letters, has sent a pious bishop to the imperial city.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 85:12
verses.text: I beg you therefore to shew your accustomed kindness to him, and to confront falsehood with the truth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 86:1
verses.text: LXXXVI.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 86:2
verses.text: To Flavianus, Bishop of Constantinople.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 86:3
verses.text: At the present time, most God-beloved lord, I have received many buffetings of billows, but I called upon the great Pilot, and have been able to stand firm against the storm; the attacks, however, now made upon me transcend every story in tragedy.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 86:4
verses.text: In relation to the attacks which are being plotted against the apostolic faith, I thought that I should find an ally and fellow-worker in the most godly bishop of Alexandria, the lord Dioscorus, and so sent him one of our pious presbyters, a man of remarkable prudence, with a synodical letter informing his piety that we abide in the agreement made in the time of Cyril of blessed memory, and accept the letter written by him as well as that written by the very blessed and sainted Athanasius to the blessed Epictetus, and, before these, the exposition of the faith laid down at Nicaea in Bithynia by the holy and blessed Fathers.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 86:5
verses.text: We exhorted him to induce those who are unwilling to abide by these documents at once to abide by them.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 86:6
verses.text: But one of the opposite party, who keep up these disturbances, by tricking some of those who are on the spot and contriving countless calumnies against myself has stirred an iniquitous agitation against me.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 86:7
verses.text: But the very godly bishop Dioscorus has written us a letter such as never ought to have been written by one who has learnt from the God of all not to listen to vain words.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 86:8
verses.text: He has believed the charges brought against me as though he had made personal enquiry into every one of them, and had arrived at the truth after questioning, and has thus condemned me.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 86:9
verses.text: I however have bravely borne the calumnious charge, and have written him back a courteous letter, representing to his piety that the whole charge is false, and that not one of the godly bishops of the East holds opinions contrary to the apostolic decrees.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 86:10
verses.text: Moreover the pious clergy whom he sent as messengers have been convinced by the actual evidence of the facts.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 86:11
verses.text: These however he has dismissed unheeded, and, lending his ears to my calumniators, has acted in a manner quite incredible, were it not that the whole church bears witness to it.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 86:12
verses.text: He put up with them that were crying Anathema against me; nay he stood up in his place and confirmed their words by adding his voice to theirs.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 86:13
verses.text: Besides all this he sent certain godly bishops to the imperial city, as we learnt, in the hope of increasing the agitation against me.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 86:14
verses.text: I in the first place have for champion Him who seeth all things, for it is on behalf of the divine decrees that I am wrestling—next after Him I invoke your holiness to fight in defence of the faith that is attacked, and do battle on behalf of the canons that are being trodden under foot.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 86:15
verses.text: When the blessed Fathers were assembled in that imperial city in harmony with them that had sat in council at Nicaea, they distinguished the dioceses, and assigned to each diocese the management of its own affairs, expressly enjoining that none should intrude from one diocese into another.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 86:16
verses.text: They ordered that the bishop of Alexandria should administer the government of Egypt alone, and every diocese its own affairs.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 86:17
verses.text: Dioscorus, however, refuses to abide by these decisions; he is turning the see of the blessed Mark upside down; and these things he does though he perfectly well knows that the Antiochene metropolis possesses the throne of the great Peter, who was teacher of the blessed Mark, and first and coryphaeus of the chorus of the apostles.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 86:18
verses.text: But I know the majesty of the see, and I know and take measure of myself.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 86:19
verses.text: I have learnt from the first the humility of the Apostles.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 86:20
verses.text: I beseech your holiness not to overlook the trampling underfoot of the holy canons, and to stand forward zealously as champion of the divine faith, for in that faith we have hope of our salvation and on its account are confident that we shall meet with mercy.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 86:21
verses.text: But that your holiness may not be ignorant of this, know, my lord, that he shewed his ill-will towards me from the time of my assenting, in obedience to the canons of the holy Fathers, to the synodical letters issued in your see in the time of Proclus of blessed memory; on this point he has chidden me once and again on the ground of my violating the rights of the church of Antioch and, as he says, of that of Alexandria.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 86:22
verses.text: Remembering this, and finding, as he thinks, an opportunity, he has exhibited his hostility.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 86:23
verses.text: But nothing is stronger than the truth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 86:24
verses.text: Truth is wont to conquer even with few words.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 86:25
verses.text: I beseech your holiness to remember me in your prayers to the Lord that I may have power to prevail against the waves that are beating me hither and thither.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 87:1
verses.text: LXXXVII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 87:2
verses.text: To Domnus, Bishop of Apamea.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 87:3
verses.text: The law of brotherly love demanded that I should receive many letters from your godliness at this time.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 87:4
verses.text: For the divine Apostle charges us to weep with them that weep and rejoice with them that do rejoice.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 87:5
verses.text: I have not received a single one, although just lately I was visited by some of the pious monks of your monastery with the pious presbyter Elias.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 87:6
verses.text: Nevertheless I have written, and I salute your holiness; and I make you acquainted with the fact that the consolation of the Master has stood me in stead of all other, for in truth not even had I as many mouths as I have hairs on my head, could I worthily praise Him for my being deemed worthy of suffering on account of my confession of Him, and for the apparent disgrace which I hold more august than any honour.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 87:7
verses.text: And if I be banished to the uttermost parts of the earth all the more will I praise Him as being counted worthy of greater blessings.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 87:8
verses.text: Nevertheless I hope your holiness will put up prayers for the quiet of the holy churches.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 87:9
verses.text: It is because of the storm that is assailing them that I wail and groan and lament.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 87:10
verses.text: That quiet, as I know, was driven away by the Osrhoene clergy, who poured out countless words against me, although I had no share in their condemnation, nor in the sentence passed upon them; on the contrary, as your holiness knows, I besought that the communion might be given to them at Easter.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 87:11
verses.text: But slanderers find no difficulty in saying what they like.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 87:12
verses.text: My consolation lies in the blessing of the Master who said, "Blessed are ye when men shall revile you and persecute you and shall say all manner of evil against you falsely for my sake; rejoice and be exceeding glad: for great is your reward in heaven: for so persecuted they the prophets which were before you".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 88:1
verses.text: LXXXVIII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 88:2
verses.text: To Taurus the Patrician.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 88:3
verses.text: Slanderers have forced me to go beyond the bounds of moderation, and compel me to write to you who have adorned the highest offices, and obtained the most distinguished honours.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 88:4
verses.text: I therefore implore you to pardon me, for I do not write in self sufficiency, but because I am thrust forward by necessity.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 88:5
verses.text: It is not because I expect to fall unjustly into trouble and distress, for this is the common fate of all who have sincerely served God, but because I desire to persuade your excellency that those who accuse my opinions are producing false charges against me.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 88:6
verses.text: From my mother's breast I have been nurtured on apostolic teaching, and the creed laid down at Nicaea by the holy and blessed Fathers I have both learnt and teach.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 88:7
verses.text: All who hold any other opinion I charge with impiety, and if any one persists in asserting that I teach the contrary, let him not bring a charge which I cannot defend, but convict me to my face.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 88:8
verses.text: For this is agreeable to the laws alike of God and of man, but to whom is it so becoming to champion the wronged as to you, O friend of Christ, to whom boldness of utterance is given by the splendour of your lineage, the greatness of your rank and your foremost place in the law?.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 89:1
verses.text: LXXXIX.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 89:2
verses.text: To Florentius the Patrician.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 89:3
verses.text: In sending a letter to your greatness I am daring what is beyond me, but the cause of my daring is not self-confidence, but the slanders of my calumniators.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 89:4
verses.text: I have thought it well worth while to instruct your righteous ears how openly the impugners of my opinions are calumniating me.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 89:5
verses.text: I have been guilty, I own, of many errors, but up to now I have ever kept the faith of the apostles undefiled, and on this account alone I have cherished the hope that I shall meet with mercy on the day of the Lord's appearing.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 89:6
verses.text: On behalf of this faith I continue to contend against every kind of heresy; this faith I am ever giving to the nurslings of piety; by means of this faith I have metamorphosed countless wolves into sheep, and have brought them to the Saviour who is the Arch-shepherd of us all.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 89:7
verses.text: So have I learnt not only from the apostles and prophets but also from the interpreters of their writings, Ignatius, Eustathius, Athanasius, Basil, Gregory, John, and the rest of the lights of the world; and before these from the holy Fathers in council at Nicaea, whose confession of the faith I preserve in its integrity, like an ancestral inheritance, styling corrupt and enemies of the truth all who dare to transgress its decrees.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 89:8
verses.text: I invoke your greatness, now that you have heard from me in these terms, to shut the mouths of my calumniators.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 89:9
verses.text: It is in my opinion wholly unreasonable to accept as true what is charged against men in their absence; rather is it lawful and right that those who wish to appear as prosecutors should accuse the defendants in their presence, and endeavour to convict them face to face.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 89:10
verses.text: Under these conditions the judges will without difficulty be able to arrive at the truth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 90:1
verses.text: XC.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 90:2
verses.text: To Lupicinus the Master.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 90:3
verses.text: I have passed through the contests of my prime.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 90:4
verses.text: I see before me the confines of old age, and have expected as an old man to have more honour given me.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 90:5
verses.text: But I am a mark for the shafts of slander, and am driven to meet by defence accusations levelled against me.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 90:6
verses.text: Under these circumstances, I beseech your excellency not to believe the lies of my accusers.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 90:7
verses.text: Had I been living a life of silence, there might have been room for the suspicion of unorthodoxy.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 90:8
verses.text: But I am continually discoursing in the churches, and therefore have, by God's grace, innumerable witnesses to the soundness of what I teach.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 90:9
verses.text: I follow the laws and rules of the apostles.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 90:10
verses.text: I test my teaching by applying to it, like a rule and measure, the faith laid down by the holy and blessed Fathers at Nicaea.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 90:11
verses.text: If any one maintain that I hold any contrary opinion, let him accuse me face to face; let him not slander me in my absence.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 90:12
verses.text: It is fair that even the defendant should have an opportunity of speech, and meet with his defence the charges brought against him, and that then and not till then should the judges lawfully pronounce their sentence.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 90:13
verses.text: This favour I beg through your excellency's assistance.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 90:14
verses.text: If any men wish to condemn me unheard, I accept with willingness even their unjust sentence.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 90:15
verses.text: For I wait for the judgment of the Master, where we need neither witnesses nor accusers.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 90:16
verses.text: Before Him, as says the divine Apostle, "all things are naked and opened".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 91:1
verses.text: XCI.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 91:2
verses.text: To the Prefect Eutrechius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 91:3
verses.text: I well know, and need no words to tell me, how your excellency regards me.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 91:4
verses.text: Actions speak more clearly than words, but I have been anxious for you to know the cause of the accusation that is brought against me.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 91:5
verses.text: For I am suffering under a most extraordinary charge, being at one and the same time attacked as unmarried, and as having been married twice.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 91:6
verses.text: If my present calumniators assert that I am falsifying the apostolic doctrine, why in the world, instead of accusing me in my absence, do they not attempt to convict me face to face? This fact alone is enough to give utter refutation to their lies, for it is because they know that I have innumerable witnesses to the apostolic character of my doctrines that they have urged an undefended indictment against me.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 91:7
verses.text: Lawful judges must on the contrary keep one ear unbiassed for the accused.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 91:8
verses.text: If they give both to the pleadings of the opponents, and deliver a sentence acceptable to them, I shall put up with the injustice as bringing me nearer to the kingdom of heaven, and shall await that impartial tribunal, where there is neither prosecutor, nor counsel, nor witness, nor distinction in rank, but judgment of deeds and words and righteous retribution.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 91:9
verses.text: "For," it is said, "we must all appear before the judgment seat of Christ that every one may receive the things done in his body according to that he hath done whether it be good or bad".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 92:1
verses.text: XCII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 92:2
verses.text: To Anatolius the Patrician.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 92:3
verses.text: The very holy lord archbishop Domnus has arranged for the most pious bishops to repair to the imperial city, with a view to the complete refutation of the false accusation made against us all.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 92:4
verses.text: At this time we stand in especial need of the aid of your magnificence, since the Lord of all has endowed you with the gifts of pure faith, of warm zeal in its behalf, of intelligence and capacity, and power withal to carry out your prudent counsels.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 92:5
verses.text: I beg you therefore to defend the cause of the wronged, to contend against lies, and champion the apostolic teaching now assailed.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 92:6
verses.text: Without doubt the master and guide of the churches will bless your endeavour, will scatter the lowering cloud, and bless the nurslings of the faith with clear sky.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 92:7
verses.text: Even should He permit the tempest to prevail, your greatness will reap your perfect reward, and we shall bow our heads before the storm, ready to live with cheerfulness wheresoever it may drive us, and waiting the judgment of God and his true and righteous sentence.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 93:1
verses.text: XCIII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 93:2
verses.text: To Senator the Patrician.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 93:3
verses.text: I cherish an indelible memory of your magnificence, and now by very religious and holy bishops I salute you.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 93:4
verses.text: The very holy lord bishop Domnus has arranged for them to journey to the imperial city in order to put an end to the false charges raised against me.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 93:5
verses.text: For certain men have contrived manifest calumnies against me, and have grievously disturbed the churches for whose sake the Lord Christ "endured the Cross despising the shame"; in whose behalf the band of the divine apostles and companies of victorious martyrs were delivered to many kinds of death.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 93:6
verses.text: On behalf of their peace I call on your magnificence to contend.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 93:7
verses.text: It had been easy for the God of all to have nodded His head and scattered the lowering clouds; but He bides His time, and thereby at once shews the endurance of them that are assailed, and gives us opportunities of doing good.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 94:1
verses.text: XCIV.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 94:2
verses.text: To ProtogenesThe Praefect.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 94:3
verses.text: The loving-kindness of the Lord has already given you an opportunity of carrying out your good intentions.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 94:4
verses.text: He has given you a greater opportunity now, that your excellency may the more easily champion the cause of the truth that is assailed, bring lies to nought, and give the churches the calm for which they so intensely long.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 94:5
verses.text: Your excellency has already learned from many other sources how great is the surge by which the churches in the East are overwhelmed, but you will acquire more accurate information concerning it from the very religious bishops who, on account of it, have undertaken their long journey in the winter, relying, next after the Grace of God, on the providence of your authority.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 94:6
verses.text: Disperse for us, then, O Christian man, the storm, change the moonless night into clear sunshine, and bridle the tongues set wagging against us.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 94:7
verses.text: We by God's grace are ever fighting for the apostolic decrees, and we preserve undefiled the faith laid down at Nicaea, and style impious all who dare to violate its dogmas.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 94:8
verses.text: In evidence of the truth of what I say may be cited my catechumens, those who are from time to time baptized by me, and the hearers of my discourses in the churches.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 94:9
verses.text: If they mean to accuse me in accordance with the law, they must convict me in my presence, not slander me in my absence.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 94:10
verses.text: In this manner your excellency, when giving judgment in other cases, is wont to deliver your sentences, perceiving on which side lies the right from the pleadings both of the prosecution and of the defence.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 95:1
verses.text: XCV.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 95:2
verses.text: To the Praefect Antiochus.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 95:3
verses.text: You have laid aside the cares of your very important government, but your fame flourishes among all; for they that have reaped the fruit of your benevolence, and they are many and everywhere, persistently extol it, proclaiming your good report in all directions, and stirring their hearers' tongues to join in the chorus of acclamation.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 95:4
verses.text: When I behold the worthy fruit which adorns with its beauty its far-famed stem, I am delighted.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 95:5
verses.text: For this reason I call your excellency to greater and higher deeds, and beseech you to give heed to the tranquillity of the churches.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 95:6
verses.text: They have been overwhelmed with a great storm by the contrivers of calumnies against me, and under these circumstances the very religious bishops, making light of a long journey, of infirmity, and of old age, have left their own flocks unshepherded, and undertaken to travel this great distance, in their eagerness to confute the lies told against us all.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 95:7
verses.text: I beseech your greatness to give them your protection, to shew care for the calumniated East, and your forethought for the welfare of the apostolic faith.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 95:8
verses.text: It is only fitting that you should add this further glory to the rest of your good deeds.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 96:1
verses.text: XCVI.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 96:2
verses.text: To Nomus the Patrician.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 96:3
verses.text: I have written to you two letters, indeed I think three, but without getting any answer.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 96:4
verses.text: I had wished to say no more, but to know my own place and the greatness of dignities, and to beg you to inform me of the cause of your silence.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 96:5
verses.text: Really I do not know what offence I can have given to your excellency.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 96:6
verses.text: We err unwillingly as well as willingly, and sometimes are quite ignorant in what way we are transgressing.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 96:7
verses.text: I therefore beg your greatness, remembering the divine laws which plainly charge us "If thy brother shall trespass against thee go and tell him his fault between him and thee alone" to deign to make plain to me the origin of the annoyance, that I may either prove myself innocent, or, made aware of where I was wrong, may beg your pardon.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 96:8
verses.text: In my confidence in the evidence of my conscience I hope for the former.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 96:9
verses.text: All men are adorned by magnanimity, and not least those who, following the example of your excellency, trained in outside education as well as instructed in divine principles, both hear the apostolic laws loudly exclaiming "Let not the sun go down upon your wrath" and remember the words of Homer  "In fit bounds contain thy mighty mind;  Benignity is best".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 96:10
verses.text: I have thus written not as though giving you information, but to remind one who is much occupied, and I do so in remembrance of the law of the Lord, who says "Therefore if thou bring thy gift to the altar, and there rememberest that thy brother hath ought against thee; leave there thy gift before the altar, and go thy way; first be reconciled to thy brother and then come and offer thy gift".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 96:11
verses.text: In obedience to these words I have thought it right to salute your excellency by the most pious bishops, and to exhort you to give heed to the tranquillity of the churches.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 96:12
verses.text: They are indeed overwhelmed by a great storm.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 97:1
verses.text: XCVII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 97:2
verses.text: To the Count Sporacius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 97:3
verses.text: I am delighted with your excellency's letter.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 97:4
verses.text: My pleasure has been increased by the very religious presbyter and monk Iamblichus, who has told me of your warm zeal, your earnestness in religion, and your real goodwill to me.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 97:5
verses.text: On hearing of this as well as of the efforts of the glorious and pious lord Patricius on my behalf I give you the apostolic blessing which the blessed Onesiphorus obtained from that holy tongue; "The Lord give mercy to your house, for he oft refreshed.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 97:6
verses.text: me and was not ashamed of my chain;" "The Lord grant unto him that he may find mercy of the Lord in that day".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 97:7
verses.text: This I pray for you, even though the enemies of the truth inflict on me yet greater miseries as they suppose; for we have been taught to regard men's purpose; but be sure of this, that with true religion death to me is very pleasant, and exile to the ends of the earth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 97:8
verses.text: Still we are distressed at the storm of the churches, which the Lord of all is mighty to disperse.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 98:1
verses.text: XCVIII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 98:2
verses.text: To Pancharius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 98:3
verses.text: We are distressed to see the tempest of the churches, but their Master and Ruler ever through mighty billows shows to men His own wisdom and power.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 98:4
verses.text: He rebukes the winds and brings about a calm as He did when He was in the apostles boat.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 98:5
verses.text: So though I am distressed, nevertheless because I know this power of our Saviour and am aware of what He arranges for us, even though adversity befall me, I give thanks and accept it as a gift of God.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 98:6
verses.text: I have learned the lesson to care little for the present, and to wait for the expected blessings.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 98:7
verses.text: But it behoves your excellency zealously to defend the apostolic faith, that you may receive from the God of all the recompense of such conduct.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 99:1
verses.text: XCIX.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 99:2
verses.text: To Claudianus the Antigrapharius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 99:3
verses.text: Although you have not yet met me, I think that your excellency is aware of the open calumnies that have been published against me, for you have often heard me preaching in church, when I have proclaimed the Lord Jesus, and have pointed out the properties alike of the Godhead and of the manhood; for we do not divide one Son into two, but, worshipping the Only-begotten, point out the distinction between flesh and Godhead.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 99:4
verses.text: This, indeed, is I think confessed even by the Arians, who do not call the flesh Godhead, nor address the Godhead as flesh.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 99:5
verses.text: Holy Scripture clearly teaches us both natures.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 99:6
verses.text: Nevertheless, though I have ever thus spoken, certain men are uttering lying words against me.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 99:7
verses.text: But I rely on my conscience and have as witness to my teaching Him who looks into the hearts.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 99:8
verses.text: So, as the prophet says, I regard the contrivances of calumny as "a spider's web".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 99:9
verses.text: I await the great judgment which needs no words, but makes manifest what in the meanwhile is unknown.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 99:10
verses.text: I send this by the very religious bishops, thinking it worth while to salute your excellency by them and to remind you of your promise.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 99:11
verses.text: For attacked as I am I do not cease to go a-hunting, for I know that even the sacred apostles in the midst of the assaults made upon them did not cease to ply the net of the spirit.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 100:1
verses.text: C.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 100:2
verses.text: To Alexandra.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 100:3
verses.text: I have recently received your excellency's letter.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 100:4
verses.text: For the zeal you have shewn on my behalf I thank you, and pray the God of all to guard the goods you have, to increase them with further boons, and to grant you the enjoyment of future and everlasting blessings.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 100:5
verses.text: I think that He hears the prayer even of them that are sentenced to relegation, and all the more when it is for the sake of His divine doctrine that they are undergoing apparent disgrace.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 100:6
verses.text: I am writing by the very religious bishops, and I beg that they may meet with your kindly care.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 100:7
verses.text: It is for the sake of the faith of the gospel and the peace of the churches that they have undertaken this long journey.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 101:1
verses.text: CI.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 101:2
verses.text: To the Deaconess Celarina.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 101:3
verses.text: The flames of the war against us have been lit up again.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 101:4
verses.text: After yielding awhile, the enemy of men has once more armed against us men nurtured in lies, who utter open slander against me, and say that I divide our one Lord Jesus Christ into two sons.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 101:5
verses.text: I however know the distinction between Godhead and manhood, and confess one Son, God the Word made man.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 101:6
verses.text: I assert that He is God eternal, who was made man at the end of days, not by the change of the Godhead, but by the assumption of the manhood.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 101:7
verses.text: It is however needless for me to inform your piety of my sentiments, for you have exact knowledge of what I preach, and how I instruct the ignorant.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 101:8
verses.text: I beseech you therefore since the workers of lies have poured their insults upon all the godly bishops of the East at once, and overwhelmed the churches with a storm, that your piety will show all possible zeal on behalf of the doctrines of the gospel and the peace of the churches.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 101:9
verses.text: On this account the very godly bishops have left the churches shepherded by them, have disregarded the inclemency of winter, and endured the labours of their long journey, that they may calm the tempest which has arisen.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 101:10
verses.text: I am sure that your godly excellency will regard them as champions of piety and governors of the churches.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 102:1
verses.text: CII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 102:2
verses.text: To Bishop Basilius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 102:3
verses.text: There is nothing remarkable in the reproaches that are directed against me being heard in silence by men who do not know me; but that your holiness should not refute the lies of my revilers, or at least should do so only to a certain extent, and with no great heartiness, passes the belief of any one who knows your character and conduct.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 102:4
verses.text: And I say this not because friendship ought to be preferred to truth, but because the witness of truth is on the side of friendship.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 102:5
verses.text: Your reverence has very often heard me preaching in church, and, in other assemblies where I have spoken on doctrinal questions; you have listened to what I have said, and I do not know of any occasion on which you have found fault with me for expressing unorthodox opinions.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 102:6
verses.text: But what is the case at the present moment? Why in the world, my dear friend, do you not utter a word against falsehood, while you allow a friend to be calumniated and the truth to be assailed? If this is because you disregard the helpless and insignificant, remember the plain proclamation of the commandment of the Lord "Take heed that ye despise not one of these little ones which believe in me, for I say unto you that in heaven their angels do always behold the face of my Father which is in heaven".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 102:7
verses.text: If however it is the influence of my calumniators which imposes silence upon you, you must listen to the other law which says "Thou shalt not honour the person of the mighty" and "Judge righteous judgment" and "Thou shalt not follow a multitude to do evil" and "He that shutteth his eyes from seeing evil and stoppeth his ears from hearing of blood".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 102:8
verses.text: You may find innumerable similar passages in holy Scripture, which I have thought it needless to collect when writing to a man brought up in the divine oracles, and watering Christian people with his teaching.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 102:9
verses.text: But this I will say, that we shall all stand before the judgment seat of Christ, and shall give account of our words and deeds.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 102:10
verses.text: I, who for every other reason dread this tribunal, now that I am encompassed with calumny, find my chief consolation in the thought of it.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 103:1
verses.text: CIII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 103:2
verses.text: To the Count Apollonius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 103:3
verses.text: The very godly bishops have been led to travel to the imperial city by the calumnies uttered against me, and I by their holinesses send your excellency my salutation, and pay the debt of friendship, not indeed to wipe out the cherished obligation, but to make it greater.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 103:4
verses.text: For in truth the obligations of friendship are increased by their discharge.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 103:5
verses.text: That I should now be reaping the fruits of calumny is not extraordinary, for, in that I am human, there is nothing that I must not expect.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 103:6
verses.text: All troubles of this kind must be borne by them that have learned wisdom; one thing only is distressing—that harm should accrue to the soul.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 104:1
verses.text: CIV.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 104:2
verses.text: To Flavianus,Bishop of Constantinople.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 104:3
verses.text: I have already in another letter informed your holiness how openly the calumniators of our teaching are slandering us.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 104:4
verses.text: Now in like manner by means of the very godly bishops I do the same, having not only these as witnesses of the orthodoxy of my teaching but also countless other men who are my hearers in the churches of the East.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 104:5
verses.text: Above and beyond all these I have my conscience, and Him who sees my conscience.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 104:6
verses.text: And I know too how the divine Apostle often appealed to the testimony of his conscience, for "our rejoicing is this, the testimony of our conscience" and again "I say the truth in Christ I lie not, my conscience also bearing me witness in the Holy Ghost".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 104:7
verses.text: Know then, O holy and godly sir, that no one has ever at any time heard us preaching two sons; in fact this doctrine seems to me abominable and impious, for there is one Lord Jesus Christ through whom are all things.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 104:8
verses.text: Him I acknowledge both as everlasting God and as man in the end of days, and I give Him one worship as only begotten.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 104:9
verses.text: I have learned however the distinction between flesh and Godhead, for the union is unconfounded.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 104:10
verses.text: Thus drawn up as it were in battle array to oppose the madness of Arius and Eunomius, we very easily refute the blasphemy hazarded by them against the only begotten, by applying what was spoken in humility about the Lord, and suitably to His assumed nature, to man, and, on the other hand, what becomes the divine and signifies the divine nature, to God; not dividing Him into two persons, but teaching that both the former and latter attributes belong to the only begotten, the latter to Him as God the Creator and Lord of all, and the former as made man on our account.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 104:11
verses.text: For divine Scripture says that He was made man, not by mutation of the Godhead, but by assumption of human nature, of the seed of Abraham.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 104:12
verses.text: This the divine Apostle openly says in the words "For verily He took not on Him the nature of angels, but He took on Him the seed of Abraham, wherefore in all things it behoved Him to be made like unto His brethren".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 104:13
verses.text: And again "Now to Abraham and his seed were the promises made: he saith not and to seeds, as of many; but as of one, and to thy seed, which is Christ".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 104:14
verses.text: These and similar passages have been cut out of divine Scripture by Simon, Basilides, Valentinus, Bardesanes, Marcion, and the man who is named after his maniacal heresy.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 104:15
verses.text: So they style the Master Christ God only, and describe Him as having nothing human about Him, but appearing in imagination and appearance as man to men.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 104:16
verses.text: On the other hand the Arians and Eunomians say that God the Word assumed only a body, and that He Himself supplied the place of a soul in the body.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 104:17
verses.text: And Apollinarius describes the Master's body as endued with a soul; but, deriving, I know not whence, the idea of a distinction between soul and intelligence, deprives intelligence of its share in the achieved salvation.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 104:18
verses.text: The teaching of the divine Apostles lays down on the contrary that a soul both reasonable and intelligent was assumed together with flesh, and the salvation of which the hope is held out to them that believe is complete.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 104:19
verses.text: There is yet another gang of heretics who hold differently.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 104:20
verses.text: Photinus, Marcellus, and Paul of Samosata, assert that our Lord and God was only man.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 104:21
verses.text: When arguing with these we are under the necessity of advancing proofs of the Godhead, and of shewing that the Master Christ is everlasting God.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 104:22
verses.text: When, on the other hand, we are contending with the former faction, which calls our Lord Jesus Christ God only, we are obliged to marshal against them the forces of the divine Scripture, and collect from it evidence of the assumption of the manhood.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 104:23
verses.text: For a physician must use remedies appropriate to the disease, and suit the medicine to the case.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 104:24
verses.text: Now, therefore, I beseech your holiness to scatter the slander raised against me, and bridle the tongues now vainly reviling me.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 104:25
verses.text: For, after the incarnation, I worship one Son of God, one Lord Jesus Christ, and denounce as impious all who hold otherwise.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 104:26
verses.text: Deign, sir, to give me too your holy prayers, that, by God's grace, I may reach the other side of the ocean of danger, and drop my anchor in the windless haven of the Lord.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 105:1
verses.text: CV.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 105:2
verses.text: To Eulogius the oeconomus.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 105:3
verses.text: We have heard from many sources of your piety's efforts on behalf of true religion.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 105:4
verses.text: It is therefore right that you should readily succour one who is calumniated for the same cause, and should refute the reviler's lies.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 105:5
verses.text: You, O godly Sir, know what I hold, and what I teach, and that no one has ever heard of my preaching two sons.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 105:6
verses.text: Exert, I implore you, in this case too your divine energy, and stop the mouths of the evil speakers.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 105:7
verses.text: In conflicts of this kind one must help not only one's friends but even those who have caused us pain.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 106:1
verses.text: CVI.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 106:2
verses.text: To Abraham the oeconomus.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 106:3
verses.text: By the godly bishops I salute you.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 106:4
verses.text: I beseech you to give heed to the churches' calm, and to disperse the waves of calumny.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 106:5
verses.text: "Whatsoever a man soweth that shall he also reap," as says the divine Apostle.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 106:6
verses.text: Without doubt then he who fights for the apostolic doctrines shall reap the fruit of the apostolic blessing and enjoy the Apostles' devotion.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 107:1
verses.text: CVII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 107:2
verses.text: To the Presbyter Theodotus.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 107:3
verses.text: The struggles which your piety has undergone on behalf of the apostolic doctrines are not unknown, but are frequently mentioned alike by those who have known them by experience, and by others who have heard of them from these.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 107:4
verses.text: Continue, my dear sir, your efforts, and fight for the doctrines of the Fathers.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 107:5
verses.text: For these I too am buffeted in all directions and, while I receive the shock of the great waves, I beseech our Governor either to nod his head and scatter the tempest, or enable the victims of the storm by His grace to play the man.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 108:1
verses.text: CVIII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 108:2
verses.text: To Acacius the Presbyter.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 108:3
verses.text: True indeed is the promise of David's Psalm, for through him the Spirit of truth gave this promise to them that believe, "Commit thy way unto the Lord, trust also to him; and he shall bring it to pass; and he shall bring forth thy righteousness as the light and thy judgment as the noonday".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 108:4
verses.text: This we find too has come to pass in the case of your piety.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 108:5
verses.text: For the great care you bestow upon them that are weeping for their orphanhood, and your struggles on behalf of the apostolic doctrines, are in every one's mouth, and so, as the prophets say, "Hidden things are made manifest".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 108:6
verses.text: Since I too have heard of your piety's admirable exertions I write to salute you, most godly sir, and beseech you to increase your glory by adding to your labours, and to fight on behalf of the doctrine of the Gospels, that we may both keep the inheritance of our fathers unimpaired, and bring our Master His talent with good usury.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 109:1
verses.text: CIX.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 109:2
verses.text: To Eusebius, Bishop of Ancyra.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 109:3
verses.text: Many are the devices secretly plotted against me, and through me patched up against the faith of apostles.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 109:4
verses.text: I am however comforted by the sufferings of the Saints, Prophets, Apostles, Martyrs, and men famous in the churches in the word of Grace; and besides these by the promises of our God and Saviour, for in this present life He has promised us nothing pleasant or delightful, but rather trouble, toil, and peril, and attacks of enemies.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 109:5
verses.text: "In the world," He says, "ye shall have tribulation," and "if they have persecuted me they will also persecute you," and "If they have called the master of the house Beelzebub how much more shall they call them of his household," and "The time cometh when whosoever killeth you will think he doeth God service," and "Straight is the gate and narrow the way which leadeth unto life," and "When they persecute you in this city flee you into another," and I might quote all similar passages.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 109:6
verses.text: The divine Apostle too speaks in the same strain.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 109:7
verses.text: "Yea and all that will live godly in Christ Jesus shall suffer persecution, but evil men and seducers shall wax worse and worse, deceiving and being deceived".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 109:8
verses.text: These words give me the greatest comfort in this distress.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 109:9
verses.text: As the calumnies uttered against me have probably reached your holiness's ears, I beseech your holiness to give no credence to the lies of my slanderers.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 109:10
verses.text: I am not aware of ever having taught anyone up to the present time to believe in two sons.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 109:11
verses.text: I have been taught to believe in one only begotten, our Lord Jesus Christ, God the Word made man.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 109:12
