verses.text: But I know the distinction between flesh and Godhead, and regard as impious all who divide our one Lord Jesus Christ into two sons, as well as those who, travelling in an opposite direction, call the Godhead and manhood of the master Christ one nature.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 109:13
verses.text: For these exaggerations stand opposed to one another, while between them lies the way of the doctrines of the Gospel, beautified by the footprints of prophets and apostles, and of all who after them have been conspicuous for the gift of teaching.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 109:14
verses.text: I was anxious to adduce their opinions, and to point out how they bear witness in favour of my own, but I want more words than a letter allows room for, wherefore I have written summarily what I have been taught about the incarnation of the only begotten; I send my statement to your godly excellency.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 109:15
verses.text: I have written not with the object of teaching others, but of making my defence against the accusations brought against me, and of explaining my sentiments to those who are ignorant of them.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 109:16
verses.text: After your holiness has read what I have written, if you find it in conformity with the apostolic doctrines, I hope you will confirm my opinion by what you reply—if, on the contrary, anything that I have said jars with the divine teaching, I request to be told of it by your holiness.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 109:17
verses.text: For, though I have spent much time in teaching, I still need one to teach me.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 109:18
verses.text: "We know," says the divine Apostle "in part," and again he says, "If any man think that he knoweth anything he knoweth nothing yet as he ought to know".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 109:19
verses.text: So I hope that I may hear the truth from your holiness, and that you may also give heed to the calm of the Church, and fight for the divine doctrines.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 109:20
verses.text: It is for their sakes that the very godly bishops, making light of the difficulties of the journey, and of the winter, have set out for the imperial city, in the endeavour to bring about some end to the storm.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 109:21
verses.text: Send them I pray you, on their way with your prayers and with your prayers too strengthen me.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 110:1
verses.text: CX.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 110:2
verses.text: To Domnus, Bishop of Antioch.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 110:3
verses.text: When I read your letter I remembered the very blessed Susannah, who when she saw the famous villains, and believed that the God of all was present, uttered that remarkable cry, "I am straitened on every side;" but nevertheless preferred to fall into the snares of slander rather than to despise the just God.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 110:4
verses.text: And I, sir, have two alternatives as I have often said, to offend God and wound my conscience, or to fall by man's unjust sentence.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 110:5
verses.text: The most pious emperor, I think, knows nothing of this.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 110:6
verses.text: For what hindered him from writing, and ordering the ordination to take place, if in truth it so pleased him? Why in the world do they utter threats without and cause alarm, and yet do not send letters openly ordering it? One of two things must be true; either the very pious emperor is not induced to write, or they are trying to make us break the law and afterwards be indicted by them for illegality.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 110:7
verses.text: I have before me the example of the blessed Principius, for in that case, when they had given orders by writing, they punished him for obedience.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 110:8
verses.text: Moreover the letters which I read on the very day of the letter-bearer's arrival are of a contrary tenour.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 110:9
verses.text: For one of the holy monks has written to some one that he has received letters both from the very illustrious guardsman and the very glorious ex-magister stating that the case of the very godly lord bishop Irenaeus will stand more favourably, and in return for this good will they ask prayers on their behalf.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 110:10
verses.text: I think therefore that a reply ought to be written to the clergy who have written from the imperial city to the effect that "in obedience to the sentence of the very godly bishops of Phoenicia, and knowing both the zeal and the magnanimity and love for the poor and all the other virtues of the very godly bishop Irenaeus, and in addition to this the orthodoxy of his opinions, I have ordained him.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 110:11
verses.text: I am not aware that he has ever objected to apply to the holy Virgin the title 'Theotokos,' or has ever held any other opinions contrary to the doctrines of the Gospel.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 110:12
verses.text: As to the question of digamy, I have followed my predecessors; for Alexander of blessed and sacred memory, the ornament of this apostolic see, as well as the very blessed Acacius, bishop of Beroea, ordained Diogenes of blessed memory who was a 'digamus;' and similarly the blessed Praylius ordained Domninus of Caesarea who was a 'digamus.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 110:13
verses.text: ' We have therefore followed precedent, and the example of men well known and illustrious both for learning and character.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 110:14
verses.text: Proclus, bishop of Constantinople, of blessed memory well aware of this and many other instances, both himself accepted the ordination, and wrote in praise and admiration of it.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 110:15
verses.text: So too did the leading godly bishops of the Pontic Diocese, and all the Palestinians.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 110:16
verses.text: "No doubt has been raised about the matter, and we hold it wrong to condemn a man illustrious for many and various noble actions".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 110:17
verses.text: In my opinion it is becoming to write in these terms.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 110:18
verses.text: If your holiness holds any other view, let what seems good to you be done.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 110:19
verses.text: I, as they suppose, have undergone one punishment, and am ready by God's help to undergo yet another.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 110:20
verses.text: Even a third and fourth, if they like, by the stay of God's grace I will endure, praising the Lord.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 110:21
verses.text: If your holiness thinks right, let us see what answer comes from Palestine, and, after considering more exactly what course is to be taken, let us so write to Constantinople.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 111:1
verses.text: CXI.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 111:2
verses.text: To Anatolius the Patrician.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 111:3
verses.text: Your excellency will be recompensed for the kindness you have shewn me by the God of all, for all that is done for His sake has its reward.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 111:4
verses.text: I laugh at all my slanderers.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 111:5
verses.text: The bodies of them who are most severely scourged do not feel the pain, because the scourged flesh is deadened.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 111:6
verses.text: Still I lament over them whose unrestrained mouths utter such lies.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 111:7
verses.text: In what way have the accusers of the godly bishop Ibas been wronged by me that they should utter such calumnies against me? To begin with, I was not even one of the judges, for in obedience to the imperial decree I was living at Cyrus.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 111:8
verses.text: Moreover, as I have heard from many, they all along treated my absence as a grievance, for I had arranged for their partaking of the Holy Communion at the Easter feast of salvation, and as they often expressed a wish to meet me, I received them with kindness and advised them as to the proper course to take.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 111:9
verses.text: But that I may also speak in the defence of the very godly bishop the lord Domnus, what was the proper course for him to take? He was openly attacked; he saw men deposed by a synodical sentence sent into another diocese, and resuming their priestly functions in violation of the laws of the Church; he saw things holy and divine laughed at and turned into ridicule by the enemies of the Church; what was he to do? When he knew this he handed over the case to others, and not only to the very godly lord Ibas, but also to the holy lord bishop Symeon of Amida, that the metropolitans of the two provinces might hear the charges.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 111:10
verses.text: What fairness is there in charging the same persons with cruelty and kindness? If we excommunicate, we run into danger; if we do not excommunicate, we do not escape it.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 111:11
verses.text: We alone of all the world are objects of attack.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 111:12
verses.text: Other dioceses are at peace.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 111:13
verses.text: We alone are exposed to calumniators,—specially I myself, though I took no part in the trial, and am absolutely without responsibility in the matter.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 111:14
verses.text: Thus have I been forced to write on reading your lordship's letter, and on learning from it how for these reasons a great commotion has been made against me, a man confined to my diocese; a man of peace; one not even deliberating with the godly bishops of the province.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 111:15
verses.text: As a matter of fact, although there have been already two episcopal ordinations in our province, I took part in neither.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 111:16
verses.text: Were I not restrained by the imperial decree I would have gone away, and spent the remainder of my days in some remote spot.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 111:17
verses.text: I am faint for the plots hatched against me.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 111:18
verses.text: I am sure those Edessenes never put together their slander against me of their own accord.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 111:19
verses.text: They were prompted to these attacks on me by their truly truthful neighbours.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 111:20
verses.text: I thank our Saviour that he has deemed me worthy of the beatitudes of the Gospel, all unworthy though I be.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 111:21
verses.text: For this reason I have gladly accepted the sentence of relegation.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 111:22
verses.text: I am ready for exile, and, for the sake of the "hope laid up for me," welcome whatever fate they may inflict.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 111:23
verses.text: I pray without ceasing for your excellency, and beseech all the saints to share in my petitions.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 112:1
verses.text: CXII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 112:2
verses.text: To Domnus, Bishop of Antioch.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 112:3
verses.text: When news was brought to me that the pettiness of the victorious emperor had been put an end to, a reconciliation effected between him and the very godly bishop, the summons to the council cancelled, and the peace of the churches restored, I hoped that our troubles were a thing of the past.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 112:4
verses.text: But I am deeply distressed at what I hear from your holiness.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 112:5
verses.text: It is impossible to hope for any good from this notorious council, unless the merciful Master with His wonted providence shall undo the riotous demons' devices.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 112:6
verses.text: Even in the great synod, I mean that of Nicaea, the Arian party voted with the orthodox and set their hands to the apostolic exposition.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 112:7
verses.text: But they did not cease to war against the truth till they had torn asunder the body of the Church.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 112:8
verses.text: For thirty years the supporters of the apostolic doctrines and they who were infected with the Arian blasphemy continued in communion with one another.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 112:9
verses.text: But at Antioch, when the latest council was finished, when they had seated the man of God, the great Meletius, on the apostolic throne, and then after a few days ejected him by the imperial authority, Euzoius who was affected with the undoubted plague of Arius was put forward, and straightway the champions of apostolic doctrines seceded and thereafter the division continued.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 112:10
verses.text: As I look back on what happened then, and look forward to similar events in the future, my wretched spirit sighs and wails, for I see no prospect of good.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 112:11
verses.text: The men of the other dioceses do not know the poison which lies in the Twelve Chapters; having regard to the celebrity of the writer of them, they suspect no mischief, and his successor in the see is I think adopting every means to confirm them in a second synod.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 112:12
verses.text: For supposing he who lately wrote them at command, and anathematized all who did not wish to abide by them, were presiding over an oecumenical council, what could he not effect? And be well assured, my lord, that no one who knows the heresy they contain will brook to accept them, though twice as many men of this sort decree them.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 112:13
verses.text: Before now, though a larger number have rashly confirmed them, I resisted at Ephesus, and refused to communicate with the writer of them till he had agreed to the points laid down by me, and had harmonized his teaching with them, without making any mention of the Chapters.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 112:14
verses.text: This your holiness can ascertain without any difficulty if you order the acts of the synod to be investigated; for they are preserved as is customary with the synodical signatures, and there are extant more than fifty synodic acts shewing the accusation of the Twelve Chapters.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 112:15
verses.text: For before the journey to Ephesus the blessed John had written to the very godly bishops Eutherius of Tyana, Firmus of Caesarea, and Theodotus of Ancyra, denouncing these Chapters as Apollinarian.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 112:16
verses.text: And at Ephesus the exposition and confirmation of these Chapters was the cause of our deposition of the Alexandrian and of the Ephesian.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 112:17
verses.text: Moreover at Ephesus many synodic letters were written both to the victorious emperor, and to the great officers, about these Chapters; and in like manner to the laity at Constantinople and to the reverend clergy.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 112:18
verses.text: Moreover when we were summoned to Constantinople we had five discussions in the imperial presence, and afterwards sent the emperor three protestations.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 112:19
verses.text: And to the very godly bishops of the West, of Milan I mean, of Aquileia, and of Ravenna, we wrote on the same subject, protesting that the Chapters were full of the Apollinarian novelty.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 112:20
verses.text: Furthermore their writer received a letter from the blessed John by the hands of the blessed Paul, openly blaming them; and in like manner from Acacius of blessed memory.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 112:21
verses.text: And to give your holiness concise information on the subject I have sent you both the letter of the blessed Acacius, as well as that of the blessed John to the blessed Cyril, in order that you may perceive that though they were writing to him on the subject of agreement they blamed these Chapters.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 112:22
verses.text: And the blessed Cyril himself, in his letter to the blessed Acacius plainly indicated the drift of these Chapters in the words "I have written this against his innovations and when peace is made they will be made manifest".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 112:23
verses.text: The very defence proves the accusation.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 112:24
verses.text: I have sent you the copy of what he wrote at the time of the agreement, that you may see, my lord, that he made no mention of them, and that those who attend the Council are under an obligation to bring forward what was written at the time of the agreement, and to state plainly what had caused the difference and on what terms the sundered parts were atoned.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 112:25
verses.text: For they who are summoned to fight for the truth must flinch from no toil, and must invoke the divine aid, that we may preserve unimpaired the heritage bequeathed us by our forefathers.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 112:26
verses.text: Your holiness must look out for men of like mind among the godly bishops and make them companions of your journey; and likewise of the reverend clergy those who are zealous for the truth, lest betrayed even by them of our own side we are either driven to do something displeasing to the God of all, or, in our abandonment, fall an easy prey to our foes.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 112:27
verses.text: It is faith in which we have our hopes of salvation, and we must leave no means untried to prevent aught spurious being brought into it, and the apostolic teaching from being corrupted.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 112:28
verses.text: I write you these words from far away, with sighs and with groans, and I beseech our common Master to scatter this dark cloud and bestow on us once more the boon of the bright sunshine.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 113:1
verses.text: CXIII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 113:2
verses.text: To Leo, Bishop of Rome.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 113:3
verses.text: If Paul, the herald of the truth, the trumpet of the Holy Ghost, hastened to the great Peter in order that he might carry from him the desired solution of difficulties to those at Antioch who were in doubt about living in conformity with the law, much more do we, men insignificant and small, hasten to your apostolic see in order to receive from you a cure for the wounds of the churches.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 113:4
verses.text: For every reason it is fitting for you to hold the first place, inasmuch as your see is adorned with many privileges.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 113:5
verses.text: Other cities are indeed adorned by their size, their beauty, and their population; and some which in these respects are lacking are made bright by certain spiritual boons.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 113:6
verses.text: But on your city the great Provider has bestowed an abundance of good gifts.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 113:7
verses.text: She is the largest, the most splendid, the most illustrious of the world, and overflows with the multitude of her inhabitants.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 113:8
verses.text: Besides all this, she has achieved her present sovereignty, and has given her name to her subjects.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 113:9
verses.text: She is moreover specially adorned by her faith, in due testimony whereof the divine Apostle exclaims "your faith is spoken of throughout the whole world".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 113:10
verses.text: And if even after receiving the seeds of the message of salvation her boughs were straightway heavy with these admirable fruits, what words can fitly praise the piety now practised in her? In her keeping too are the tombs that give light to the souls of the faithful, those of our common fathers and teachers of the truth, Peter and Paul.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 113:11
verses.text: This thrice blessed and divine pair arose in the region of sunrise, and spread their rays in all directions.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 113:12
verses.text: Now from the region of sunset, where they willingly welcomed the setting of this life, they illuminate the world.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 113:13
verses.text: They have rendered your see most glorious; this is the crown and completion of your good things; but in these days their God has adorned their throne by setting on it your holiness, emitting, as you do, the rays of orthodoxy.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 113:14
verses.text: Of this I might give many proofs, but it is enough to mention the zeal which your holiness lately shewed against the ill-famed Manichees, proving thereby your piety's earnest regard for divine things.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 113:15
verses.text: Your recent writings, too, are enough to indicate your apostolic character.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 113:16
verses.text: For we have met with what your holiness has written concerning the incarnation of our God and Saviour, and we have marvelled at the exactness of your expressions.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 113:17
verses.text: For both writings agreed in setting forth both the everlasting Godhead of the Only-begotten derived from the everlasting Father, and the manhood derived from the seed of Abraham and David; and that the nature assumed was in all things like unto us, being unlike to us in this respect alone, that it remained free from all sin; since it springs not of nature but of free will.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 113:18
verses.text: The letters moreover contain this, that the Only-begotten Son of God is one, and his Godhead impassible, immutable, and invariable, like the Father who begat Him and the Holy Spirit; and that on this account He took the passible nature, divine nature being incapable of suffering, that by the suffering of His own flesh He might bestow freedom from suffering on them that have believed in Him.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 113:19
verses.text: These statements and others of like nature were contained in your letters.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 113:20
verses.text: We, in admiration of your spiritual wisdom, have lauded the grace of the Holy Ghost uttered through you, and we invoke and beseech and beg and implore your highness to protect the churches of God that are now assailed by the storm.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 113:21
verses.text: We had expected that through the instrumentality of the representatives sent by your holiness to Ephesus, the tempest would have been done away, but we have fallen under severer attacks of the storm.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 113:22
verses.text: For the very righteous bishop of Alexandria was not content with the illegal and very unrighteous deposition of the most holy and godly bishop of Constantinople, the lord Flavianus, nor was his soul satisfied with a similar slaughter of the rest of the bishops, but me too in my absence he stabbed with a pen, without summoning me to the bar, without trying me in my presence, without questioning me as to my opinions about the incarnation of our God and Saviour.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 113:23
verses.text: Even murderers, tomb-breakers, and adulterers, are not condemned by their judges until they have themselves confirmed by confession the charges brought against them, or have been clearly convicted by the testimony of others.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 113:24
verses.text: Yet I, nurtured as I have been in the divine laws, have been condemned by him at his pleasure, when all the while I was five and thirty days' march away.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 113:25
verses.text: Nor is this all that he has done.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 113:26
verses.text: Only last year when two fellows tainted with the unsoundness of Apollinarius had gone thither and patched up slanders against me, he stood up in church and anathematized me, and that after I had written to him and explained my opinions to him.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 113:27
verses.text: I lament the disturbance of the church, and long for peace.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 113:28
verses.text: Six and twenty years have I ruled the church entrusted to me by the God of all, aided by your prayers.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 113:29
verses.text: Never in the time of the blessed Theodotus, the chief bishop of the East; never in the time of his successors in the see of Antioch, did I incur the slightest blame.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 113:30
verses.text: By the help of God's grace working with me more than a thousand souls did I rescue from the plague of Marcion; many others from the Arian and Eunomian factions did I bring over to our Master Christ.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 113:31
verses.text: I have done pastoral duty in eight hundred churches, for so many parishes does Cyrus contain; and in them, through your prayers, not even one tare is left, and our flock is delivered from all heresy and error.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 113:32
verses.text: He who sees all things knows how many stones have been cast at me by evil heretics, how many conflicts in most of the cities of the East I have waged against pagans, against Jews, against every heresy.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 113:33
verses.text: After all this trial and all this danger I have been condemned without a trial.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 113:34
verses.text: But I await the sentence of your apostolic see.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 113:35
verses.text: I beseech and implore your holiness to succour me in my appeal to your fair and righteous tribunal.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 113:36
verses.text: Bid me hasten to you, and prove to you that my teaching follows the footprints of the apostles.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 113:37
verses.text: I have in my possession what I wrote twenty years ago; what I wrote eighteen, fifteen, twelve, years ago; against Arians and Eunomians, against Jews and pagans; against the magi in Persia; on divine Providence; on theology; and on the divine incarnation.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 113:38
verses.text: By God's grace I have interpreted the writings of the apostles and the oracles of the prophets.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 113:39
verses.text: From these it is not difficult to ascertain whether I have adhered to the right rule of faith, or have swerved from its straight course.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 113:40
verses.text: Do not, I implore you, spurn my prayer; regard, I implore you, the insults piled after all my labours on my poor grey head.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 113:41
verses.text: Above all, I implore you to tell me whether I ought to put up with this unrighteous deposition or not; for I await your decision.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 113:42
verses.text: If you bid me abide by the sentence of condemnation, I abide; and henceforth I will trouble no man, and will wait for the righteous tribunal of our God and Saviour.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 113:43
verses.text: God is my witness, my lord, that I care not for honour and glory.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 113:44
verses.text: I care only for the scandal that has been caused, in that many of the simpler folk, and especially those whom I have rescued from various heresies, cleaving to the authority of my judges and quite unable to understand the exact truth of the doctrine, will perhaps suppose me guilty of heresy.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 113:45
verses.text: All the people of the East know that during all the time of my episcopate I have not acquired a house, not a piece of ground, not an obol, not a tomb, but of my own accord have embraced poverty, after distributing, at the death of my parents, the whole of the property which I inherited from them.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 113:46
verses.text: Above all I implore you, O holy sir, beloved of God, to grant me the help of your prayers.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 113:47
verses.text: I have told you this by the reverend and godly presbyters Hypatius and Abramius chorepiscopi and by Alypius exarch of our monks.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 113:48
verses.text: I would hasten to you myself were I not kept back by the chains of the imperial order, which imprison me as they do others.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 113:49
verses.text: Treat my messengers, I beseech you, as a father might his sons; give them kindly and unbiassed audience; deign to grant your protection to my old age, slandered as it is and attacked in vain.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 113:50
verses.text: Above all, regard, to the utmost of your power, the faith conspired against; preserve for the churches the inheritance of their fathers unimpaired.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 113:51
verses.text: So will your holiness receive the recompense due for such deeds from the great Giver of all good gifts.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 114:1
verses.text: CXIII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 114:3
verses.text: From Pope Leo to Theodoret.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 114:4
verses.text: To our much beloved brother Theodoretus, bishop, Leo, bishop.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 115:1
verses.text: CXIV.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 115:2
verses.text: To Andiberis.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 115:3
verses.text: The reverend presbyter Peter is distinguished not only by his priestly rank, but also by his wise practice in medicine.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 115:4
verses.text: During his long residence with us he has won all hearts by his conciliatory manners.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 115:5
verses.text: On learning of my departure he has now determined to leave Cyrus; I therefore commend him to your excellency, and hope that, fully capable as he is of doing good service to the city,—for when he lived at Alexandria he practised the same profession,—he will meet with kindness at your hands.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 116:1
verses.text: CXV.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 116:2
verses.text: To Apella.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 116:3
verses.text: When I undertook the direction of the see of Cyrus, I procured for it from all directions men who practised necessary arts, and besides this induced skilful physicians to live there.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 116:4
verses.text: Of these one is the reverend presbyter Peter, who practises his profession with wisdom, and adorns it by his character.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 116:5
verses.text: On my departure, several have left the city and Peter also has determined to leave.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 116:6
verses.text: Under these circumstances I beseech your excellency to give him your kind care.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 116:7
verses.text: He is well able to attend the sick and to wage war against their ailments.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 117:1
verses.text: CXVI.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 117:2
verses.text: To the Presbyter Renatus.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 117:3
verses.text: We have heard of the warm and righteous zeal of your holiness, and the just and lawful boldness of speech which you employed in condemning the audacious proceedings at Ephesus.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 117:4
verses.text: Nor is this known to us alone, but the fame of your orthodoxy has gone out into all lands, and all men are celebrating your righteousness, your zeal, your boldness, and your denunciation of my unfair treatment.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 117:5
verses.text: And your holiness took this course after seeing one massacre.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 117:6
verses.text: If you had seen the others which took place after your departure you would perhaps have emulated the fervour of the famous Phinehas.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 117:7
verses.text: I am one of those who was subsequently condemned, being forbidden by the imperial order to attend the council, and sentenced in my absence.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 117:8
verses.text: Six and twenty years have I been a bishop; innumerable labours have I undergone; I have struggled hard for the truth; I have freed tens of thousands of heretics from their errors and brought them to the Saviour; and now they have stripped me of my priesthood; they are exiling me from the city.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 117:9
verses.text: For my old age, for my hairs grown gray in the truth, they have no respect.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 117:10
verses.text: Wherefore, I beseech your sanctity, persuade the very sacred and holy archbishop to bid me hasten to your council.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 117:11
verses.text: For that holy see has precedence over all churches in the world, for many reasons; and above all for this, that it is free from all taint of heresy, and that no bishop of heterodox opinion has ever sat upon its throne, but it has kept the grace of the apostles undefiled.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 117:12
verses.text: Confident in your justice I shall accept your decisions, whatever they may be, and shall claim to be judged by my writings.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 117:13
verses.text: More than thirty books have I written against Arius and Eunomius, against Marcion, against Macedonius, against the heathen and against Jews; I have interpreted the holy Scriptures, and any one who likes may easily learn that I have followed in the steps of the apostles, proclaiming the one Son, one Father, and one Holy Ghost; one Godhead of the Trinity, one sovereignty, one power, eternity, immutability, impassibility, one will; that the Godhead of the Lord Jesus Christ was perfect, perfect the manhood taken for our salvation and for our sakes delivered unto death.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 117:14
verses.text: I do not know one Son of man and another Son of God, but one and the same, Son of God and God begotten of God, and Son of man, through the form of the servant, of the seed of Abraham and David.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 117:15
verses.text: These and like doctrines I continue to teach; these also I have found in the writings of the most holy and sacred lord archbishop Leo, and I praise the Lord of all that I agree with his apostolic doctrines.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 117:16
verses.text: Receive, I beseech you, my supplication, and do not overlook the wrongs under which I suffer.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 117:17
verses.text: On this account I have sent to your holiness the godly presbyters Hypatius and Abramius, chorepiscopi, and Alypius exarch of our monks, adorned as they are by good lives, and able by word of mouth to give you exact information as to the affairs of my insignificant self.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 118:1
verses.text: CXVII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 118:2
verses.text: To the Bishop Florentius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 118:3
verses.text: Truly the grace of our God and Saviour has not yet abandoned the human race, but has left us a seed in your holiness "lest we should become as Sodom, and be made like unto Gomorrah".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 118:4
verses.text: This seed suffers us not altogether to faint, but charges us to wait for the passing away of the dire storm; this renders us hopeful.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 118:5
verses.text: We have therefore sent to your holiness the very godly presbyters Hypatius and Abramius, chorepiscopi, and Alypius, exarch of our monks, that you may put an end to the disaster which has befallen the churches of the East; that in the first place you may confirm the faith handed down to us from the first by the holy Apostles, may proscribe the heresy that has started up, and openly convict the men who have the hardihood to debase the preaching of the oeconomy; and secondly may fight as champion of them who are being attacked for the truth's sake.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 118:6
verses.text: For it is in the cause of the apostolic Faith, most holy, that we have undergone that unrighteous massacre, because we refused to abandon the truth of the Gospel doctrines.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 118:7
verses.text: Now it behoves your holiness not to overlook the unjust persecution of men of like mind with yourself, but by your just help to put a stop to injustice, and teach the assailants of the truth that men who strive to act unscrupulously at their own good pleasure cannot be allowed to work out their ends.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 119:1
verses.text: CXVIII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 119:2
verses.text: To the Archdeacon of Rome.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 119:3
verses.text: A terrible storm has attacked our churches, but the adherents of the apostolic faith have in your holiness a safe and quiet haven.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 119:4
verses.text: Not only do you champion the cause of the doctrines of the Gospel, but you utterly detest the wrong done to me.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 119:5
verses.text: I was living far away at a distance of thirty-five days' journey, when I was condemned at their good pleasure by those most righteous judges.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 119:6
verses.text: Teaching which has obtained in the churches from the coming of God our Saviour till this day they have abandoned.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 119:7
verses.text: They have introduced a novel and bastard doctrine, diametrically contrary to the tradition of the apostles, and are openly at war with them that hold to the ancient instruction.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 119:8
verses.text: Deign, then, most godly sir, to kindle the zeal of the very sacred and holy archbishop, that the churches of the East too may enjoy your kindly care.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 119:9
verses.text: Above all fight in behalf of the faith delivered from the beginning by the holy apostles; preserve the heritage of our fathers unimpaired, and scatter the mist that oppresses us.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 119:10
verses.text: Give us instead of moonless night clear sunshine, and condemn the wickedness of the massacre unrighteously wrought against us.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 119:11
verses.text: It is becoming to your holiness to add yet this act of zeal to your other good deeds.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 120:1
verses.text: CXIX.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 120:2
verses.text: To Anatolius the Patrician.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 120:3
verses.text: Your excellency has been fully informed as to the acts of the most righteous judges at Ephesus, for their sound has gone out into all lands and their most just judgment to the ends of the world.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 120:4
verses.text: What church has not felt the storm that has been raised by it? The one side wronged, the other were wronged, but they who neither suffered nor did the wrong share the distress of the wronged, and lament over them that so savagely and against all laws human and divine massacred their own members.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 120:5
verses.text: Even house breakers caught in the very act are first tried and then punished by their judges; even murderers, violators of sepulchres, and adulterers, are first haled before the bench, and their accusers ordered to make their indictment, and the motive of the witnesses is tested to see that they are not giving evidence to curry favour with the prosecutors, or are prejudiced against the defendants; and after this they are bidden to make their defence to the charges brought against them.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 120:6
verses.text: This is done twice, thrice; sometimes even four times; and then, and not till then, after the truth has been sought in the words of both accuser and accused, the sentence is given.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 120:7
verses.text: As to how these men judged in the case of the rest I will say nothing, lest I may seem a meddler in what does not concern me.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 120:8
verses.text: I am forced to speak on behalf of myself alone, for the unrighteous deed of violence compels me.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 120:9
verses.text: The imperial order kept me at home, and prevented me from travelling beyond the bounds of the city placed under my pastoral care.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 120:10
verses.text: The decision of the synod went against me, and a man was condemned who was five and thirty days' journey away.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 120:11
verses.text: Now the God of all said to the patriarch Abraham about Sodom and Gomorrah: "Because the cry of Sodom and Gomorrah is very great and because their sin is very grievous; I will go down now and see whether they have done altogether according to the cry of it which is come unto me; and if not, I will know".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 120:12
verses.text: He knew quite well the wickedness of those men, and nevertheless He said, "I will go down and see," so teaching us to wait for the proof of facts.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 120:13
verses.text: But these men never summoned me to trial, they never heard the sound of my voice, they refused to hear from me a statement of my opinions, and handed me over, as a victim to be slaughtered, to the rage of the enemies of the truth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 120:14
verses.text: I, however, welcome my rest, and especially so at the present time, when the apostolic decrees have been by many destroyed, and the new heresy strengthened.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 120:15
verses.text: But lest any one who does not know me should believe that the slanders uttered against me are true, and should be scandalized at the idea of my holding opinions other than those of the gospel, I implore your excellency to ask as a favour from the victorious sovereign that I may go to the West, and there plead my cause before the very godly and holy bishops; and if I be found transgressing in the least degree the rule of the faith, that I may be plunged into the midst of the deep sea.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 120:16
verses.text: If he will not grant you this request, let him at least command me to inhabit my monastery, which is a hundred and twenty miles away from Cyrus, seventy-five from Antioch, and lies three miles away from Apamea.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 120:17
verses.text: Of these petitions, if possible, I ask the former; if not at least I implore that, through your excellency's interposition, the second may be granted me.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 120:18
verses.text: I shall ever carry the memory of your kindness in my heart and on my lips, supplicating the Lord of hosts to requite your excellency as well with present as with future blessings.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 120:19
verses.text: I am compelled to write to you in these terms because I have heard that certain persons are endeavouring to compass my removal from this place.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 121:1
verses.text: CXX.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 121:2
verses.text: To Lupicius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 121:3
verses.text: Even the enemies of the truth must, I think, be indignant at the injustice and illegality of the violence done us.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 121:4
verses.text: It is only reasonable that the nurslings of the truth, at whose head stands your excellency, should be still more distressed at this new and surprising tragedy.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 121:5
verses.text: It is only right that those who are the more grieved should show the more earnestness and zeal to counteract the deeds impiously and illegally done; and restore to its previous concord the Church's body now in peril of being torn asunder.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 121:6
verses.text: Wherefore I beseech your excellency to reckon the present crisis an opportunity for spiritual reciprocity; to give on your side earnestness on behalf of the truth, and to receive from our generous Master alike His kindly care in this present life and in the life to come the kingdom of heaven.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 122:1
verses.text: CXXI.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 122:2
verses.text: To Anatolius the Patrician.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 122:3
verses.text: The Lord who overlooks and governs all things has shewn both the apostolic truth of my doctrines, and the falsehood of the slander laid at my door.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 122:4
verses.text: For the writings sent from the right godly and holy lord Leo, archbishop of Great Rome, to Flavianus of holy memory and to the rest assembled at Ephesus, are entirely in harmony with what I myself have written and have always preached in church.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 122:5
verses.text: So soon therefore as I had read them, I praised the loving-kindness of the Lord, in that He had not wholly forsaken the churches, but had protected the spark of orthodoxy; or—shall I not rather say?—not a spark, but a very great torch, such as might enkindle and enlighten the world; for he has truly, in his writings, observed the apostolic stamp, and in them we have found at once what has been delivered by the holy and blessed prophets and apostles, and their successors in the preaching of the Gospel, and moreover the holy Fathers assembled at Nicaea.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 122:6
verses.text: By these I confess that I abide, and indict all who hold other doctrines as guilty of impiety.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 122:7
verses.text: Side by side with these writings of mine I have set one of the letters sent by him to Ephesus, to the end that when your excellency reads them you may remember the words which I have often spoken in church, may recognise the harmony of the doctrines, and may hate the utterers of the lie as well as those who have set up their new heresy in opposition to the doctrines of the Apostle.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 123:1
verses.text: CXXII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 123:2
verses.text: To UraniusBishop of Emesa.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 123:3
verses.text: I have been greatly delighted that we who correspond in character should have corresponded by letter.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 123:4
verses.text: But I do not quite see what you mean by saying "Are not these my words?" If it were said only for the sake of salutation, I am not annoyed at it; but if it is intended to remind me of the advice which recommended silence, and of the so-called oeconomy, I am very much obliged, but I do not accept the suggestion.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 123:5
verses.text: For the divine Apostle charges us to take quite the opposite course.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 123:6
verses.text: "Be instant in season and out of season".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 123:7
verses.text: And the Lord says to this very spokesman, "Be not afraid, but speak" and to Isaiah, "Cry aloud, spare not" and to Moses "Go down, charge the people" and to Ezekiel "I have made thee a watchman unto the house of Israel," and it shall be "if thou warn not the wicked," and the like: for I think it needless to write at length to one who knows.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 123:8
verses.text: Not only therefore are we not distressed at having spoken freely, but we even rejoice and are glad, and laud Him who has thought us worthy of these sufferings; aye and call on my friends to encounter the same perils.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 123:9
verses.text: If they know that we do not keep the apostolic rule of the faith, but swerve to the right hand or the left, let them hate us; let them join the opposite side; let them be ranked with them that are at war with us.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 123:10
verses.text: But if they bear witness to our holding the right teaching of the gospel message, we hail them with the cry, "Do you too 'stand having your loins girt about with truth,…and your feet shod with the preparation of the gospel of peace,'" and so on, for it is said that virtue comprises not only temperance, righteousness, and prudence, but also courage, and that by means of courage the rest of its component parts are preserved.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 123:11
verses.text: For righteousness needs the alliance of courage in its war against wrong; temperance vanquishes intemperance by the aid of courage.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 123:12
verses.text: And for this reason the God of all said to the prophet "The just shall live by his faith, and if any man draw back, my soul shall have no pleasure in him".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 123:13
verses.text: Shrinking he calls cowardice.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 123:14
verses.text: Hold fast then, my dear friend, to the apostolic doctrines, for "He that shall come will come, and will not tarry," and "He shall render to every man according to his deeds," for "the fashion of this world passeth away," and the truth shall be made manifest.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 124:1
verses.text: CXXIII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 124:2
verses.text: To the Same.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 124:3
verses.text: Your letter was a long one, and a pleasant one, and it shews how warm and genuine is your affection.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 124:4
verses.text: So delighted am I with it that I am not at all sorry for having erroneously conjectured the meaning of the beginning of your former one.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 124:5
verses.text: For my misapprehension of the intention of your letter has disclosed your brotherly love, made plain the sincerity of your faith, and shewn your zeal for the true religion.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 124:6
verses.text: We have indeed shared between us the words and the trials of the prophet; your holiness has used the words; I am buffeted by the hurricane and billows, and against the rowers of the ship I exclaim in his words "They that observe lying vanities forsake their own mercy".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 124:7
verses.text: Perhaps He who is Jonah's Lord and mine will grant that I too may rise and be released from the monster.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 124:8
verses.text: But if the surge continue to boil I trust that even thus I shall enjoy the divine protection, and learn by my own experience how His strength is "made perfect in weakness," for He has measured the peril by my infirmity.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 124:9
verses.text: The divine prophet whom I have mentioned was flung into the sea by his shipmates one and all, but I am granted the consolation of your holiness, and of other godly men.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 124:10
verses.text: For them and for your godliness I pray that the blessing bestowed upon the excellent Onesiphorus may be yours, for you have not blushed at my gibes; nay rather you have shared in my afflictions for the faith's sake.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 124:11
verses.text: And one thing which I wish you to know is that, though other godly bishops have sent me their bounty, I have declined to receive it;—not from any want of respect to the senders, God forbid;—but because hitherto food convenient for me has been provided by Him Who gives it even to the ravens without stint.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 124:12
verses.text: In the case of your reverence I have acted differently, for really the warmth of your affection has overcome what has hitherto been my fixed principle.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 124:13
verses.text: For be well assured, my godly friend, that ever since friendship grew up between us the fire of our love has been kindled to greater heat.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 125:1
verses.text: CXXIV.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 125:2
verses.text: To the Learned Maranas.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 125:3
verses.text: I too am distressed at the calamities of the Church, and wail over the storm that is raging; for myself I am glad to be quit of agitation, and to be enjoying a calm which is delightful to me.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 125:4
verses.text: As to the men whom your learning states to be still carrying on their iniquities, the day is not far distant when they will pay the penalty of their present rash lawlessness.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 125:5
verses.text: All things are governed by the Lord of all with weight and rule, and whenever any fall away into unbounded iniquity His long suffering comes to an end, and He then acts as Judge and appoints punishment.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 125:6
verses.text: Foreseeing this I pray that they may cease from their license that I may not be compelled to weep once more for them as I behold them undergoing chastisement.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 125:7
verses.text: Your excellency I can never forget, and I beg our common Master to fill your house with blessing.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 126:1
verses.text: CXXV.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 126:2
verses.text: To Aphthonius, Theodoritus, Nonnus, Scylacius, Apthonius, Joannes, Magistrates of the Zeugmatensis.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 126:3
verses.text: I know the strength and stability of your faith, and have been filled with the greatest possible delight, for, since we worshippers of the eternal Trinity constitute one body, it is only natural that together with the members that are sound the rest of the members should rejoice.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 126:4
verses.text: So says the divine Apostle; "Whether one member be honoured all the members rejoice with it".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 126:5
verses.text: I therefore rejoice with you in your struggles on behalf of the apostolic doctrines and your following of the famous Naboth in more excellent things.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 126:6
verses.text: Naboth for his vineyard's sake suffered most unrighteous slaughter, because he would not give up the heritage of his fathers.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 126:7
verses.text: You are fighting not for vineyards, but for divine doctrines, and reject this new-fangled and spurious heresy as blackening the brightness of the teaching of the gospel; you do not suffer the number of the blessed Trinity to be diminished or increased.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 126:8
verses.text: For it is diminished by those who ascribe the passion of the only begotten to the Godhead; it is increased by those who have the audacity to introduce a second son.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 126:9
verses.text: You believe in one only begotten, as you do in one Father and in one Holy Ghost.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 126:10
verses.text: In the only begotten made flesh you behold the assumed nature which He took from us and offered on our behalf.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 126:11
verses.text: The denial of this nature puts our salvation far from us; for if the Godhead of the only begotten is impassible, as the nature of the Trinity is impassible, and we refuse to acknowledge that which is by nature adapted to suffer, then the preaching of a passion which never happened is idle and vain.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 126:12
verses.text: For if that which suffers has no existence how could there be a passion? We declare that the divine nature is impassible;—a doctrine confessed by our opponents as well as by ourselves.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 126:13
verses.text: How then could there be a passion when there is no subject capable of suffering? The great mystery of the oeconomy will appear an appearance, a mere seeming instead of the reality.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 126:14
verses.text: This is the fable started by Valentinus, Bardesanes, Marcion and Manes.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 126:15
verses.text: But the teaching handed down to the churches from the beginning recognises, even after the incarnation, one Son, our Lord Jesus Christ, and confesses the same to be everlasting God, and man made at the end of days; made man not by the mutation of the Godhead but by the assumption of the manhood.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 126:16
verses.text: For suppose the divine nature to have undergone mutation into the human nature, then it did not remain what it was; and if it is not what it was, they who have these objects of worship are false in calling Him God.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 126:17
verses.text: We, on the contrary, recognise the only begotten Son of God to be immutable as God, and Son of the very God.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 126:18
verses.text: For we have learnt from the divine Scripture that being in the form of God He took the form of the servant; and took on Him the seed of Abraham, not was changed into Abraham's seed; and shared just as we do both in flesh and blood and in a soul immortal and immaculate.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 126:19
verses.text: Preserving these for our sinful bodies He offered His sinless body and for our souls His soul free from all stain.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 126:20
verses.text: It is for this reason that we have the hope of the common resurrection for the race will assuredly share with its first fruits, and as we have shared with Adam in his death, so too with Christ our Saviour shall we be sharers in His life.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 126:21
verses.text: This the divine Apostle has plainly taught us, for "now" he says "is Christ risen from the dead and become the first fruits of them that slept.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 126:22
verses.text: For since by man came death, by man came also the resurrection of the dead, for as in Adam all die, even so in Christ shall all be made alive".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 126:23
verses.text: I write thus not to inform you but to remind you.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 126:24
verses.text: I have tried to be brief, but I fear I have transgressed the limits of a letter.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 126:25
verses.text: I was however urged to write by the very reverend and godly presbyter and archimandrite Mecimas, who, in obedience to the law of love, has undertaken so long a journey, told us of your excellency's zeal, and begged us to inflame it by a letter.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 126:26
verses.text: I have therefore granted his supplication, and written my letter, and I implore the Lord of all to keep you safe in the faith and make stronger than him who sifts us.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 127:1
verses.text: CXXVI.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 127:2
verses.text: To the Bishop Sabinianus.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 127:3
verses.text: I praised your holiness on your quitting the envied see.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 127:4
verses.text: Once it was venerable; now it is ridiculous, for we have made it a thing to be bought and sold.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 127:5
verses.text: I was astounded to hear of your having appealed to the men who ejected you.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 127:6
verses.text: You ought to have done just the contrary, and, on being invited to grasp the tiller, to have declined to do so, on the ground that your shipmates had become your foes.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 127:7
verses.text: Are you not aware, most godly sir, what our Saviour, through His sacred apostles, taught us to preach? Do you not know what the heirs of the apostolic doctrines have just now laid down as objects of worship? For who of the old teachers from the time when the message was first preached down to the period of the darkness that now obtains, ever listened to any one preaching one nature of flesh and Godhead or dared at any time to call the nature of the only begotten passible? These doctrines in our day are by some men openly and boldly uttered, while among others their utterance is overlooked, and by silence men become participators in the blasphemy.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 127:8
verses.text: What then, may well be asked, is the proper course to be taken by those who abominate such doctrines? They have, I should reply, two alternatives before them; they may either come to close quarters, and prove the spuriousness of the doctrines, or they may decline communion with their opponents as openly impious.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 127:9
verses.text: I, indeed, have received the wrong done me as a divine blessing.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 127:10
verses.text: I do not mean that I have thanked them that have wronged me; how could I thank fratricides, and men who have become followers of Cain?  But I praise my Master for thinking me worthy of the lot of them that suffer wrong, for separating me from wrong-doers and blasphemers, and for giving me my most delightful rest.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 128:1
verses.text: CXXVII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 128:2
verses.text: To Jobius, Presbyter and Archimandrite.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 128:3
verses.text: The patriarch Abraham won a victory in his old age.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 128:4
verses.text: The great Moses was now an old man when, so long as he stretched out his hands in prayer, he vanquished Amalek.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 128:5
verses.text: The divine Samuel was an old man when he put the aliens to flight.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 128:6
verses.text: These are emulated by your venerable old age.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 128:7
verses.text: In our wars for true religion's sake you are playing the man, and championing the cause of the gospel doctrines, and putting young men in the shade by the vigour of your spirit.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 128:8
verses.text: I rejoice to hear it, and am glad, and long to embrace your right venerable gray hairs.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 128:9
verses.text: This I cannot do, for your reverence is kept at home by your years, and I am kept in durance here by the imperial decree.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 128:10
verses.text: But I cheat my love by this letter, and give your piety this most loving embrace.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 128:11
verses.text: I call upon you in your prayers to help the churches now whelmed in the storm, and to win for me the divine support, assailed as I am for the sake of the doctrines of the gospel, and standing sorely in need of help from above.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 129:1
verses.text: CXXVIII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 129:2
verses.text: To Candidus, Presbyter and Archimandrite.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 129:3
verses.text: I am afraid that the vigour of your godly soul has been overcome by old age, and that you do not keep your hands stretched out as usual.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 129:4
verses.text: So Amalek is trying to win.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 129:5
verses.text: May there be some to succour your weakness, as once of old Ur and Aaron supported the hands of the law-giver, that you may overthrow Amalek and save Israel.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 129:6
verses.text: These are days when we specially need more earnest prayers, when Gentiles and Jews and every heresy are at peace, and the Church alone is beaten by the storm and surrounded by the boisterous billows.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 129:7
verses.text: We indeed specially need the aid of your prayers, for those whom we reckoned to be fighting on our side are fighting on that of our foes.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 130:1
verses.text: CXXIX.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 130:2
verses.text: To Magnus Antoninus the Presbyter.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 130:3
verses.text: Sailors at night are cheered by the sight of the harbour lights, and so are they who are in peril for the sake of the apostolic faith by the zeal of them that share the faith.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 130:4
verses.text: We have great comfort in what we hear of your godliness's efforts on behalf of the divine doctrines, for this mind has been given you by the Giver of all good gifts and for the safe keeping of these doctrines you undergo every toil.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 130:5
verses.text: Now I, comforted by your zeal, make an insignificant return, calling on you to persevere in your divine labours, to despise your adversaries as an easy prey, (for what is weaker than they who are destitute of the truth?) and to trust in Him who said "I will not fail thee nor forsake thee," and "Lo I am with you alway even unto the end of the world".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 130:6
verses.text: Help me too with your prayers that I may confidently say "The Lord is on my side; I will not fear: what can man do unto me?".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 131:1
verses.text: CXXX.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 131:2
verses.text: To Bishop Timotheus.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 131:3
verses.text: Not without purpose does the supreme Ruler allow the spirits that are against us to agitate the waves of impiety.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 131:4
verses.text: He does so that He may try the courage of the sailors, and, while He exhibits some men's manliness, convicts others of cowardice, stripping the mask from the faces of some who put on an appearance of piety, and proclaiming others as foremost fighters in the ranks of the truth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 131:5
verses.text: We have seen an instance of this in the present time.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 131:6
verses.text: The storm rose high; some shewed their secret impiety; some abandoned the truth which they were holding, went over to the phalanx of our foes, and now, with them, are smiting the very men whom they used to call their chiefs.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 131:7
verses.text: The witnesses of these things detest the enemy and pity the deserters, but are afraid to give aid to the victims of the attack upon the apostolic doctrines.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 131:8
verses.text: Nay, suppose the traitors to urge them with greater insistency, they will perhaps themselves pass over to the side of the assailants, will give no quarter to their fellow-believers, but will drive against them their barbs side by side with the very men whom they accuse.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 131:9
verses.text: They will act thus though they have been taught by the divine Scripture that a wrong done to one's neighbour incurs punishment, while the suffering of injustice entails great and lasting rewards.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 131:10
verses.text: Your own piety, your zeal for the faith, and your good will to myself, have been proved by this agitation.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 131:11
verses.text: Twice you have written me a letter in contempt of all that might deter you, and have thus shewn your brotherly affection.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 131:12
verses.text: You have also indicated the conflict you are sustaining on behalf of the apostolic doctrines.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 131:13
verses.text: You ask me to tell you by letter what we ought to think and preach concerning the passion of salvation.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 131:14
verses.text: I have received your request with delight, and, not indeed to give you information but only to remind one who is beloved of God, will proceed to tell you what I have learnt from the divine Scripture and from the Fathers who have interpreted it.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 131:15
verses.text: Know then, most godly sir, that before all things it is necessary to observe the distinction of terms, and, in addition to this, the cause of the divine incarnation.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 131:16
verses.text: Once let these be made clear, and there will be no ambiguity left about the passion.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 131:17
verses.text: We will therefore first, to those who endeavour to contradict us, put this enquiry.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 131:18
verses.text: Which of the names given to the only begotten Son of God are anterior to the incarnation, and which posterior, or rather, connected with the operation of the oeconomy? They will reply that the terms anterior are, "God the Word," "only begotten Son," "Almighty," and "Lord of all creation"; and that the names "Jesus Christ" belong to the incarnation.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 131:19
verses.text: For, after the incarnation, God the Word, the only begotten Son of God is called Jesus Christ; for "Behold" He says "unto you is born this day Christ the Lord" and because others had been called christs, priests, kings, and prophets, lest any one should suppose Him to be like unto them, the angels conjoined the title Lord with that of Christ, in order to prove the supreme dignity of Him that was born.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 131:20
verses.text: And, again, Gabriel says to the blessed Virgin, "Behold thou shalt conceive in thy womb, and bring forth a son and shalt call His name Jesus" "for He shall save His people from their sins".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 131:21
verses.text: Before the incarnation, however, He was never called either Christ or Jesus.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 131:22
verses.text: For truly the divine Prophets, in their predictions of things to come, used the words, just as they prophesied about the birth, the cross, and the passion, when the events had not yet come to pass.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 131:23
verses.text: Nevertheless, even after the incarnation He is called God the Word, Lord, Almighty, only begotten Son, Maker, and Creator.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 131:24
verses.text: For He was not made man by mutation, but, remaining just what He was, assumed what we are, for "Being in the form of God," to use the words of the divine Apostle "He took the form of a servant".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 131:25
verses.text: On this account, therefore, even after the incarnation, He is called also by the titles which are anterior to the incarnation, since His nature is invariable and immutable.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 131:26
verses.text: But when relating the passion the divine Scripture nowhere uses the term God, since that is the name of the absolute nature.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 131:27
verses.text: No one on hearing the words "In the beginning was the Word and the Word was with God, and the Word was God" and similar expressions, would suppose that the flesh existed before the ages, or is of one substance with the God of the universe, or was Creator of the world.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 131:28
verses.text: Every one knows that these terms are proper to the Godhead.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 131:29
verses.text: Nor would any one on reading the genealogy of St.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 131:30
verses.text: Matthew suppose that David and Abraham according to nature were forefathers of God, for it is the assumed nature which is derived from them.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 131:31
verses.text: Since then these points are plain and indubitable even among extreme heretics, and we acknowledge both the nature which is before the ages, and that which is of recent time, so are we bound to recognise at once the passibility of the flesh, and the impassibility of the Godhead, not dividing the union nor separating the only begotten into two persons, but contemplating the properties of the natures in the one Son.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 131:32
verses.text: In the case of soul and body, which are of natures contemporary and naturally united, we are accustomed to make this distinction, describing the soul as simple, reasonable, and immortal, but the body as complex, passible, and mortal.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 131:33
verses.text: We do not divide the union, nor cut one man in two.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 131:34
verses.text: Far rather, then, in the case of the Godhead, begotten of the Father before the ages, and of the manhood assumed of David's seed, is it becoming to adopt a similar course, and distinctly to recognise the everlasting, eternal, simple, uncircumscribed, immortal, and invariable character of the one nature, and the recent, complex, circumscribed, and fluctuating nature of the other.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 131:35
verses.text: We acknowledge the flesh to be now immortal and incorruptible, although before the resurrection it was susceptible of death and of passion; for how otherwise was it nailed to the tree, and committed to the tomb? And though we recognise the distinction of the natures, we are bound to worship one Son, and to acknowledge the same as Son of God and Son of man, form of God, and form of a servant, Son of David, and Lord of David, seed of Abraham, and creator of Abraham.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 131:36
verses.text: The union causes the names to be common, but the community of names does not confound the natures.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 131:37
verses.text: With them that are right-minded some names are plainly appropriate as to God, and others as to man; and in this way both the passible and the impassible are properly used of the Lord Christ, for in His humanity He suffered, while as God He remained impassible.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 131:38
verses.text: If, according to the argument of the impious, it was in the Godhead that He suffered, then, I apprehend, the assumption of the flesh, was supererogatory; for suppose the divine nature to have been capable of undergoing passion, then He did not need the passible manhood.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 131:39
verses.text: But grant that, as even their own argument contends, the Godhead was impassible, and the passion was real, let them beware of denying that which suffered, lest they deny with it the reality of the passion; for if that which suffers does not exist, then the passion is unreal.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 131:40
verses.text: Now for any one who likes to open the quaternion of the sacred evangelists, it is easy to perceive that the divine Scripture distinctly proclaims the passion of the body, and to learn from them how Joseph of Arimathaea came to Pilate, and begged the body of Jesus; how Pilate ordered the body of Jesus to be delivered, how Joseph took down the body of Jesus from the tree and wrapped the body of Jesus in the linen cloth, and laid it in the new tomb.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 131:41
verses.text: All this is described by the four evangelists with frequent mention of the body.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 131:42
verses.text: But if our opponents adduce the words of the angel to Mary and her companions, "Come where the Lord lay," let them be referred to the passage in the Acts which states that devout men "carried Stephen to his burial" and observe that it was not the soul, but the body, of the victorious Stephen, to which the customary rites were paid.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 131:43
verses.text: And to this very day, when we approach the shrines of the victorious martyrs, we commonly enquire what is the name of him who is buried in the grave, and those who are acquainted with the facts reply peradventure "Julian the martyr," or "Romanus," or, "Timotheus".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 131:44
verses.text: Very often it is not entire bodies that are buried, but only very small remains, yet nevertheless we speak of the body by the name that belongs to the whole man.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 131:45
verses.text: It was in this sense that the angel called the body of the Lord, "Lord," because it was the body of the Lord of the universe.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 131:46
verses.text: Moreover the Lord Himself promised to give on behalf of the life of the world, not His invisible nature, but His body.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 131:47
verses.text: "For," He says, "the bread that I will give is my flesh which I will give for the life of the world," and when He took the symbol of divine mysteries, He said, "This is my body which is given for you".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 131:48
verses.text: Or according to the version of the Apostle, "broken".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 131:49
verses.text: In no place where He spoke of the passion did He mention the impassible Godhead.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 131:50
verses.text: It is therefore before all things necessary that the question should be put to those who are endeavouring to contradict us whether they confess that the perfect manhood was assumed by God the Word, and assert the union to have been made without confusion.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 131:51
verses.text: Once let these points be admitted, and the rest will follow in due course, and the passion will be attributed to the passible nature.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 131:52
verses.text: I have now summed up these heads and have exceeded the limits of my letter.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 131:53
verses.text: I have sent also what I lately wrote at the suggestion of a very godly and holy man of God, the lord—in the form of a concise instruction designed to teach the truth of the apostolic doctrines.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 131:54
verses.text: Should I find a good copyist, I will also send your holiness what I have written in the form of a dialogue, extending the argument, and strengthening my positions, by the teaching of the Fathers.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 131:55
verses.text: I have moreover now sent a few statements of the ancient teachers, sufficient to shew the drift of their instruction.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 131:56
verses.text: Give me in return, most godly sir, the succour of your prayers, that I may pass through the terrible tempest and reach the quiet haven of the Saviour.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 132:1
verses.text: CXXXI.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 132:2
verses.text: To Longinus, Archimandrite of Doliche.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 132:3
verses.text: You have shewn alike your zeal for the true religion, and your love for your neighbour, both of which are at the present time clearly connected, for it is for the sake of the apostolic decrees that I am being attacked, because I refuse to give up the heritage of my fathers, and prefer to undergo any suffering to looking lightly on the robbery of one tittle from the faith of the Gospel.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 132:4
verses.text: You have accepted fellowship in my sufferings, not only by comforting me by means of your letter, but further by sending to me the very honourable and pious Matthew and Isaac.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 132:5
verses.text: You shall hear, I am well assured, from the lips of the righteous Lord, "I was in prison, and ye visited me".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 132:6
verses.text: We are small and of no account, and burdened by a great load of sins, but the Lord is bountiful and generous.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 132:7
verses.text: He remembers the small rather than the great, and says, "Inasmuch as ye have done it unto one of the least of these" "which believe in me" "ye have done it unto me".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 132:8
