verses.text: I pray you in that you are conspicuous for right doctrine, and shine by worthiness of life, and therefore have great boldness before God, help me in your prayers, that I may be able "to stand," to use the words of the Apostle, "against the wiles of error," escape the sins of the destroyer, and stand, though with little boldness, in the day of the appearing before the righteous Judge.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 133:1
verses.text: CXXXII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 133:2
verses.text: To Ibas, Bishop of Edessa.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 133:3
verses.text: The Lord has taught them that suffer wrong not to be cast down, but to rejoice, and to derive consolation from the examples of old.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 133:4
verses.text: For from the period of the first men down to our own days we find instances of men who have been zealous in the worship of the God of all, and yet have been wronged by those with whom their lot was cast, and have fallen into many and grievous troubles.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 133:5
verses.text: Of these I would have gone through the entire list, had I not been writing to one of accurate knowledge of the divine Scriptures.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 133:6
verses.text: But since you, O beloved of God, have been nurtured from your boyhood in the divine oracles, I have thought it needless so to do.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 133:7
verses.text: I only ask you to cast your eyes on them, and to look on all the kind-hearted clergy that have done wrong, with sorrow; on all that look lightly on wrong doing, with pity; and to be sorrowful for the disquiet of the Church.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 133:8
verses.text: I ask you to rejoice and be glad that I am a sharer in suffering for the sake of true religion, and to praise without ceasing Him who has imposed this lot on me.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 133:9
verses.text: As for honour and comfort and the dignity of sees and wretched reputation, let us yield them to the murderers.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 133:10
verses.text: Let us cleave only to the doctrines of the gospel, and with them, if need be, endure any extremity of pain, and choose honourable penury rather than wealth with its many cares.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 133:11
verses.text: I am not writing in these terms in order to give you exhortation, for I know the courage of your holiness in trouble.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 133:12
verses.text: My object is to make my own mind known to your piety, and to inform you that you have on your side comrades who are gladly incurring peril for the truth's sake.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 133:13
verses.text: I have been anxious for some time to write thus to you, but I have been unable to find anyone to convey my letter.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 133:14
verses.text: Now I have met with the very honourable and pious presbyter Ozeas, a man who is at once engaged in the battle for truth and attached to your piety.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 133:15
verses.text: So I write and salute your holiness, and beg you to give me both the prop of your prayers and the comfort of a letter from you.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 134:1
verses.text: CXXXIII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 134:2
verses.text: To John, Bishop of Germanicia.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 134:3
verses.text: I have always known, sir, that you are not unmindful of our friendship.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 134:4
verses.text: And it has ever been my wish and prayer that your piety should give heed to exact truth, and shun the communion of traitors to true religion, ascribing to the Supreme Ruler His care on our behalf.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 134:5
verses.text: For indeed, while I have been silent and inactive, He has put an end to our very keen and terrible sufferings, and has replaced the dire tempest by this bright calm.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 134:6
verses.text: And now that the loving-kindness of the Lord has granted us this blessing, I find the quiet of my retreat indeed delightful, for I feel the necessity of persuading those who have been led away by the slanders launched against me, and of both convincing them of the truth of the teaching of the gospels, and refuting the attack of falsehood.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 134:7
verses.text: When once this refutation is finished, and the victory of the truth is secured, it is my purpose to quit public life, and withdraw to the rest that I so greatly long for.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 134:8
verses.text: As to the foes of the truth I cry with the prophet, "Their memorial is perished with a noise, but the Lord shall endure for ever".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 134:9
verses.text: As to ourselves, I sing with the Psalmist, "He sent from above, He took me, He drew me out of many waters, He delivered me from my strong enemy".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 134:10
verses.text: This letter is in reply to two received from your holiness, one conveyed by Anastasius, the presbyter of Beroea, and one by the standard-bearer Theodotus.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 134:11
verses.text: In your last letter you mention another, but this has not been delivered.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 134:12
verses.text: As to my journey thither I can say nothing till I know what orders are given concerning me by the most pious emperor.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 134:13
verses.text: His letter has not yet arrived.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 135:1
verses.text: CXXXIV.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 135:2
verses.text: To Theoctistus, Bishop of Beroea.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 135:3
verses.text: Our Saviour, Lawgiver, and Lord, was once asked, "What is the first commandment?" His reply was "Thou shalt love the Lord thy God with all thy heart, and with all thy soul, and with all thy mind".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 135:4
verses.text: And He added "This is the first commandment: and the second is like unto it, Thou shalt love thy neighbour as thyself".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 135:5
verses.text: Then He said further "On these two commandments hang all the law and the prophets".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 135:6
verses.text: He then who keeps these, according to the definition of the Lord, plainly fulfils the Law; and he who transgresses them is guilty of transgressing the whole Law.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 135:7
verses.text: Let us then examine, before the exact and righteous tribunal of our conscience, whether we have fulfilled the divine commandments.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 135:8
verses.text: Now the first is kept by him who guards the faith given by God in its integrity, who abominates its assailants as enemies of the truth and hates heartily all those who hate the beloved; and the second by him who most highly esteems the care of his neighbour and who, not only in prosperity but also in apparent misfortunes, observes the laws of friendship.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 135:9
verses.text: They, on the other hand, who look after their own safety, as they suppose, who on its account make little of the laws of friendship and take no heed of their friends when assaulted and attacked, are reckoned to belong to the number of the wicked and of them that are without.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 135:10
verses.text: The Lord of all requires better things at the hands of His disciples.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 135:11
verses.text: "Love" He says "your enemies, for if ye love them which love you, what reward have ye? for the sinners and the publicans do this".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 135:12
verses.text: I, however, have not received even such kindness as publicans receive.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 135:13
verses.text: Publicans, do I say? I have not even received the consolation given to murderers and wizards in their dungeons.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 135:14
verses.text: If every one had imitated this cruelty, nothing else would have been left then for me in my life time but to be wasted by want, and, at my death, instead of being committed to a tomb, to be made meat for dogs and wild beasts.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 135:15
verses.text: But I have found support in those who care nought for this present life, but await the enjoyment of everlasting blessings, and these furnish me with manifold consolation.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 135:16
verses.text: But the loving Lord "caused judgment to be heard from heaven; the earth feared and was still, when God arose to judgment".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 135:17
verses.text: But the wicked shall perish.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 135:18
verses.text: The falsehood of the new heresy has been proscribed, and the truth of the divine Gospels is publicly proclaimed.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 135:19
verses.text: I for my part exclaim with the blessed David, "Blessed be the Lord God who only doeth wondrous things, and blessed be His glorious name: and let the whole earth be filled with His glory; amen and amen".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 136:1
verses.text: CXXXV.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 136:2
verses.text: To Bishop Romulus.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 136:3
verses.text: You have reminded me of the ancient story, and remarked how the King of the Syrians, bethinking him of the loving kindness of the kings of Israel, assumed the form of a suppliant and failed not to obtain his petition.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 136:4
verses.text: Remember therefore, sir, the divine wrath.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 136:5
verses.text: God delivered Ahab to utter destruction for using mercy, and delivered his sentence through the mouth of the prophet, saying "Thy life shall go for his life and thy people for his people".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 136:6
verses.text: We are thus commanded to temper mercy with justice, since not every kind of mercy is pleasing to the God of all.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 136:7
verses.text: The present state of affairs specially requires prudent council; for we are contending on behalf of the divine doctrines, wherein we have the hope of our salvation.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 136:8
verses.text: But herein, too, may be seen the great difference between man and man.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 136:9
verses.text: Some men are verily infected with the common impiety; while others, without distinction, advance at one time one doctrine, and at another its opposite.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 136:10
verses.text: Some who know the truth conceal it in the secret chambers of their soul, while they preach impiety with the rest; others again who are filled with envy have made their private ill-will an occasion of waging war against the truth, and wreak all kinds of mischief against the prophets of the truth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 136:11
verses.text: Again, there are who embrace the truth of the apostolic doctrines, and yet because they are afraid of the power of the dominant party are too cowed to proclaim it, and though they lament at the abundance of our misfortunes, nevertheless side with them that set the mighty surge a-rolling.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 136:12
verses.text: It is in this last category that we place your reverence.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 136:13
verses.text: We have believed you to be sound in the divine doctrines, and think that you keep your affection for me, and are borne along with the time for no other reason than your cowardice.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 136:14
verses.text: Under these circumstances though I am not writing to any of the rest, I write to your holiness, and receive your reply.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 136:15
verses.text: I see your drift and to some extent I pardon your pusillanimity.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 136:16
verses.text: But the loving Lord has now removed all occasions of cowardice, by exhibiting the new-fangled impiety, and shewing the plain truth of the gospels.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 136:17
verses.text: I, even though my mouths were as many as my hairs, cannot praise as I ought the loving-kindness of the Lord for compelling my strongest opponents openly to preach what has been preached by me.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 136:18
verses.text: For I have heard that he who shares your holiness's roof, when he heard that anathemas had been published in the great cities, ceased to imitate the crooked gait of crabs, and, after disputing in a certain assembly about doctrines, walked in the straight road.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 136:19
verses.text: Never must we suit our words to the season, but ever preserve the unbending rule of truth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 137:1
verses.text: CXXXVI.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 137:2
verses.text: To Cyrus Magistrianus.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 137:3
verses.text: I was very much distressed to hear of the trouble which had befallen you.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 137:4
verses.text: How indeed could I fail to suffer, making as I do your interest mine, and remembering the apostolic law which bids us not only "rejoice with them that do rejoice, but also weep with them that weep"? Suffering itself is able to draw even those that are at enmity with one another into sympathy.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 137:5
verses.text: What is so grievous as to lose a wife; one who bore blamelessly the yoke of wedlock, one who made her husband's life pleasant, one who shared the care of the family; one who managed the household and shared in the direction of everything; one who was ready to suggest whatever might be likely to be of service, and to comply with the wishes of her husband? But what sorrow could surpass the committal to the tomb of the mother at the same moment as the son whom she bore; a son who had been carefully trained and had received a learned education; one who, you hoped, would be the stay of your old age; buried in the very spring of his manhood, when the down was just beginning to grow upon his cheeks? Did we only look at the character of the calamity, it admits of no consolation.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 137:6
verses.text: But when we bethink us how our race is doomed to die; that against that race the divine fiat has gone forth; that suffering is common, for life is full of such woes; we shall bravely bear what has happened, shall repel the assaults of despair, and shall raise that wonderful song of praise "The Lord gave and the Lord hath taken away; the Lord hath done what seemed to him good; blessed be the name of the Lord".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 137:7
verses.text: But we have many more reasons for consolation.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 137:8
verses.text: We have been distinctly taught the hopes of the resurrection, and we look for the time when the dead shall live again.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 137:9
verses.text: We know how the Lord many times called death sleep.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 137:10
verses.text: If we trust, as in truth we do, the Saviour's words, we are bound not to mourn those that have fallen asleep, even though their sleep lasts somewhat longer than it is wont.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 137:11
verses.text: We must await the resurrection.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 137:12
verses.text: We must remember that the Ruler of the world in His wisdom, and clearly knowing as He does not the present only but the future also, guides events for our good.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 137:13
verses.text: A wise man who knew all this full well reasons about deaths of this kind and says, "Yea; speedily was he taken away, lest that wickedness should alter his understanding".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 137:14
verses.text: Let us submit I beg you to the wise Ruler of all; let us submit to His decrees.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 137:15
verses.text: Whether they be pleasant or whether they be grievous, they are good and profitable, they make men wise; for them that endure they ordain crowns.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 138:1
verses.text: CXXXVII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 138:2
verses.text: To the Archimandrite John.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 138:3
verses.text: The blessed David fell into several errors, which God, who wisely orders all things, has caused to be recorded for the good of them that were to come after.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 138:4
verses.text: But it was not on their account that Absalom, parricide, murderer, impious, and altogether vile, started his wild war against his father.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 138:5
verses.text: The reason of his beginning that most unrighteous struggle was because he coveted the sovereignty.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 138:6
verses.text: The divine David, however, when these events were coming to pass, began to remember the wrong that he had done.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 138:7
verses.text: I too am conscious within myself of the guilt of many errors, but I have kept undefiled the dogmatic teaching of the Apostles.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 138:8
verses.text: And they who have trampled upon all laws human and divine, and condemned me in my absence, have not sentenced me for what I have done wrong, for my secret deeds are not made manifest to them; but they have contrived false witness and calumny against me, or rather in their open attack upon the doctrines of the Apostles have proscribed me for my obedience to them.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 138:9
verses.text: "So the Lord awaked as one out of sleep; He smote His enemies in the hinderparts and put them to a perpetual shame".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 138:10
verses.text: Counterfeit and spurious doctrines He has scattered to the winds, and has provided for the free preaching of those which He has handed down to us in the holy Gospels.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 138:11
verses.text: To me this suffices for complete delight.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 138:12
verses.text: I do not even long for a city in which I have passed all my time in hard work; all I long for is to see the establishment of the truth of the Gospels.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 138:13
verses.text: And now the Lord has satisfied this longing.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 138:14
verses.text: I am therefore very glad and happy, and I sing praises to our generous Lord, and I invite your reverence to rejoice with me, and, with our praises, to put up the earnest prayer that the men who say now one thing and now another and change about to suit the hour, like the chameleons who assume the colour of the leaves, may be strengthened by the loving-kindness of the Lord, established upon the rocks and, of His mercy, made to pay the highest honour to the truth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 139:1
verses.text: CXXXVIII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 139:2
verses.text: To Anatolius the Patrician.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 139:3
verses.text: I have cordially welcomed the rest which has fallen to my lot, and am harvesting its beneficial and pleasant results.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 139:4
verses.text: Our Christ-loving Emperor, after reaping the empire as fruit of his true piety, has offered as first-fruits of his sovereignty to Him that bestowed it, the calm of the storm-tossed churches, the triumph of the invaded faith, the victory of the doctrines of the Gospel.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 139:5
verses.text: To these he has added the righting of the wrong done to me.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 139:6
verses.text: Of a wrong so great and of such a kind who ever heard? What murderer was ever doomed in his absence? What violator of wedlock was ever condemned without a hearing? What burglar, grave-breaker, wizard, church-robber, or doer of any other unlawful deed, was ever prevented, when eager to appeal to the law, and slain when far away by the sentence of his judge? In their cases nothing of the kind was ever known.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 139:7
verses.text: For, by our law, plaintiff and defendant are bidden to stand face to face before the judge, while the judge has to wait for the production of plain truth, and then and not till then, either dismiss the accused as innocent, or punish him as being reached by the indictment.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 139:8
verses.text: In my case the course pursued has been just the opposite.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 139:9
verses.text: The emperor's letter forbade me to approach the far-famed synod, and the most righteous judges condemned me in my absence, not after fair trial, but after extravagant laudation of the documents which were produced to incriminate me.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 139:10
verses.text: Neither the law of God nor shame of man staved the deed of blood.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 139:11
verses.text: Orders were given by the president, flinging the truth to the winds, and courting the power of the hour.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 139:12
verses.text: He was obeyed by men who think as I do, whose doctrines are my doctrines, and who had expressed admiration of me and mine.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 139:13
verses.text: None the less did that day convict some men of treachery; some of cowardice; while to me a ground of confidence was given by my sufferings for the truth's sake.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 139:14
verses.text: And to me our master Christ hath granted the boon "not only of believing on Him but also of suffering for His sake".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 139:15
verses.text: For the greatest of all gifts of grace are sufferings for the Master's sake, and the divine Apostle puts them even before great marvels.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 139:16
verses.text: In these boons I too glory, humble and insignificant as I am, and having no other ground of boasting.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 139:17
verses.text: And I beseech your excellency to offer on behalf of my poor self expressions of thanksgiving to the emperor, lover of Christ, and to the most pious Augusta, dear to God, instructress of the good, for that she has requited our generous Lord with such gifts, and has made her zeal for true religion the foundation and groundwork of her sway.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 139:18
verses.text: Besides this, beg their godly majesties to complete the work that has been so well marked out, and to summon a council, not, like the last, composed of a turbulent rabble, but—kept quite clear of all of these—of men who decide on and highly value divine things, and esteem all human affairs as of less account than the truth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 139:19
verses.text: If their majesties wish to bring about the ancient peace for the churches, and I am sure that they do, beg their pious graces to take part in the proceedings, that their presence may overawe those of a contrary mind and the truth may have none to gainsay her, but may herself by her own unaided powers examine into the position of affairs, and the character of the apostolic doctrines.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 139:20
verses.text: I make this request to your excellency, not because I long to see Cyrus again, for your lordship knows what a solitary town it is, and how I have somehow or other managed to conceal its ugliness by my great expenditure on all kinds of buildings, but to the end that what I preach may be shewn to be in agreement with apostolic doctrines while the inventions of my opponents are counterfeit and base.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 139:21
verses.text: Once let this come to pass, by God's help be it spoken, and I shall pass the remainder of my days in cheerful contentment, wherever the Master may bid me dwell.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 139:22
verses.text: To you who have been brought up in the true religion, and are dowered with the wealth of goodness it is becoming to make this effort, and by your urgent counsel to render yet more zealous our most pious emperor and the Christ-loving Augusta, zealous already as they are to strengthen their glorious empire by laudable and rightful energy.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 140:1
verses.text: CXXXIX.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 140:2
verses.text: To Aspar, Consular and Patrician.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 140:3
verses.text: To the other good deeds of your excellency must be added your having acquainted our pious and most christian emperor, whom God's grace has appointed for the blessing of his subjects, of the enormous wrong done against me, and your having by a righteous edict annulled an edict which was nothing of the kind.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 140:4
verses.text: Supported by divine Providence I have made what they reckoned a punishment a means of good, and I have welcomed my rest with delight; but none the less I have been wrongly and illegally treated, though in no single point guilty of the errors which the enemies of the truth slanderously laid at my door, but yet made to suffer the penalty of the greatest criminals.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 140:5
verses.text: Nay, my fate has been yet harder than theirs.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 140:6
verses.text: I was judged without a trial; I was doomed in my absence; when forbidden by the emperor's orders to go to Ephesus I received the most righteous sentence of my holy judges.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 140:7
verses.text: All this has now been undone by his most serene majesty, through the active interposition of your excellency.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 140:8
verses.text: I, for my part, feeling that I should be wrong to keep silent and not offer you my thanks, have availed myself of this letter, whereby I beseech your excellency to speak in warm terms in my behalf both to the victorious and Christian emperor and to the very godly and pious Augusta.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 140:9
verses.text: On their behalf I implore our good Lord as earnestly as lies in my power to guard their empire in security, and to grant that it may be at once a source of loving protection for their subjects, and of terror to their foes, and establish honourable peace for all.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 140:10
verses.text: May your excellency be induced to petition them completely to put an end to the agitation of the Church, and order the assembling of the council; not, like the last, of men who from their habits of unruliness throw the synod into confusion, but, in peace and quiet, of members instructed in divine things, and in the habit of confirming the apostolic decrees and rejecting what is spurious and at variance with the truth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 140:11
verses.text: And I express this hope to the end that your excellency may reap the good which such a course of conduct is likely to produce.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 141:1
verses.text: CXL.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 141:2
verses.text: To the Master Vincomalus.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 141:3
verses.text: I have been much astonished to learn that your magnificence, though quite unacquainted with me and mine, and knowing only the wrong that had been done me, stood up as my advocate, and left no means untried to undo the results of the conspiracy against me.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 141:4
verses.text: But your excellency will assuredly receive recompense from our bountiful Lord, for He who promised to give a reward for a little water will doubtless give greater recompense to the givers of greater gifts.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 141:5
verses.text: I have indeed endured such sufferings as none, or at least very few, of the ancients have undergone, and this not only from my open foes, but, as I apprehend, from my real friends.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 141:6
verses.text: The former attacked me, the latter betrayed me.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 141:7
verses.text: Who in the world ever heard of such a trial? Who ever commanded a criminal to be tried in his absence after chaining him up at a distance of more than five and thirty stages? What judge has ever been so savage and inhuman as not only to try men, aye but to condemn men the sound of whose voice he has never heard, and this in most savage and inhuman fashion? The Lord has ordered the erring brother, who spurns advice, after a first, second and third admonition, to be treated as "an heathen man and a publican".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 141:8
verses.text: Now these most equitable and righteous judges have not even given to them of the same faith with themselves the treatment which they give to heathen men and publicans.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 141:9
verses.text: These indeed they do see and occasionally converse with, and that with all honour and deference where they appear to be of rank and dignity.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 141:10
verses.text: But they have ordered me to be cut off from home, from water, from everything.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 141:11
verses.text: This is the way in which they have wished to become imitators of our Father in heaven "Who maketh His sun to rise on the evil and on the good and sendeth rain on the just and on the unjust".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 141:12
verses.text: But of these men I will say no more.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 141:13
verses.text: The tribunal of the Lord is at hand where is required not stage pretence but the reality of life.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 141:14
verses.text: Now I beseech your excellency to express my thanks to the emperor, the lover of Christ and victorious, and to the very pious and godly Augusta, for having made true religion the firm root of their pious empire, and to implore their majesties to make the peace of the churches firm by commanding the assembling of a council, not of men of violence who throw the discussion into confusion, but of the lovers of the truth who confirm the apostolic teaching, and repudiate this new fangled and spurious heresy.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 141:15
verses.text: And I pray that of these honourable endeavours you may reap the fruit at the hands of our loving Lord.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 142:1
verses.text: CXLI.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 142:2
verses.text: To Marcellus, Archimandrite of the Acoemetae.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 142:3
verses.text: Bright is made your holiness by your goodly life, exhibiting on earth the image of the conversation of the angels, but it is made still brighter by your zeal for the apostolic faith.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 142:4
verses.text: As keel to boat, as corner-stone to house, so to them that choose to live in piety is the truth of the doctrines of the Gospel.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 142:5
verses.text: For this truth when assailed you have bravely fought, not striving to protect it as though it were weak, but shewing your godly disposition; for the teaching of our Master Christ is gifted with stability and strength, in accordance with the promise of the same Saviour, "that the gates of hell shall not prevail against it".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 142:6
verses.text: It is the loving and bountiful Lord who has thought right that I too should be dishonoured and slain on behalf of this doctrine.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 142:7
verses.text: For truly we have reckoned dishonour honour, and death life.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 142:8
verses.text: We have heard the words of the apostle "For unto us it is given by God not only to believe on Him, but also to suffer for His sake".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 142:9
verses.text: But the Lord arose like the sleeper, and stopped the mouths of them that uttered blasphemy against God and injustice against me.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 142:10
verses.text: But He has made the tongues of the pious pour forth their fountains in their wonted message.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 142:11
verses.text: I, however, am gathering the delightful fruits of rest; as I look at the agitation of the churches I am grieved, but I rejoice and am glad at being freed from cares.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 142:12
verses.text: I have ever been gratified at your admirable piety, but heretofore I have not written, not from any lack of regard for the dictates of charity, but because I have waited for some suitable occasion.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 142:13
verses.text: Just now, having fallen in with the most pious and prudent monks who have been sent by your holiness on other business, I have lost no time in carrying out my wish.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 142:14
verses.text: I salute your godliness.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 142:15
verses.text: I beg you in the first place to support me with your prayers, and further to cheer me by a letter, for by God's grace I have been attacked for the Gospel's sake.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 143:1
verses.text: CXLII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 143:2
verses.text: To the Same.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 143:3
verses.text: I have already addressed your reverence in another letter, and have delivered it to your much respected brethren.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 143:4
verses.text: Now again I address your holiness.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 143:5
verses.text: I am induced to do so both by your admirable life, and by the praiseworthy zeal which you have shewn on behalf of the apostolic faith, fearless alike of imperial power and of episcopal combination.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 143:6
verses.text: For granted that the majority of the council consented under coercion, still they did confirm the new fangled heresy by their signatures.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 143:7
verses.text: Your holiness, however, was shaken by none of these things, but abided by the ancient doctrines which the Lord, by means of both the prophets and the apostles, has taught the churches to hold.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 143:8
verses.text: These decrees I pray that I may preserve, and keep to the end my faith and confession in one Father, one Son and one Holy Ghost.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 143:9
verses.text: For the incarnation of the only begotten made no addition to the number of the Trinity.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 143:10
verses.text: Even after the incarnation the Trinity is still a Trinity.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 143:11
verses.text: This is the teaching I have received from the beginning; this has been my faith; in this was I baptized; this have I preached; in this have I baptized, this I continue to hold.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 143:12
verses.text: Of them that utter a lie about the Father the Lord has said "When he speaketh a lie he speaketh of his own," for what is said of the teacher is appropriate to the disciples.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 143:13
verses.text: So these men who employ lies against me speak of their own, and do not describe what is mine.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 143:14
verses.text: I am comforted by my Master's words "Blessed are ye when men shall revile you and persecute you and shall say all manner of evil against you falsely for my sake.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 143:15
verses.text: Rejoice and be exceeding glad for great is your reward in heaven".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 143:16
verses.text: I entreat your piety to pray that I may not have my part among the wrong doers, but among them that suffer wrong on account of the truth of the Gospels.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 144:1
verses.text: CXLIII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 144:2
verses.text: To Andrew, Monk of Constantinople.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 144:3
verses.text: I have never seen your piety nor have we ever communicated by letter, but I have become warmly attached to you.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 144:4
verses.text: What has wrought the charm and continues to inflame it is the report unanimously brought by the tasters of your honey.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 144:5
verses.text: All express admiration of the orthodoxy of your faith, the brightness of your life, the constancy of your soul, the harmoniousness of your character, the attractiveness and sweetness of your society and all the other characteristics of the true foster child of philosophy.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 144:6
verses.text: For all these reasons I am attached to your godliness, and my longing has made me even begin a correspondence; but, my dear sir, grant me as soon as possible what I desire and let me have written communication from you.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 144:7
verses.text: For when friends are at a distance considerable comfort is given them by epistolary communication.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 144:8
verses.text: You will write to no man of heterodox opinions, but to one nurtured in the teaching of the apostles and preacher not of a quaternity but of a Trinity, for in reality I see little difference in the impiety of those who have the hardihood to endeavour to contract into one the two natures of the Only-begotten and those who endeavour to divide our Lord Jesus Christ, the Son of the living God, God the Word made man, into two sons; if such indeed there be; I cannot think so; but Arians, Eunomians, and Apollinarians too have ever shamelessly fabricated this slander against the Church, and indeed laborious students may easily perceive that our far famed Fathers, lights of the churches, laboured at the hands of the foes of the truth under this accusation which is now levelled against me by the most excellent champions of the new fangled heresy.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 144:9
verses.text: Our wise Lord has laid bare their impiety, for He could not endure to confirm the unholy heresy by His long suffering.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 144:10
verses.text: Be sure then, sir, that you will be writing to one of like sentiments with your own; and of this you can easily assure yourself from my copious writings.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 144:11
verses.text: Write then to me in return, and again your letter, by God's leave, shall serve to kindle affection.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 144:12
verses.text: And before you write, give me the help of your prayers, and beseech our good Lord to guide my feet into the right road, that I may travel the rest of my journey in accordance with His laws.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 144:13
verses.text: You who have won right of access from your unstained life will easily persuade Him Who is eager to give us His good gifts.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 145:1
verses.text: CXLIV.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 145:2
verses.text: To the Soldiers.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 145:3
verses.text: Human nature is everywhere the same, but pursuits in life are many and various.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 145:4
verses.text: Some men prefer a sailor's career, some a soldier's; some men become athletes, some husbandmen; some ply one craft and some another.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 145:5
verses.text: To pass by all other differences, some men are zealous and diligent about divine things, and get themselves instructed in the exact teaching of the apostolic doctrines; while others, on the contrary, become slaves of the belly, and suppose that the enjoyment of base pleasures is happiness.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 145:6
verses.text: Others again are there, lying in a mean between these two extremes, who do not exhibit this praiseworthy enthusiasm, nor embrace a life of incontinence, but still honour the simplicity of the faith.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 145:7
verses.text: Men who attack the statement that some things are altogether impossible with God must not, I apprehend, be classed with the zealous and the well instructed in divine things, but rather either with those who have no exact knowledge of the apostolic doctrines, or those who have been enslaved by pleasures and shift hither and thither at the caprice of a moment, setting forth now one thing and now another.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 145:8
verses.text: You have asked me to write on these points.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 145:9
verses.text: I should prefer at the present time to keep silence.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 145:10
verses.text: But in obedience to the commandment of the Lord, "Give to every man that asketh of thee," I am constrained briefly to reply.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 145:11
verses.text: I say then that the God of the universe can do all things, but that in the word "all" is comprehended only what is right and good, for He who is naturally both wise and good admits of nothing that is of a contrary nature, but only what becomes his nature.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 145:12
verses.text: If any objectors gainsay this statement, ask them if the God of the universe, the lawgiver of truth, can lie.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 145:13
verses.text: If they say that lying is possible to God, expel them from your company as impious and blasphemous.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 145:14
verses.text: Should they agree that lying is not possible to the God of the universe, ask them in the second place, if He who is the fount of justice can become unjust.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 145:15
verses.text: Should they allow that this too is impossible to the God of all, you must yet again enquire if the unfathomable depth of wisdom can become unwise, God cease to be God, the Lord cease to be the Lord, the Creator be no Creator, the Good not good but evil and the true Light not light but its opposite.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 145:16
verses.text: If they admit that all these things and the like are impossible to God, you must say to them therefore many things are impossible with God; and that their being impossible so far from being a proof of want of power, indicates on the contrary the greatest power.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 145:17
verses.text: Even in the case of our own soul, when we say that it cannot die, we do not predicate weakness of it, but we proclaim its capacity of immortality.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 145:18
verses.text: And similarly when we confess the immutability, impassibility, and immortality of God, we cannot attribute to the divine nature change, passion, or death.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 145:19
verses.text: Suppose them to urge that God can do whatever He will, you must reply to them that He wishes to do nothing which it is not His nature to do; He is by nature good, therefore He does not wish anything evil; He is by nature just, therefore He does not wish anything unjust; He is by nature true, therefore He abominates falsehood; He is by nature immutable, therefore He does not admit of change; and if He does not admit of change He is always in the same state and condition.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 145:20
verses.text: This He Himself asserts through the prophet.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 145:21
verses.text: "I am the Lord I change not".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 145:22
verses.text: And the blessed David says "Thou art the same and Thy years shall have no end".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 145:23
verses.text: If He is the same He undergoes no change.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 145:24
verses.text: If He is naturally superior to change and mutation He has not become from immortal, mortal nor from impassible, passible, for had this been possible He would not have taken on Him our nature.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 145:25
verses.text: But since He has an immortal nature, He took a body capable of suffering, and with the body a human soul.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 145:26
verses.text: Both of these He kept unstained from the defilements of sin, and gave His soul for the sake of the souls that had sinned, and His body for the sake of the bodies that had died.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 145:27
verses.text: And since the body that was assumed is described as body of the very only begotten Son of God, He refers the passion of the body to Himself.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 145:28
verses.text: But the four evangelists testify that it was not the divine nature but the body which was nailed to the cross, all teaching with one voice that Joseph of Arimathea came to Pilate and begged the body of Jesus; that he took down the body of Jesus from the tree and wrapped in fine linen, and laid in his own new tomb the body of Jesus; that Mary the Magdalene came to the tomb seeking the body of Jesus and ran to His disciples, and reported these things when she could not find the body of Jesus.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 145:29
verses.text: This is the unanimous teaching of the evangelists.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 145:30
verses.text: But if your opponents urge that the angels said "Come see the place where the Lord lay" let the foolish folk learn that the divine Scripture says also about the victorious Stephen "And devout men carried Stephen to his burial".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 145:31
verses.text: And yet it was the body only which was deemed proper for burial, while the soul was not buried together with the body; nevertheless the body alone was spoken of by the common name.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 145:32
verses.text: Similarly the blessed Jacob said to his sons "Bury me with my fathers".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 145:33
verses.text: He did not say "Bury my body".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 145:34
verses.text: Then he went on "There they buried Abraham and Sarah his wife; there they buried Isaac and Rebekah his wife; and there I buried Leah".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 145:35
verses.text: He did not say "their bodies".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 145:36
verses.text: The names are common to bodies or souls, but nevertheless it is only the bodies which he called by the common names.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 145:37
verses.text: In this manner too we constantly describe the shrines of the holy apostles, prophets and martyrs, one it may be of Dionysius, another of Julianus another of Cosmas.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 145:38
verses.text: And yet we know that only fragmentary remains of bodies lie there, while the souls in diviner regions are at rest.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 145:39
verses.text: Precisely the same custom is to be found in common use, for such an one, we say, died; and such an one lies in this place; although we know that the soul is immortal and does not share the tomb with the body.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 145:40
verses.text: In this sense the angel said "Come see the place where the Lord lay" not because he shut the Godhead in the tomb, but because he spoke of the Lord's body by the Lord's name.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 145:41
verses.text: In proof of this being the view of the holy Fathers let them mark the words of Athanasius, illustrious archbishop of Alexandria, who adorned his episcopate with confession.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 145:42
verses.text: He exclaims "Life cannot die, but rather quickens the dead".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 145:43
verses.text: Let them hear too the words of the far-famed Damasus bishop of Rome, "If anyone allege that on the cross pain was undergone by the Godhead and not by the body with the soul, the form of the servant which He had taken in its completeness, let him be anathema".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 145:44
verses.text: Let them hear too the very sacred and holy bishop of the Church of the Romans, the lord Leo, who has now written "The Son of God suffered as He was capable of suffering, not according to the nature which assumed but that which was assumed.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 145:45
verses.text: For the impassible nature assumed the passible body, and gave it for us, to the end that He might work out our salvation and at the same time preserve His own nature impassible".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 145:46
verses.text: And again "For He did not come to destroy His own nature but to save ours".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 145:47
verses.text: If therefore they accuse us for saying that God can do what He wishes, but that He wishes what is becoming to His own nature, and what is unbecoming He neither wishes nor is capable of; let them accuse too these saints and all the rest who maintain this position.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 145:48
verses.text: Let them accuse even the Apostle who says "That by two immutable things in which it was impossible for God to lie".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 145:49
verses.text: And again "If we believe not, yet He abideth faithful: He cannot deny Himself".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 145:50
verses.text: Repeat these passages to your opponents, and if they are convinced, praise the good Lord for that, by means of your zeal, He has benefited them.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 145:51
verses.text: If they remain unconvinced, enter into no discussion with them about doctrines, for it is forbidden by the divine apostle to "strive about words to no profit but to the subverting of the hearers".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 145:52
verses.text: But do you keep inviolate the teaching of the Gospels, that in the day of His appearing you may bring to the righteous Judge what has been entrusted to you with its due interest, and may hear the longed for words "Well done good and faithful servant; thou hast been faithful over a few things I will make thee ruler over many things.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 145:53
verses.text: Enter thou into the joy of thy Lord".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:1
verses.text: CXLV.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:2
verses.text: To the Monks of Constantinople.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:3
verses.text: There is nothing new or surprising in the fact that the men who have made their tongues weapons against our God and Saviour should also aim their shafts of falsehood against His right minded servants.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:4
verses.text: It must needs be that the servants who grieve sorely at the outrage inflicted on their Master should share it.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:5
verses.text: That so it should be they have been forwarned by their Lord Himself, Who consoles His holy disciples with the words "If they have persecuted me they will also persecute you".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:6
verses.text: "If they have called the Master of the house Beelzebub, how much more shall they call them of His household".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:7
verses.text: Then He cheered them by pointing out that calumny is easily detected, for He went on "There is nothing covered that shall not be revealed and hid that shall not be known".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:8
verses.text: I have often seen the truth of the divine prediction, but I see it with special clearness now.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:9
verses.text: The authors of the calumny against me, who have bought my destruction for large sums of money, have been distinctly seen to be involved in the unsoundness of Valentinus and Bardesanes.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:10
verses.text: They had hoped to cloke their own iniquity if only they could whet their tongues on the hone of falsehood in order to wound me.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:11
verses.text: For ever since I saw that the heresy long ago extinguished had been renewed by these men I never ceased to cry aloud, bearing my testimony in private and in public, as well in social gatherings as in the temples of God, and strive to confute their conspiracy against the faith.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:12
verses.text: They have consequently poured out their insults on my head, and allege that I preach two sons.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:13
verses.text: But they ought to have convicted me to my face, not slandered me behind my back.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:14
verses.text: They have done just the contrary.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:15
verses.text: They tied me hand and foot at Cyrus by the imperial decree; they compelled the very righteous judges to condemn me without a trial, and delivered their most equitable sentence against a man who was five and thirty stages away.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:16
verses.text: Such treatment was never suffered by any criminal charged with witchcraft or robbery of the dead, by murderer or by adulterer.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:17
verses.text: But for the present I will leave the judges alone, for the Lord is at hand "Who judges the world with righteousness and the people with his truth;" Who exacts an account not only of words and deeds, but even of evil thoughts.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:18
verses.text: But think it right to refute the false charge which has been made.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:19
verses.text: What proof have they of my asserting two sons? Had I been one of the silent kind there might have been some ground for the suspicion, but my task has been to contend on behalf of the apostolic decrees, to bring the pasture of instruction to the Lord's flocks, and to this end I have written five and thirty books interpreting the divine Scripture, and proving the falsehood of the heresies.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:20
verses.text: The falsehoods these men have concocted are therefore easy of refutation.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:21
verses.text: Tens on tens of thousands of hearers testify that I have taught the truth of the doctrines of the Gospel, and for any one who likes to bring them to the test my writings lie before the world.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:22
verses.text: Not on behalf of a duality of sons, but of the only begotten Son of God, against the heathen, against Jews, against the recipients of the plague of Arius and Eunomius, against the supporters of the madness of Apollinarius, against the victims of the corruption of Marcion, I have never ceased to struggle; trying to convince the heathen that the Eternal Son of the ever living God is Himself Creator of the Universe; the Jews that about Him the prophets uttered their predictions, the Arians and Eunomians that He is of one substance, of one dignity and of equal power with the Father; Marcion's mad adherents that He is not only good but just; and Saviour not, as they fable, of another's works, but of His own.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:23
verses.text: Once for all, fighting against each heresy, I charge men to fall down and worship the one Son.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:24
verses.text: And what need is there of many words, when it is possible to refute falsehood in few? We provide that those who year by year come up for holy baptism should carefully learn the faith set forth at Nicaea by the holy and blessed Fathers; and initiating them as we have been bidden, we baptize them in the name of the Father and of the Son and of the Holy Ghost, pronouncing each name singly.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:25
verses.text: Furthermore when performing divine service in the churches, both at the beginning and the decline of day and when dividing the day itself into three parts, we glorify the Father the Son and the Holy Ghost.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:26
verses.text: If, as our slanderers allege, we preach two sons, which do we glorify and which do we leave unworshipped? It were the wildest folly to believe that there are two sons, and to give the doxology to one alone.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:27
verses.text: And who is so distraught as, while hearing the words of the divine Paul "one Lord, one faith, one baptism," and again "there is one Lord Jesus Christ by Whom are all things," to lay down the law at variance with the teaching of the Spirit, and cut the one in two.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:28
verses.text: But I am prating unnecessarily, for these men, nurtured in falsehood as they are, do not even dare to assert that they have ever heard me say anything of the kind; but they affirm that I preach two sons because I confess the two natures of our Master Christ.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:29
verses.text: And they refuse to perceive that every human being has both an immortal soul and a mortal body; yet no one has hitherto been found to call Paul two Pauls because he has both soul and body, any more than Peter two Peters or Abraham or Adam.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:30
verses.text: Everyone recognises the distinction of the natures, and does not call one man two Pauls.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:31
verses.text: Precisely in the same way, when styling our Lord Jesus Christ the only begotten Son of God, God the Word incarnate, both Son of God and Son of Man, as we have been taught by the divine Scripture, we do not assert two sons, but we do confess the peculiar properties of the Godhead and of the manhood.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:32
verses.text: The party however who deny the nature assumed of us men cannot hear these arguments without irritation.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:33
verses.text: It is only right that I should point out from what sources they have derived this impiety.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:34
verses.text: Simon, Menander, Cerdo, and Marcion absolutely deny the incarnation, and call the birth from a Virgin fable.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:35
verses.text: Valentinus, however, Basilides, Bardesanes, and Harmonius and their following, accept the conception of the Virgin and the birth; but they deny that God the Word took anything from the Virgin, but made as it were a transit through her as through a conduit, and appeared to mankind in semblance only, and seeming to be a man, in like manner as He was seen by Abraham and certain others of the ancients.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:36
verses.text: Arius and Eunomius on the contrary held that He assumed a body, but that the Godhead played the part of the soul, in order that they may attribute to it what was lowly in His words and deeds.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:37
verses.text: Apollinarius did indeed assert that He assumed a soul with the body, not the reasonable soul, but the soul which is called animal or phytic.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:38
verses.text: Their contention is that the Godhead took the part of the mind.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:39
verses.text: He had learnt the distinction of soul and of mind from the philosophers that are without while divine Scripture says that man consists of soul and body.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:40
verses.text: For we read "And the Lord God formed man of the dust of the ground and breathed into his nostrils the breath of life and man became a living soul".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:41
verses.text: And the Lord in the sacred Gospels said to His apostles "Fear not them which kill the body but are not able to kill the soul".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:42
verses.text: So great is the divergence between the doctrines.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:43
verses.text: These men have now done their best to outdo Apollinarius, Arius and Eunomius, in their impiety and have now endeavoured to plant anew the heresy sown of old by Valentinus and Bardesanes, and afterwards uprooted by most excellent husbandmen.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:44
verses.text: Like Valentinus and Bardesanes they have denied that the body of our Lord was assumed of our nature.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:45
verses.text: But the Church, following the footprints of the Apostles, contemplates in the Lord Christ both perfect Godhead and perfect manhood.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:46
verses.text: For just as He took a body, not that He needed a body, but by its means to give immortality to all bodies; so too He took a soul, the guide of the body, that every soul by its means might share His immutability.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:47
verses.text: For even if souls are immortal, they are not however immutable; for they undergo many and frequent changes, as they experience pleasure, now from one object, and now from another.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:48
verses.text: Whence it cometh about that we err when we are changed and are inclined to what is worse.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:49
verses.text: But after the resurrection our bodies enjoy immortality and incorruptibility, and our souls impassibility and immutability.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:50
verses.text: For this reason the only begotten Son of God took both a body and a soul, preserved them free from all blame, and offered the sacrifice for the race.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:51
verses.text: And this is why He is called our high priest; and He is named high priest not as God but as man.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:52
verses.text: He makes the offering as man, and accepts the sacrifice with the Father and the Holy Spirit as God.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:53
verses.text: If only Adam's body had sinned, it alone should have benefited by the cure.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:54
verses.text: But since the soul not only shared in the sin but was first in the sin, for first the thought forms an image of the sin and then carries it out by means of the body, it was just, I ween, that the soul too should be healed.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:55
verses.text: But it is perhaps superfluous to demonstrate these points by reasoning, when the divine Scripture clearly proclaims them.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:56
verses.text: This doctrine is distinctly taught by the holy David and the very divine Peter, the one foretelling from distant ages, and the other interpreting his prediction.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:57
verses.text: The words of the first of the apostles are "David therefore being a prophet, and knowing that God had sworn with an oath to him, that of the fruit of his loins, according to the flesh, He would raise up Christ to sit on his throne; he seeing this before spake of the resurrection of Christ that His soul was not left in hell neither His flesh did see corruption".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:58
verses.text: Now he has given us much instruction on the same point in these few words.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:59
verses.text: First he states that the assumed nature derives its descent from the loins of David; secondly that He took not a body only, but also an immortal soul, and thirdly that He delivered body and soul to death, and, after taking them again, raised them as He would.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:60
verses.text: His own words are "Destroy this temple and in three days I will raise it up".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:61
verses.text: But we have learnt that the divine nature is immortal.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:62
verses.text: What suffered was the passible, and the impassible remained impassible.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:63
verses.text: For God the Word was made man not to render the impassible nature passible, but on the passible nature, by means of the Passion, to bestow the boon of impassibility.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:64
verses.text: And the Lord Himself in the holy Gospels at one time says "I have power to lay down my life and I have power to take it again, no man taketh it from me but I lay it down of myself;" "That I may take it again".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:65
verses.text: And again "Therefore doth my Father love me because I lay down my life for the sheep," and again "Now is my soul troubled" "my soul is exceeding sorrowful even unto death" and of His body He says "The bread that I will give is my flesh which I will give for the life of the world," and when He delivered the divine mysteries and broke the symbol and distributed it, He added "This is my body which is being broken for you for the remission of sins," and again "This is my blood which is shed for many for the remission of sins," and again "Except ye eat the flesh of the Son of Man and drink His blood ye have no life in you" and "Whosoever eateth my flesh and drinketh my blood hath eternal life" "in himself" he adds.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:66
verses.text: Innumerable passages of the same character may be quoted, both in the old Testament and the new, pointing out the assumption both of the body and of the soul, and that they are descended from Abraham and David.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:67
verses.text: Joseph of Arimathea when he came to Pilate begged the body of Jesus, and the fourfold authority of the holy Gospels tells us how he received the body, wrapped it in the linen cloth, and committed it to the tomb.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:68
verses.text: I do, indeed, sorrow and lament that I am compelled by the attacks of error to adduce against men supposed to be of one and the same faith with myself the arguments which I have already urged against the victims of the plague of Marcion,—of whom, by God's grace, I have converted more than ten thousand, and brought them to Holy Baptism.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:69
verses.text: What child of the church ever had any doubts on these points? Who has not cited this teaching of the holy Fathers? The works of the great Basil are full of it; as well, as those of his fellow soldiers Gregory and Amphilochius, and of those who in the West have been illustrious teachers of grace, Damasus, bishop of great Rome, and Ambrose of Milan; and Cyprian of Carthage who for the sake of these doctrines won the martyr's crown.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:70
verses.text: Five times was the famous Athanasius driven from his flock and compelled to dwell in exile; and in the cause of these doctrines strove too his master Alexander.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:71
verses.text: Eustathius, Meletius, and Flavianus, luminaries of the East, and Ephraim, harp of the Spirit, who daily waters the people of Syria with the streams of grace; John and Atticus, loud heralds of the truth; and men of an earlier age than they, Ignatius, Polycarp, Irenaeus, Justin, and Hippolytus, of whom the more part not only shine at the head of the company of bishops, but also adorn the martyr's band.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:72
verses.text: He, too, who now rules great Rome and diffuses in all directions from the West the rays of right teaching, the most holy Leo, has expressed to me this distinctive mark of the faith in his own letters.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:73
verses.text: All these have clearly taught that the only begotten Son of God and everlasting God, ineffably begotten of the Father, is one Son; and that after the incarnation He was called both Son of man and man, not because He was changed into manhood, for His nature is immutable, but because He took what was ours.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:74
verses.text: They teach too that He was both impassible and immortal as God, and mortal and passible as man; but after the resurrection even in relation to His humanity He received impassibility and immortality, for, though the body remained a body, still it is impassible and immortal, verily a divine body and glorified with divine glory.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:75
verses.text: This is distinctly told us by the blessed Paul in the words "For our conversation is in heaven from whence also we look for the Saviour, our Lord Jesus Christ, who shall change our vile body that it may be fashioned like unto the body of His glory".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:76
verses.text: He does not say to "His glory" but to "the body of His glory," and the Lord Himself, when He had said to His apostles "There be some standing here which shall not taste of death till they see the Son of man coming in His Father's glory," took them after six days into an exceeding high mountain, and was transfigured before them, and His face became as the sun, and His raiment was bright like the light.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:77
verses.text: By these means He shewed the manner of the second advent.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:78
verses.text: He taught that the assumed nature is not uncircumscribed (for this is characteristic of the Godhead alone) but that it shall send forth flashes of the divine glory, and emit rays of light transcending the powers of the sense of sight.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:79
verses.text: With this glory He was taken up; with this the angels said that He should come; for their words were "He who was taken from you into heaven shall so come in like manner as ye have seen him go into heaven".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:80
verses.text: When moreover He was seen by the divine apostles after the resurrection, He shewed them both hands and feet; and to Thomas He shewed also His side and the wounds of the nails and of the spear.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:81
verses.text: For on account of those men who positively deny the assumption of the flesh, and further of those others who assert that after the resurrection the nature of the body was changed into the nature of Godhead, He preserved unaltered the prints of the nails and of the spear.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:82
verses.text: And while raising all other bodies free from every disfigurement, in His own body He left the marks of His sufferings, to the end that deniers of the assumption of the body may be convicted of their error by means of His sufferings; and holders of the notion that His body was changed into another nature may be taught by the print of the nails that it abides in its own proper qualities.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:83
verses.text: Suppose any one to imagine that he has a proof that the body of the Lord did not remain a body after the resurrection in the fact that He came in to the disciples when the doors were shut, let such an one remember how He walked upon the sea while His body was still mortal, how He was born after keeping the seals of virginity intact, and how again when encircled by them that were plotting against Him He frequently escaped from their hands.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:84
verses.text: But why need I mention the Lord, who was not only man, but God before the ages, and to whom it was easy to do whatsoever He would? Let them tell how Habakkuk was translated from Judaea into Babylon in a moment of time and passed through the covering of the den, and brought the food to Daniel, and returned again.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:85
verses.text: without destroying the seals of the den.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:86
verses.text: It is sheer foolishness to enquire into the manner of the miracles of the Lord, but in addition to what has been said it ought also to be known that after the resurrection our bodies also will be incorruptible and immortal, and being released from what is earthly will become light and aethereal.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:87
verses.text: This moreover is distinctly taught us by the divine Paul in the words "It is sown in corruption, it is raised in incorruption, it is sown in weakness, it is raised in power; it is sown in dishonour it is raised in glory; it is sown a natural body, it is raised a spiritual body" and in another place "We shall be caught up in the clouds to meet the Lord in the air".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:88
verses.text: If then the bodies of the saints become light and aethereal and easily travel through the air, we cannot wonder that the Lord's body united to the Godhead of the only begotten, when, after the resurrection, it had become immortal, entered in when the doors were shut.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:89
verses.text: Countless other proofs might be quoted without difficulty from apostles and prophets.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:90
verses.text: But what has been already said is enough to show the drift of my teaching.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:91
verses.text: I believe in one Father, one Son and one Holy Ghost; and I confess one Godhead, one Lordship, one substance and three hypostases.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:92
verses.text: For the incarnation of the only begotten did not add to the number of the Trinity, and make the Trinity a quaternity, but, even after the incarnation the Trinity was still a Trinity.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:93
verses.text: And while confessing that the only begotten Son of God was made man I do not deny the nature which He took, but confess, as I have said, both the nature which took and the nature which was taken.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:94
verses.text: The union did not confound the properties of the natures.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:95
verses.text: For if the air by receiving the light through all its parts does not cease to be air, nor yet at the same time destroy the nature of the light, for with our eyes we behold the light and by our feeling we recognise the air, as it meets us cold or hot, or moist or dry, so it were sheer folly to call the union of the Godhead and the manhood confusion.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:96
verses.text: If created natures which share at once subordinate and temporal existence, when united and in some sense mingled, yet remain unimpaired, and, when the light withdraws, the nature of the air is left alone, much more proper is it, I apprehend, for the nature which fashioned all things, when conjoined with and united to the nature which it assumed from us, to be acknowledged to continue itself in its purity, and in like manner to preserve unimpaired that which it had assumed.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:97
verses.text: Gold, too, when brought in contact with the fire, participates both in the colour and power of fire, but it does not lose its own nature, but at the same time remains gold and has the active qualities of fire.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:98
verses.text: In this manner also the Lord's body is a body, but impassible, incorruptible, immortal, of the Lord, divine and glorified with the divine glory.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:99
verses.text: It is not separated from the Godhead, nor yet is of any one else, save of the only begotten Son of God Himself.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:100
verses.text: For it does not show to us another person, but the only-begotten Himself clad in our nature.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:101
verses.text: This is the doctrine which I am continually preaching.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:102
verses.text: They on the other hand who deny the incarnation wrought on our behalf have called me a heretic, adopting a course something like that of unchaste females, who, while they sell their own charms, assail honest women with the insults of their profession, and apply language proper to their own wantonness to women who hold such wantonness in abhorrence.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:103
verses.text: This is how Egypt has acted.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:104
verses.text: She has herself fallen willingly into the thraldom of base desire.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:105
verses.text: She has lavished her servile adulation on a man of chaste character.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:106
verses.text: Then, failing to entice him by her wiles, or to trap him in the snares of her voluptuous passion, she describes one who is faithful to purity as an adulterer.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:107
verses.text: But these men will be called to account by God, as well for their devices against the faith as for the snares they have laid against me.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:108
verses.text: I only charge those who have been influenced by the false accusations uttered against me to keep one ear for the accused, and not to give both to the accusers.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:109
verses.text: In this manner they will fulfil the divine law which lays down "Thou shalt not raise a false report," and "Judge righteously between every man and his brother".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 146:110
verses.text: In these words the divine law charges us not to believe the calumnies uttered against the absent but to judge the accused face to face.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:1
verses.text: CXLVI.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:2
verses.text: To John the oeconomus.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:3
verses.text: Rest and a life free from care are very grateful to me.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:4
verses.text: I have therefore blocked the door of the monastery, and decline intercourse with my friends.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:5
verses.text: But I have received information that fresh attacks are being made against the Faith of the Gospels, and therefore conclude that there may be danger in my silence.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:6
verses.text: When wrong has been done some mortal prince, not only the guilty authors of the outrage but they also who have been standing by and made no effort to drive off the assailants, are in peril of punishment: What penalty then ought not to be undergone by men who can venture to look lightly on the utterance of blasphemy against our God and Saviour? This is the fear which has impelled me now to write and expose the innovations of which I have been informed.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:7
verses.text: It is said that a common report in the city represents that after certain presbyters had offered prayer, and concluded it in the wonted manner, while some said "For to Thee belongs glory and to thy Christ and to the Holy Ghost;" and others "Through grace and loving kindness of thy Christ, with whom belongs glory to Thee with thy holy Spirit," the very wise archdeacon prohibited the use of the expression, "the Christ" and said that the "only begotten" ought to be glorified.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:8
verses.text: If this is true it were impossible to exceed the impiety.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:9
verses.text: For he either divides the one Lord Jesus Christ into two sons and regards the only begotten Son as lawful and natural, but the Christ as adopted and spurious, and consequently unmeet for being honoured in doxology; or else he is endeavouring to support the heresy which has now burst in on us with the riot of wild revelry.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:10
verses.text: Had a grievous tempest been now oppressing us, any one might have supposed that the blasphemer suited his blasphemy to the necessity of the moment, through fear of the power of the originators of the heresy.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:11
verses.text: But now that He who is blasphemed has rebuked the winds and the sea, and blessed the storm-tossed churches with a calm, while everywhere by land and sea the proclamation of the apostles is preached, what room is there for the blasphemy? While not even they who have lately basely inserted among the doctrines of the Church that flesh and godhead are of one and the same nature have ever forbidden the offering of praise to the Lord Christ.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:12
verses.text: This fact may be easily ascertained from those who have returned thence.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:13
