verses.text: A man holding the foremost place in the ecclesiastical rank ought to have known the divine Scripture, and to have learnt from it that just as the heralds of the truth rank the only begotten Son with the Father, so accordingly using the title of "the Christ" instead of that of "Son" they number Him sometimes with the Father and sometimes with the Holy Ghost; for the Christ is none other than the only begotten Son of God.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:14
verses.text: So we may quote the divine Paul writing to the Corinthians, but teaching the world, that "There is one God the Father of whom are all things…and one Lord Jesus Christ by whom are all things".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:15
verses.text: Thus he calls the same person, Christ, Jesus, Lord, and Creator of all things.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:16
verses.text: And writing to the Thessalonians he says "Now God Himself and our Father and our Lord Jesus Christ direct our way unto you".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:17
verses.text: And in his second epistle to the same he puts the Christ before the Father, not to invert the order, but to teach that the order of the names does not indicate a distinction of dignity and nature.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:18
verses.text: His words are "Now our Lord Jesus Christ Himself, and God, even our Father, which hath loved us, and hath given us everlasting consolation and good hope through grace, comfort your hearts, and stablish you in every good word and work".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:19
verses.text: And at the end of his Epistle to the Romans after certain exhortations he adds "I beseech you brethren for the Lord Jesus Christ's sake and for the love of the spirit".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:20
verses.text: Now if he had known the Christ as being any other than the Son he would not have put Him before the Holy Ghost.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:21
verses.text: Writing to the Corinthians, at the very beginning of his letter, he mentions the name of Christ as alone sufficient to influence the faithful.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:22
verses.text: "Now I beseech you brethren by the name of our Lord Jesus Christ that ye all speak the same thing" and when writing to them a second time he thus concludes "The peace of our Lord Jesus Christ and the love of God the Father and the communion of the Holy Ghost be with you all".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:23
verses.text: Here he puts the name of Christ not only before the Spirit, but also before the Father and this in all the churches is the beginning of the Liturgy of the Mystery.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:24
verses.text: According, then, to this extraordinary regulation the august name of our God and Saviour, Jesus Christ, ought to be omitted from the mystic writings.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:25
verses.text: But it is unnecessary to say more on this point.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:26
verses.text: The opening of every one of his letters is distinguished by the divine Apostle with this address.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:27
verses.text: At one time it is "Paul a servant of Jesus Christ called to be an apostle".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:28
verses.text: At another "Paul called to be an apostle of Jesus Christ".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:29
verses.text: At another "Paul a servant of God and an apostle of Jesus Christ".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:30
verses.text: And suiting his benediction to his exordium he deduces it from the same source and links the title of the Son with God the Father, saying "Grace to you and peace from God our Father and the Lord Jesus Christ".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:31
verses.text: And he graces the conclusion of his letters with the blessing "The grace of our Lord Jesus Christ be with you all, amen".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:32
verses.text: Copious additional evidence may be found whereby it may be learnt without difficulty that our Lord Jesus Christ is no other person than the Son which completes the Trinity.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:33
verses.text: For the same before the ages was only begotten Son and God the Word, and after the resurrection He was called Jesus and Christ, receiving the names from the facts.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:34
verses.text: Jesus means Saviour; "Thou shalt call His name Jesus for He shall save His people from their sins".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:35
verses.text: He is named Christ from being as man anointed with the Holy Ghost, and called our High Priest, Apostle, Prophet and King.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:36
verses.text: Long ago the divine Moses exclaimed "The Lord thy God will raise up unto thee a prophet, from the midst of thee, of thy brethren, like unto me".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:37
verses.text: And the divine David cries "The Lord hath sworn and will not repent, Thou art a priest forever after the order of Melchisedek".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:38
verses.text: This prophecy is confirmed by the divine Apostle.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:39
verses.text: And again "seeing then that we have a great High Priest that has passed into the heavens, Jesus the Son of God, let us hold fast our profession".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:40
verses.text: That as God, He is king before the ages that prophetic minstrelsy teaches us in the words "Thy throne, O God, is for ever and ever; the sceptre of Thy kingdom is a right sceptre".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:41
verses.text: His majesty as man is also shown us.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:42
verses.text: For having the sovereignty of all things as God and Creator, He assumes this majesty as man, wherefore it is added "Thou lovest righteousness and hatest wickedness, therefore God thy God hath anointed thee with the oil of gladness above thy fellows".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:43
verses.text: And in the second psalm the anointed one himself says "Yet was I set as king by Him upon the holy hill of Sion, I will declare the decree of the Lord.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:44
verses.text: The Lord hath said unto me 'Thou art my Son this day have I begotten Thee; ask of me and I shall give Thee the heathen for thine inheritance and the uttermost parts of the earth for thy possession.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:45
verses.text: '" This He said as man, for as man He receives what as God He possesses.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:46
verses.text: And at the very beginning of the psalm the gift of prophecy ranks Him with God the Father in the words "Why do the heathen rage and the people imagine a vain thing.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:47
verses.text: The kings of the earth set themselves and the rulers take counsel together against the Lord and against His anointed".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:48
verses.text: Let no one then foolishly suppose that the Christ is any other than the only begotten Son.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:49
verses.text: Let us not imagine ourselves wiser than the gift of the Spirit.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:50
verses.text: Let us hear the words of the great Peter, "Thou art the Christ, the Son of the living God".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:51
verses.text: Let us hear the Lord Christ confirming this confession, for "On this rock," He says, "I will build my church and the gates of Hell shall not prevail against it".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:52
verses.text: Wherefore too the wise Paul, most excellent master builder of the churches, fixed no other foundation than this.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:53
verses.text: "I," he says, "as a wise master builder have laid the foundation, and another buildeth thereon.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:54
verses.text: But let every man take heed how he buildeth thereon.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:55
verses.text: For other foundation can no man lay than that is laid, which is Jesus Christ".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:56
verses.text: How then can they think of any other foundation, when they are bidden not to fix a foundation, but to build on that which is laid? The divine writer recognises Christ as the foundation, and glories in this title, as when he says, "I am crucified with Christ: nevertheless I live; yet not I but Christ liveth in me".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:57
verses.text: And again "To me to live is Christ and to die is gain," and again "For I determined not to know anything among you save Jesus Christ and Him crucified".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:58
verses.text: And a little before he says, "But we preach Christ crucified to the Jews a stumbling-block and to the Greeks foolishness, but unto them which are called both Jews and Greeks, Christ the power of God and the wisdom of God".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:59
verses.text: And in his Epistle to the Galatians he writes, "But when it pleased God who separated me from my mother's womb and called me by His grace to reveal His Son in me that I might preach Him among the heathen".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:60
verses.text: But when writing to the Corinthians he does not say we preach "the Son" but "Christ crucified," herein doing no violence to his commission, but recognising the same to be Jesus, Christ, Lord, only begotten, and God the Word.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:61
verses.text: For the same reason too at the beginning of his letter to the Romans he calls himself "servant of Jesus Christ" and describes himself as "separated unto the gospel of God, which He had promised afore by His prophets in the Holy Scriptures, concerning His Son Jesus Christ our Lord, which was made of the seed of David according to the flesh; and declared to be the Son of God with power" and so on.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:62
verses.text: He calls the same both Jesus Christ, and Son of David, and Son of God, as God and Lord of all, and yet in the middle of his epistle, after making mention of the Jews, he adds, "whose are the fathers, and of whom as concerning the flesh Christ came, who is over all God blessed for ever, amen".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:63
verses.text: Here he says that He who according to the flesh derived His descent from the Jews is eternal God and is praised by the right minded as Lord of all created things.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:64
verses.text: The same teaching is given us in the Apostle's words to the excellent Titus "Looking for that blessed hope, and the glorious appearing of the great God and our Saviour Jesus Christ".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:65
verses.text: Here he calls the same both Saviour, and great God, and Jesus Christ.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:66
verses.text: And in another place he writes, "In the kingdom of Christ and of God".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:67
verses.text: Moreover the chorus of the angels announced to the shepherds "Unto you is born this day in the city of David…Christ the Lord".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:68
verses.text: But to men who meditate on God's law day and night, it is indeed needless to write all the proofs of this kind; the above are sufficient to persuade even the most obstinate opponents not to divide the divine titles.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:69
verses.text: One point, however, I cannot endure to omit.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:70
verses.text: He is alleged to have said that there are many Christs but one Son.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:71
verses.text: Into this error I suppose he fell through ignorance.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:72
verses.text: For if he had read the divine Scripture, he would have known that the title of the Son has also been bestowed by our bountiful Lord on many.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:73
verses.text: The lawgiver Moses, the writer of the ancient history, says "And the sons of God saw the daughters of men that they were fair and they took them wives of them," and the God of all Himself said to this Prophet "Thou shalt say unto Pharaoh, Israel is my son even my first-born".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:74
verses.text: In the great song he says "Rejoice O ye nations with His people and let all the sons of God be strong in Him;" and by the mouth of the prophet Isaiah He says "I have nourished and brought up sons (children) and they have rebelled against me;" and through the thrice blessed David "I have said ye are gods and all of you are children of the Most High," and to the Romans the wise Paul wrote in this manner, "For as many as are led by the Spirit of God, they are the sons of God.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:75
verses.text: For ye have not received the spirit of bondage again to fear; but ye have received the spirit of adoption, whereby we cry, Abba, Father.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:76
verses.text: For the Spirit itself beareth witness with our spirit, that we are the children of God.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:77
verses.text: And if children, then heirs; heirs of God and joint-heirs with Christ: if so be that we suffer with Him that we may be also glorified together;" and to the Galatians he writes "And because ye are sons God hath sent forth the spirit of His Son into your hearts, crying, Abba, Father.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:78
verses.text: Wherefore thou art no more a servant but a son; and if a son then an heir of God through Jesus Christ".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:79
verses.text: The lesson he gives to the Ephesians is "in love having predestinated us into the adoption of children by Jesus Christ to Himself".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:80
verses.text: If then, because the name of the Christ is common, we ought not to glorify the Christ as God, we shall equally shrink from worshipping Him as Son, since this also is a name which has been bestowed upon many.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:81
verses.text: And why do I say the Son? The very name of God itself has been given by God to many.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:82
verses.text: "The Lord the God of gods hath spoken and called the earth".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:83
verses.text: And "I have said Ye are gods," and "Thou shalt not revile the gods".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:84
verses.text: Many too have appropriated this name to themselves.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:85
verses.text: The daemons who have deceived mankind have given this title to idols; whence Jeremiah exclaims, "The gods that have not made the heavens and the earth even they shall perish from the earth and from under these heavens;" and again "They made to themselves gods of silver and gods of gold;" and the prophet Isaiah when he had mocked the making of the idols, and said "He burneth part thereof in the fire with part thereof he eateth flesh he warmeth himself and saith Aha I am warm I have seen the fire," went on "and the residue thereof he maketh a god and falleth down unto it and saith 'Deliver me for thou art my god'" and so the prophet laments over them and says "Know that their heart is ashes".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:86
verses.text: And the Psalmist David has taught us to sing "For all the gods of the nations are idols, but the Lord made the heavens".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:87
verses.text: But this common use of titles gives no offence to men who are instructed in true religion.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:88
verses.text: We are aware that the daemons have falsely bestowed upon themselves and on idols the divine name, while the saints have received this honour of free grace.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:89
verses.text: In reality and by nature it is the God of all, and His only-begotten Son and the Holy Spirit which are God.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:90
verses.text: This is distinctly taught us by the admirable Paul in the words "For though there be that are called gods whether in heaven or in earth, as there are gods many and lords many, but to us there is but one God, the Father, of whom are all things, and we in Him; and one Lord by whom are all things and we by Him".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:91
verses.text: And the Holy Spirit is called the Spirit of God and so also is the soul of man, for, it is written, "His breath goeth forth," and "O ye spirits and souls of the righteous bless ye the Lord," and the Psalmist David called the angels spirits.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:92
verses.text: "Who maketh His angels spirits and His ministers a flame of fire".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:93
verses.text: Why indeed do I mention the angels and the souls of men? Even the daemons are so called by the Lord "He shall take unto him seven other spirits more wicked than himself and they shall enter in, and the last state of that man shall be worse than the first".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:94
verses.text: But even this application of the name does not offend the pious reader, for the Father and His only begotten Son and His Holy Spirit are one God by nature; and the divine Word made man, our Lord Jesus Christ, is by nature one Son, only begotten of the Father; and the Comforter who completes the number of the Trinity is one Holy Ghost.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:95
verses.text: Thus though many are named fathers, we worship one Father, the Father before the ages, who Himself gave this title to men, as the Apostle says, "For this cause I bow my knees unto the Father of our Lord Jesus Christ, of whom every fatherhood in heaven and earth is named".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:96
verses.text: Let us not then, because others are called christs, rob ourselves of the worship of our Lord Jesus Christ.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:97
verses.text: For just as though many are called gods and fathers, there is one God and Father over all and before the ages; and though many are called sons, there is one real and natural Son; and though many are styled spirits there is one Holy Ghost; just so though many are called christs there is one Lord Jesus Christ by Whom are all things.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:98
verses.text: And very properly does the Church cling to this name; for she has heard Paul, escorter of the Bride, exclaiming "I have espoused you to one husband that I may present you as a chaste virgin to Christ," and again "Husbands love your wives as Christ also loved the Church," and again "For this cause shall a man leave his father and mother, and shall be joined unto his wife, and they two shall be one flesh.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:99
verses.text: This is a great mystery; but I speak concerning Christ and the Church".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:100
verses.text: Listen to him as he says "Christ hath redeemed us from the curse of the law, being made a curse for us," and elsewhere "Know ye not that so many of us as were baptized unto Jesus Christ were baptized into His death," and in another place, "For as many of you as have been baptized into Christ have put on Christ," and again "Put ye on the Lord Jesus Christ, and make not provision for the flesh, to fulfil the lust thereof".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:101
verses.text: They who are blessed by the boons of God and have learnt to know these passages and others like them, kindled with warm love for their bountiful Master, constantly carry on their lips this His dearest name and cry in the words of the Song of Songs "My beloved is mine and I am his;" "I sat down under his shadow with great delight, and his fruit was sweet to my taste".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:102
verses.text: And besides all this that name of ours which we love so well we have derived from the name of Christ.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:103
verses.text: We are called Christians.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:104
verses.text: Of this name the Lord of all says, "The Lord God shall call His servants by another name which shall be blessed on the earth" and the following is the reason why the Church specially clings to this name.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:105
verses.text: When the only-begotten Son of God was made man, then He was named Christ, then human nature received the beams of intellectual light; then the heralds of the truth shed their beams upon the world.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:106
verses.text: Teachers of the Church, however, constantly used the names of the only begotten without distinction; at one time they glorify the Father the Son and the Holy Ghost; at another the Father with Christ and the Holy Ghost; yet as far as the sense is concerned there is here no difference.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:107
verses.text: Wherefore after the Lord had commanded to baptize in the name of the Father and of the Son and of the Holy Ghost the blessed Peter said to them who received his preaching and asked what they must do, "Believe and be baptized every one of you in the name of our Lord Jesus Christ," as though this name contained in itself all the potency of the divine command.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:108
verses.text: The same teaching is clearly given us by the great Basil, luminary of the Cappadocians, or rather of the world.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:109
verses.text: His words are "the name of Christ is the confession of the whole".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:110
verses.text: It indicates at once the Father, who anointed, the Son, who was anointed, and the Holy Ghost whereby He was anointed.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:111
verses.text: Furthermore the thrice blessed Fathers assembled in council at Nicaea, after saying that we must believe in one God, the Father, added "and in one Lord Jesus Christ, the only begotten Son of God".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:112
verses.text: Thereby they teach that the Lord Jesus Christ is Himself the only begotten Son of God.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:113
verses.text: To what has been said it must also be added that we must not affirm that after the ascension the Lord Christ is not Christ but only begotten Son.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:114
verses.text: The divine Gospels and the history of the Acts and the Epistles of the Apostle himself were, as we know, written after the ascension.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:115
verses.text: It is after the ascension that the divine Paul exclaims "Seeing then that we have a great High Priest that is passed into the heavens, Jesus the Son of God, let us hold fast our profession".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:116
verses.text: And again, "For Christ is not entered into the holy places made with hands, which are the figures of the true; but into Heaven itself, now to appear in the presence of God for us".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:117
verses.text: And again after speaking of our hope in God he adds "which hope we have as an anchor both sure and stedfast, and which entereth into that within the veil; whither the forerunner is for us entered, even Jesus made an High Priest for ever after the order of Melchisedec".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:118
verses.text: And when, writing to the blessed Titus about the second advent he says, "Looking for that blessed hope, and the glorious appearing of the great God and our Saviour Jesus Christ".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:119
verses.text: And to the Thessalonians he wrote in similar terms "For they themselves show of us what manner of entering in we had unto you, and how we turned to God from idols to serve the living and true God; and to wait for His Son from heaven, whom He raised from the dead, even Jesus, which delivered us from the wrath to come".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:120
verses.text: And again "And the Lord make you to increase and abound in love one toward another, and toward all men, even as we do toward you: to the end he may stablish your hearts unblamable in holiness before God, even our Father, at the coming of our Lord Jesus Christ with all his saints".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:121
verses.text: And again when writing to the same a second time he says, "Now we beseech you, brethren, by the coming of our Lord Jesus Christ, and by our gathering together unto him".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:122
verses.text: And a little further on when predicting the destruction of antichrist he adds, "Whom the Lord shall consume with the spirit of his mouth, and shall destroy with the brightness of his coming".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:123
verses.text: And when exhorting the Romans to concord he says, "But why dost thou judge thy brother? or why dost thou set at naught thy brother? for we shall all stand before the judgment seat of Christ.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:124
verses.text: For it is written, as I live, saith the Lord, every knee shall bow to me, and every tongue shall confess to God".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:125
verses.text: And the Lord Himself when announcing His second advent besides other things says too this "Then if any man shall say unto you, Lo, here is Christ, or there; believe it not.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:126
verses.text: For as the lightning cometh out of the east, and shineth even unto the west, so shall also the coming of the Son of Man be".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:127
verses.text: And after the immortality and incorruptibility of His body He called Himself Son of Man, naming Himself from the nature which was seen, inasmuch as the divine nature is indeed invisible to angels, as the Lord Himself had said "No one hath seen God at any time".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:128
verses.text: And to the great Moses He said "There shall no man see me and live".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:129
verses.text: The words "Henceforth know we no man after the flesh; yea, though we have known Christ after the flesh; yet now henceforth know we Him no more," were not written by the divine Apostle in order to annul the assumed nature, but for the confirmation of our own future incorruption, immortality, and spiritual life.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:130
verses.text: The Apostle therefore continues "Therefore if any man be in Christ he is a new creature; old things are passed away; behold all things are become new".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:131
verses.text: He speaks of what is to be in the future as though it had already come to pass.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:132
verses.text: We have not yet been gifted with immortality, but we shall be; and when so gifted we shall not become bodiless, but we shall put on immortality.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:133
verses.text: "For" says the divine Apostle, "we would not be unclothed, but clothed upon, that mortality might be swallowed up of life".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:134
verses.text: And again "For this corruptible must put on incorruption, and this mortal must put on immortality".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:135
verses.text: Thus he did not speak of the Lord as bodiless, but taught us to believe that even the visible nature is incorruptible, and glorified with the divine glory.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:136
verses.text: This instruction he has given us yet more clearly in the Epistle to the Philippians; "For our conversation" he writes "is in heaven; from whence also we look for the Saviour, the Lord Jesus Christ; who shall change our vile body, that it may be fashioned like unto his glorious body".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:137
verses.text: By these words he teaches us distinctly that the body of the Lord is a body, but a divine body, and glorified with the divine glory.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:138
verses.text: Let us, then, not shun the name whereby we enjoy salvation, and whereby all things are made new, as says our teacher himself in his Epistle to the Ephesians,—"According to His good pleasure which He hath purposed in Himself; that in the dispensation of the fulness of time He might gather together in one all things in Christ, both which are in heaven, and which are on earth, even in Him".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:139
verses.text: Let us rather learn from this blessed language how we are bound to glorify our benefactor, by connecting the name of Christ with our God and Father.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:140
verses.text: In his Epistle to the Romans the Apostle says "my gospel, and the preaching of Jesus Christ, according to the revelation of the mystery, which was kept secret since the world began, but now is made manifest, and by the scriptures of the prophets, according to the commandment of the everlasting God, made known to all nations for the obedience of faith; to God only will be glory through Jesus Christ forever, Amen".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:141
verses.text: Writing to the Ephesians he thus gives praise—"Now unto Him that is able to do exceeding abundantly above all that we ask or think, according to the power that worketh in us, unto Him be glory in the Church by Christ Jesus throughout all ages, world without end, Amen".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:142
verses.text: And a little before he says, "For this cause I bow my knee unto the Father of our Lord Jesus Christ of whom the whole family in heaven and earth is named".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:143
verses.text: And considerably farther on he says "Giving thanks always for all things unto God and the Father in the name of our Lord Jesus Christ".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:144
verses.text: And when he requites with benediction the liberality of the Philippians he says "But my God shall supply all your need according to His riches in glory by Christ Jesus".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:145
verses.text: And for the Hebrews he prayed, "Now the God of peace, that brought again from the dead our Lord Jesus Christ, that great shepherd of the sheep, through the blood of the everlasting covenant, make you perfect in every good work, to do His will, working in you that which is well pleasing in His sight, through Jesus Christ; to whom be glory for ever and ever, Amen".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:146
verses.text: And not only when glorifying, but also when exhorting and protesting, the Apostle conjoins the Christ with God the Father.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:147
verses.text: To the blessed Timothy he exclaims "I charge thee therefore before God and the Lord Jesus Christ".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:148
verses.text: And again "I give thee charge in the sight of God who quickeneth all things, and before Jesus Christ, who before Pontius Pilate witnessed a good confession; that thou keep this commandment without spot, unrebukable, until the appearing of our Lord Jesus Christ; which in His times He shall shew, who is the blessed and only Potentate, the King of kings and Lord of lords; who only hath immortality, dwelling in the light which no man can approach unto; whom no man hath seen, nor can see; to whom be honour and power everlasting, Amen".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:149
verses.text: These are the lessons we have learnt from the divine Apostles; this is the teaching given us by John and Matthew, those mighty rivers of the gospel message.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:150
verses.text: The latter says "The book of the generation of Jesus Christ the son of David, the son of Abraham;" and the former when he shewed the things which were before the ages wrote, "In the beginning was the Word and the Word was with God and the Word was God.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:151
verses.text: The same was in the beginning with God.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 147:152
verses.text: All things were made by Him".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 148:1
verses.text: CXLVII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 148:2
verses.text: To John, Bishop of Germanicia.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 148:3
verses.text: Immediately on receipt of your holiness's former letter I replied.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 148:4
verses.text: About the present state of affairs, it is impossible to entertain any good hope.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 148:5
verses.text: I apprehend that this is the beginning of the general apostasy.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 148:6
verses.text: For when we see that those who lament what was done as they say, by violence, at Ephesus, show no signs of repentance, but abide by their unlawful deeds and are building up a superstructure at once of injustice and of impiety; when we see that the rest take no concerted action to deny their deeds and do not refuse to hold communion with men who abide by their unlawful action, what hope of good is it possible for us to entertain? Had they been expressing their admiration of what has happened as though all had been well and rightly done, it would only have been proper for them to abide by what they themselves commend.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 148:7
verses.text: But if, as they say, they are lamenting what has been done and stating it to have been done by force and violence, why in the world do they not repudiate what has been unlawfully done? Why is the present, which lasts for such a little time, preferred before what is sure to come to pass? Why in the world do they openly lie and deny that any innovation has been introduced into doctrine? On account of what murders and witchcrafts have I been expelled? What adulteries did the man commit? What tombs did the man violate? It is perfectly clear even to outsiders that it was for doctrine that I and the rest were expelled.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 148:8
verses.text: Why the Lord Domnus too, because he would not accept "the Chapters" was deposed by these excellent persons who called them admirable and confessed that they abided by them.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 148:9
verses.text: I had read their propositions, and they rejected me as the head and front of the heresy and expelled others for the same reason.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 148:10
verses.text: What has happened proves plainly enough that they supposed the Saviour to have laid down the law of practical virtue rather for Hamaxobians than for them.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 148:11
verses.text: When some men had given in charges against Candidianus, the Pisidian, accusing him of several acts of adultery and other iniquities, it is said that the president of the council remarked, "If you are bringing accusation on points of doctrine, we receive your charges; we have not come here to decide about adulteries".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 148:12
verses.text: Accordingly Athenius and Athanasius who had been expelled by the Eastern Synod were bidden to return to their own churches; just as though our Saviour had laid down no laws about conduct, and had only ordered us to observe doctrines—which those most sapient persons have been foremost in corrupting.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 148:13
verses.text: Let them then cease to mock; let them no longer attempt to conceal the impiety which they have confirmed by blows as well as by words.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 148:14
verses.text: If this is not the case, let them tell us the reasons of the massacres; let them own in writing the distinction between the natures of our Saviour, and that the union is without confusion; let them declare that after the union both Godhead and manhood remained unimpaired.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 148:15
verses.text: "God is not mocked".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 148:16
verses.text: Let the chapters be denied which they have often repudiated, and now at Ephesus have sanctioned.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 148:17
verses.text: Do not let them trick your holiness by their lies.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 148:18
verses.text: They used to praise my utterances at Antioch, being brethren, and when made readers, and ordained deacons, presbyters and bishops; and at the end of my discourse they used to embrace me and kiss me, on head, on breast, on hands; and some of them would cling to my knees, calling my doctrine apostolic,—the very doctrine that they have now condemned, and anathematized.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 148:19
verses.text: They used to call me luminary, not only of the East, but of the whole world, and now I forsooth have been proscribed and, so far as lies in their power, I have not even bread to eat.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 148:20
verses.text: They have anathematized even all who converse with me.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 148:21
verses.text: But the man whom but a little while ago they deposed and called Valentinian and Apollinarian they have honoured as a martyr of the faith, rolling at his feet, asking his pardon and calling him spiritual father.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 148:22
verses.text: Do even woodlice change their colour to match the stones or chameleons their skin to suit the leaves, as these men do their mind to match the times? I give up to them see, dignity, rank, and all the luxury of this life.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 148:23
verses.text: On the side of the apostolic doctrines I await the evils which they deem terrible, finding sufficient consolation in the thought of the judgment of the Lord.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 148:24
verses.text: For I hope that for the sake of this injustice the Lord will remit me many of my sins.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 148:25
verses.text: Now I implore your holiness to beware of the fellowship of iniquity and to insist on their repudiation of what has been done.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 148:26
verses.text: If they refuse shun them as traitors to the faith.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 148:27
verses.text: That your reverence should wait awhile to see if the tempest will pass, we have not thought subject for blame.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 148:28
verses.text: But after the ordination of the primate of the East every man's mind will be made manifest.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 148:29
verses.text: Deign, Sir, to pray for me.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 148:30
verses.text: At this time I am sorely in want of that help that I may hold out against all that is being devised against me.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 149:1
verses.text: CXLVIII in the Edition of Garnerius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 149:2
verses.text: Is "the minute of the most holy bishop Cyril, delivered to Posidonius, when sent by him to Rome, in the matter of Nestorius".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 149:3
verses.text: (Cyrill.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 149:4
verses.text: Ep.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 149:5
verses.text: XI.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 149:6
verses.text: tom.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 149:7
verses.text: lxxvii.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 150:1
verses.text: CXLIX is "Copy of the Letter written by John, Bishop of Antioch, to Nestorius".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 150:2
verses.text: This letter has sometimes been supposed to have been really composed by Theodoret.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 151:1
verses.text: CL.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 151:2
verses.text: Letter of Theodoretus, Bishop of Cyrus, to Joannes, Bishop of Antioch.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 151:3
verses.text: I have been much distressed at reading the anathematisms which you have sent to request me to refute in writing, and to make plain to all their heretical sense.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 151:4
verses.text: I have been distressed at the thought that one appointed to the shepherd's office, entrusted with the charge of so great a flock and appointed to heal the sick among his sheep, is both himself unsound, and that to a terrible degree, and is endeavouring to infect his lambs with his disease and treats the sheep of his folds with greater cruelty than that of wild beasts.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 151:5
verses.text: They, indeed, tear and rend the sheep that are dispersed and separated from the flock; but he in its very midst, and while thought to be its saviour and its guardian introduces secret error among the victims of their confidence in him.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 151:6
verses.text: Against an open assault it is possible to take precautions, but when an attack is made in the guise of friendship, its victim is found off his guard and hurt is easily done him.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 151:7
verses.text: Hence foes who make war from within are far more dangerous than those who attack from without.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 151:8
verses.text: I am yet more grieved that it should be in the name of true religion and with the dignity of a shepherd that he should give utterance to his heretical and blasphemous words, and renew that vain and impious teaching of Apollinarius which was long ago stamped out.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 151:9
verses.text: Besides all this there is the fact that he not only supports these views but even dares to anathematize those who decline to participate in his blasphemies;—if he is really the author of these productions and they have not proceeded from some enemy of the truth who has composed them in his name and, as the old story has it, flung the apple of discord in the midst, and so fanned the flame on high.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 151:10
verses.text: But whether this composition comes from himself or from some other in his name, I, for my part, by the aid of the light of the Holy Ghost, in the investigation of this heretical and corrupt opinion, according to the measure of the power given me, have refuted them as best I could.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 151:11
verses.text: I have confronted them with the teaching of evangelists and apostles.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 151:12
verses.text: I have exposed the monstrosity of the doctrine, and proved how vast is its divergence from divine truth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 151:13
verses.text: This I have done by comparing it with the words of the Holy Spirit, and pointing out what strange and jarring discord there is between it and the divine.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 151:14
verses.text: Against the hardihood of this anathematizing, thus much I will say, that Paul, the clear-voiced herald of truth, anathematized those who had corrupted the evangelic and apostolic teaching and boldly did so against the angels, not against those who abided by the laws laid down by theologians; these he strengthened with blessings, saying, "And as many as walk according to this rule, peace be on them and mercy and on the Israel of God".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 151:15
verses.text: Let then the author of these writings reap from the Apostle's curse the due rewards of his labours and the harvest of his seeds of heresy.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 151:16
verses.text: We will abide in the teaching of the holy Fathers.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 151:17
verses.text: To this letter I have appended my counter arguments, that on reading them you may judge whether I have effectively destroyed the heretical propositions.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 151:18
verses.text: Setting down each of the anathematisms by itself, I have annexed the counter statement that readers may easily understand, and that the refutation of the dogmas may be clear.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:1
verses.text: CLI.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:2
verses.text: Letter or Address of Theodoret to the Monks of the Euphratensian, the Osrhoene, Syria, Phoenicia, and Cilicia.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:3
verses.text: When I contemplate the condition of the Church at the present crisis of affairs,—the tempest which has recently beset the holy ship, the furious blasts, the beating of the waves, the deep darkness of the night, and, besides all this, the strife of the mariners, the struggle going on between oarsmen, the drunkenness of the pilots, and, lastly, the untimely action of the bad,—I bethink me of the laments of Jeremiah and cry with him, "my bowels, my bowels! I am pained at my very heart, my heart maketh a noise in me," and to put away despondency's great cloud by the drops from my eyes, I have recourse to founts of tears.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:4
verses.text: Amid a storm so wild it is fitting that the pilots be awake, to battle with the tempest, and take heed for the safety of the ship: the sailors ought to cease from their strife, and strive to undo the danger alike by prayer and skill: the mariners ought to keep the peace, and quarrel neither with one another nor with the pilots, but implore the Lord of the sea to banish the darkness by His rod.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:5
verses.text: No one now is willing to do anything of the kind; and, just as happens in a night-engagement, we cannot recognise one another, we leave our enemies alone, and waste our weapons against our own side; we wound our comrades for foes, while all the while the bystanders laugh at our drunken folly, enjoy our disasters, and are delighted to see us engaged in mutual destruction.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:6
verses.text: The responsibility for all this lies with those who have striven to corrupt the apostolic faith, and have dared to add a monstrous doctrine to the teaching of the Gospels; with them that have accepted the impious "Chapters" which they have sent forth with anathematisms to the imperial city, and have confirmed them, as they have imagined, by their own signatures.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:7
verses.text: But these "Chapters" have sprouted without doubt from the sour root of Apollinarius; they are tainted with Arian and Eunomian error; look into them carefully, and you will find that they are not clear of the impiety of Manes and Valentinus.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:8
verses.text: In his very first chapter he rejects the dispensation which has been made on our behalf, teaching that God the Word did not assume human nature, but was Himself changed into flesh, thus laying down that the incarnation took place not in reality but in semblance and seeming.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:9
verses.text: This is the outcome of the impiety of Marcion, Manes, and Valentinus.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:10
verses.text: In his second and third chapters, as though quite oblivious of what he had stated in his preface, he brings in the hypostatic union, and a meeting by natural union, and by these terms he represents that a kind of mixture and confusion was effected of the divine nature and of the form of the servant.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:11
verses.text: This comes of the innovation of the Apollinarian heresy.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:12
verses.text: In his fourth chapter he denies the distinction of the terms of evangelists and apostles, and refuses to allow, as the teaching of the orthodox Fathers has allowed, the terms of divine dignity to be understood of the divine nature, while the terms of humility, spoken in human sense, are applied to the nature assumed; whence the rightminded can easily detect the kinship with impiety.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:13
verses.text: For Arius and Eunomius, asserting the only begotten Son of God to be a creature, and made out of the non-existent, and a servant, have ventured to apply to His godhead what is said in lowly and human sense; establishing by such means the difference of substance and the unlikeness.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:14
verses.text: Besides this, to be brief, he argues that the very impassible and immutable Godhead of the Christ suffered, and was crucified, dead, and buried.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:15
verses.text: This goes beyond even the madness of Arius and Eunomius, for this pitch of impiety has not been reached even by them that dare to call the maker and creator of the universe a creature.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:16
verses.text: Furthermore he blasphemes against the Holy Ghost, denying that It proceeds from the Father, in accordance with the word of the Lord, but maintaining that It has Its origin of the Son.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:17
verses.text: Here we have the fruit of the Apollinarian seed; here we come near the evil husbandry of Macedonius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:18
verses.text: Such are the offspring of the Egyptian, viler children of a vile father.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:19
verses.text: This growth, which men, entrusted with the healing of souls, ought to make abortive while yet in the womb, or destroy as soon as it is born, as dangerous and deadly to mankind, is cherished by these excellent persons, and promoted with great energy, alike to their own ruin and to that of all who will listen to them.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:20
verses.text: We, on the contrary, earnestly desire to keep our heritage untouched; and the faith which we have received, and in which we have been ourselves baptized, and baptize others, we strive to preserve uninjured and undefiled.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:21
verses.text: We confess that our Lord Jesus Christ, perfect God and perfect man, of a reasonable soul and body, was begotten of the Father before the ages, as touching the Godhead; and in the last days for us men and our salvation (was born) of the Virgin Mary; that the same Lord is of one substance with the Father as touching the Godhead, and of one substance with us as touching the manhood.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:22
verses.text: For there was an union of two natures.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:23
verses.text: Wherefore we acknowledge one Christ, one Son, one Lord; but we do not destroy the union; we believe it to have been made without confusion, in obedience to the word of the Lord to the Jews, "Destroy this temple and in three days I will raise it up".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:24
verses.text: If on the contrary there had been mixture and confusion, and one nature was made out of both, He ought to have said "Destroy me and in three days I shall be raised".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:25
verses.text: But now, to show that there is a distinction between God according to His nature, and the temple, and that both are one Christ, His words are "Destroy this temple and in three days I will raise it up," clearly teaching that it was not God who was undergoing destruction, but the temple.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:26
verses.text: The nature of this latter was susceptible of destruction, while the power of the former raised what was being destroyed.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:27
verses.text: Furthermore it is in obedience to the divine Scriptures that we acknowledge the Christ to be God and man.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:28
verses.text: That our Lord Jesus Christ is God is asserted by the blessed evangelist John "In the beginning was the Word and the Word was with God and the Word was God.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:29
verses.text: He was in the beginning with God.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:30
verses.text: All things were made by Him and without Him was not anything made that was made".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:31
verses.text: And again, "That was the true light which lighteth every man that cometh into the world".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:32
verses.text: And the Lord Himself distinctly teaches us, "He that hath seen me hath seen the Father".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:33
verses.text: And "I and my Father are one" and "I am in the Father and the Father in me," and the blessed Paul in his epistle to the Hebrews says "Who being the brightness of His glory and the express image of His person, and upholding all things by the word of His power" and in the epistle to the Philippians "Let this mind be in you, which was also in Christ Jesus; who being in the form of God thought it not robbery to be equal with God but made Himself of no reputation and took upon Him the form of a servant".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:34
verses.text: And in the Epistle to the Romans, "Whose are the fathers and of whom as concerning the flesh Christ came who is over all God blessed for ever, Amen".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:35
verses.text: And in the epistle to Titus "Looking for that blessed hope and the glorious appearing of the great God and our Saviour Jesus Christ".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:36
verses.text: And Isaiah exclaims "Unto us a child is born, unto us a son is given: and the government shall be upon His shoulder; and His name shall be called, Angel of great counsel, Wonderful, Counsellor, The mighty God, powerful, the Prince of Peace, the Father of the Age to come".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:37
verses.text: And again "In chains they shall come over and they shall fall unto thee.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:38
verses.text: They shall make supplication unto thee saying, surely God is in thee and there is none else, there is no God.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:39
verses.text: Verily thou art a God that hidest thyself, O God of Israel, the Saviour".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:40
verses.text: The name Emmanuel, however, indicates both God and man, for it is interpreted in the Gospel to mean "God with us," that is to say "God in man," God in our nature.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:41
verses.text: And the divine Jeremiah too utters the prediction "This is our God and there shall none other be accounted of in comparison with him.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:42
verses.text: He hath found out all the way of knowledge and hath given it unto Jacob His servant and to Israel His beloved and afterward did He show Himself upon earth and conversed with men".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:43
verses.text: And countless other passages might be found as well in the holy gospels and in the writings of the apostles as in the predictions of the prophets, setting forth that our Lord Jesus Christ is very God.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:44
verses.text: That after the Incarnation He is spoken of as Man our Lord Himself teaches in His words to the Jews "Why go ye about to kill me?" "A man that hath told you the truth".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:45
verses.text: And in the first Epistle to the Corinthians the blessed Paul writes "For since by man came death, by man came also the resurrection of the dead," and to show of whom he is speaking he explains his words and says, "For as in Adam all die even so in Christ shall all be made alive".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:46
verses.text: And writing to Timothy he says, "For there is one God and one mediator between God and men, the man Christ Jesus".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:47
verses.text: In the Acts in his speech at Athens "The times of this ignorance God winked at; but now commandeth all men everywhere to repent; because He hath appointed a day in the which He will judge the world in righteousness by that man whom He hath ordained, whereof He hath given assurance unto all men, in that He hath raised him from the dead".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:48
verses.text: And the blessed Peter preaching to the Jews says, "Ye men of Israel, hear these words Jesus of Nazareth, a man approved of God among you by miracles and wonders and signs which God did by Him in the midst of you," and the prophet Isaiah when predicting the sufferings of the Lord Christ, whom but just before he had called God, calls man in the passage "A man of sorrows and acquainted with grief".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:49
verses.text: "Surely he hath borne our griefs and carried our sorrows".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:50
verses.text: I might have collected other consentient passages of holy Scripture and inserted them in my letter had I not known you to be practised in the divine oracles as befits the man called blessed in the Psalms.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:51
verses.text: I now leave the collection of evidence to your own diligence and proceed with my subject.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:52
verses.text: We confess then that our Lord Jesus Christ is very God and very man.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:53
verses.text: We do not divide the one Christ into two persons, but we believe two natures to be united without confusion.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:54
verses.text: We shall thus be able without difficulty to refute even the manifold blasphemy of the heretics: for many and various are the errors of those who have rebelled against the truth, as we shall proceed to point out.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:55
verses.text: Marcion and Manes deny that God the Word assumed human nature and do not believe that our Lord Jesus Christ was born of a Virgin.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:56
verses.text: They say that God the Word Himself was fashioned in human form and appeared as man rather in semblance than in reality.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:57
verses.text: Valentinus and Bardesanes admit the birth, but they deny the assumption of our nature and affirm that the Son of God employed the Virgin as it were as a mere conduit.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:58
verses.text: Sabellius the Libyan, Photinus, Marcellus the Galatian, and Paul of Samosata say that a mere man was born of the Virgin, but openly deny that the eternal Christ was God.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:59
verses.text: Arius and Eunomius maintain that God the Word assumed only a body of the Virgin.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:60
verses.text: Apollinarius adds to the body an unreasonable soul, as though the incarnation of God the Word had taken place not for the sake of reasonable beings but of unreasonable, while the teaching of the Apostles is that perfect man was assumed by perfect God, as is proved by the words "Who being in the form of God took the form of a servant;" for "form" is put instead of "nature" and "substance" and indicates that having the nature of God He took the nature of a servant.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:61
verses.text: When therefore we are disputing with Marcion, Manes and Valentinus, the earliest inventors of impiety, we endeavour to prove from the divine Scriptures that the Lord Christ is not only God but also man.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:62
verses.text: When, however, we are proving to the ignorant that the doctrine of Arius, Eunomius and Apollinarius about the oeconomy is incomplete, we show from the divine oracles of the Spirit that the assumed nature was perfect.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:63
verses.text: The impiety of Sabellius, Photinus, Marcellus, and Paulus, we refute by proving by the evidence of divine Scripture that the Lord Christ was not only man but also eternal God, of one substance with the Father.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:64
verses.text: That He assumed a reasonable soul is stated by our Lord Himself in the words "Now is my soul troubled; and what shall I say? Father save me from this hour; but for this cause came I unto this hour".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:65
verses.text: And again "My soul is exceeding sorrowful even unto death".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:66
verses.text: And in another place "I have power to lay down my soul (life A.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:67
verses.text: V.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:68
verses.text: ) and I have power to take it again.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:69
verses.text: No man taketh it from me".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:70
verses.text: And the angel said to Joseph, "Take the young child and His mother and go into the land of Israel; for they are dead which sought the young child's soul (life A.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:71
verses.text: V.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:72
verses.text: )" And the Evangelist says "Jesus increased in wisdom and stature and in favour with God and man".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:73
verses.text: Now what increases in stature and wisdom is not the Godhead which is ever perfect, but the human nature which comes into being in time, grows, and is made perfect.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:74
verses.text: Wherefore all the human qualities of the Lord Christ, hunger, I mean, and thirst and weariness, sleep, fear, sweat, prayer, and ignorance, and the like, we affirm to belong to our nature which God the Word assumed and united to Himself in effecting our salvation.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:75
verses.text: But the restitution of motion to the maimed, the resurrection of the dead, the supply of loaves, and all the other miracles we believe to be works of the divine power.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:76
verses.text: In this sense I say that the same Lord Christ both suffers and destroys suffering; suffers, that is, as touching the visible, and destroys suffering as touching the ineffably indwelling Godhead.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:77
verses.text: This is proved beyond question by the narrative of the holy evangelists, from whom we learn that when lying in a manger and wrapped in swaddling clothes, He was announced by a star, worshipped by magi and hymned by angels.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:78
verses.text: Thus we reverent discern that the swaddling bands and the want of a bed and all the poverty belonged to the manhood; while the journey of the magi and the guiding of the star and the company of the angels proclaim the Godhead of the unseen.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:79
verses.text: In like manner He makes His escape into Egypt and avoids the fury of Herod by flight, for He was man; but as the Prophet says "He shakes the idols of Egypt," for He was by nature God.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:80
verses.text: He is circumcised; He keeps the law; and offers offerings of purification, because He sprang from the root of Jesse.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:81
verses.text: And, as man, He was under the law; and afterwards did away with the law and gave the new covenant, because He was a lawgiver and had promised by the prophets that He Himself would give it.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:82
verses.text: He was baptized by John; and this shews His sharing what is ours.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:83
verses.text: He is testified to by the Father from on high and is pointed out by the Spirit; this proclaims Him eternal.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:84
verses.text: He hungered; but He fed many thousands with five loaves; the latter is divine, the former human.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:85
verses.text: He thirsted and He asked for water; but He was the well of life; the former of His human weakness, the latter of His divine power.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:86
verses.text: He fell asleep in the boat, but he put the tempest of the sea to sleep; the former of His human nature, the latter of His efficient and creative power which has gifted all things with their being.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:87
verses.text: He was weary as he walked; but He healed the halt and raised dead men from their tombs; the former of human weakness, the latter of a power passing that of this world.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:88
verses.text: He feared death and He destroyed death; the former shows that He was mortal, the latter that He was immortal or rather giver of life.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:89
verses.text: "He was crucified," as the blessed Paul says "through weakness".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:90
verses.text: But as the same Paul says "Yet He liveth by the power of God".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:91
verses.text: Let that word "weakness" teach us that He was not nailed to the tree as the Almighty, the Uncircumscribed, the Immutable and Invariable, but that the nature quickened by the power of God, was according to the Apostle's teaching dead and buried, both death and burial being proper to the form of the servant.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:92
verses.text: "He broke the gates of brass and cut the bars of iron in sunder" and destroyed the power of death and in three days raised His own temple.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:93
verses.text: These are proofs of the form of God in accordance with the Lord's words "Destroy this temple and in three days I will raise it up".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:94
verses.text: Thus in the one Christ through the sufferings we contemplate the manhood and through the miracles we apprehend the Godhead.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:95
verses.text: We do not divide the two natures into two Christs, and we know that of the Father God the Word was begotten and that of the seed of Abraham and David our nature was assumed.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:96
verses.text: Wherefore also the blessed Paul says when discoursing of Abraham "He saith not and to seeds as of many; but as of one, and to thy seed which is Christ," and writing to Timothy he says "Remember that Jesus Christ of the seed of David was raised from the dead according to my gospel".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:97
verses.text: And to the Romans he writes "Concerning His son Jesus Christ…which was made of the seed of David according to the flesh".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:98
verses.text: And again "Whose are the fathers and of whom as concerning the flesh Christ came".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:99
verses.text: And the Evangelist writes "The book of the generation of Jesus Christ, the Son of David, the Son of Abraham," and the blessed Peter in the Acts says David "being a prophet and knowing that God had sworn with an oath to him that of the fruit of his loins, He would raise up Christ to sit on his throne, he seeing this before spake of his resurrection," and God says to Abraham "In thy seed shall all the nations of the earth be blessed," and Isaiah "There shall come forth a rod out of the stem of Jesse and a branch shall grow out of His roots; and there shall rest upon Him the spirit of wisdom and understanding, the spirit of counsel and might, the spirit of knowledge and of piety and the spirit of the fear of the Lord shall fill Him".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:100
verses.text: And a little further on "And in that day there shall be a root of Jesse which shall stand for an ensign of the people; to it shall the Gentiles seek; and His rest shall be glorious".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:101
verses.text: From these quotations it is made plain that according to the flesh, the Christ was descended from Abraham and David and was of the same nature as theirs; while according to the Godhead He is Everlasting Son and Word of God, ineffably and in superhuman manner begotten of the Father, and co-eternal with Him as brightness and express image and Word.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:102
verses.text: For as the word in relation to intelligence and brightness in relation to light are inseparably connected, so is the only begotten Son in relation to His own Father.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:103
verses.text: We assert therefore that our Lord Jesus Christ is only begotten, and first born Son of God; only begotten both before the incarnation and after the incarnation, but firstborn after being born of the Virgin.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:104
verses.text: For the name first-born seems to be in a sense contrary to that of only begotten, because the only Son begotten of any one is called only begotten, while the eldest of several brothers is called first-born.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:105
verses.text: The divine Scriptures state God the Word alone to have been begotten of the Father; but the only begotten becomes also first-born, by taking our nature of the Virgin, and deigning to call brothers those who have trusted in Him; so that the same is only begotten in that He is God, first born in that He is Man.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:106
verses.text: Thus acknowledging the two natures we adore the one Christ and offer Him one adoration, for we believe that the union took place from the moment of the conception in the Virgin's holy womb.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:107
verses.text: Wherefore also we call the holy Virgin both Mother of God and Mother of man, since the Lord Christ Himself is called God and man in the divine Scripture.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:108
verses.text: The name Emmanuel proclaims the union of the two natures.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:109
verses.text: If we acknowledge the Christ to be both God and Man and so call Him, who is so insensate as to shrink from using the term "Mother of man" with that of "Mother of God"? For we use both terms of the Lord Christ.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:110
verses.text: For this reason the Virgin is honoured and called "full of grace".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:111
verses.text: What sensible man then would object to name the Virgin in accordance with the titles of the Saviour, when on His account she is honoured by the faithful? For He who was born of her is not worshipped on her account, but she is honoured with the highest titles on account of Him Who was born from her.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:112
verses.text: Suppose the Christ to be God only, and to have taken the origin of His existence from the Virgin, then let the Virgin be styled and named only "Mother of God" as having given birth to a being divine by nature.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:113
verses.text: But if the Christ is both God and man and was God from everlasting (inasmuch as He did not begin to exist, being co-eternal with the Father that begat Him) and in these last days was born man of His human nature, then let him who wishes to define doctrine in both directions devise appellations for the Virgin with the explanation which of them befits the nature and which the union.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:114
verses.text: But if any one should wish to deliver a panegyric and to compose hymns, and to repeat praises, and is naturally anxious to use the most august names; then, not laying down doctrine as in the former case, but with rhetorical laudation, and expressing all possible admiration at the mightiness of the mystery, let him gratify his heart's desire, let him employ high names, let him praise and let him wonder.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:115
verses.text: Many instances of this kind are found in the writings of orthodox teachers.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:116
verses.text: But on all occasions let moderation be respected.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:117
verses.text: All praise to him who said that "moderation is best," although he is not of our herd.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:118
verses.text: This is the confession of the faith of the Church; this is the doctrine taught by evangelists and apostles.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:119
verses.text: For this faith, by God's grace I will not refuse to undergo many deaths.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:120
verses.text: This faith we have striven to convey to them that now err and stray, again and again challenging them to discussion, and eager to show them the truth, but without success.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:121
verses.text: With a suspicion of their probably plain confutation, they have shirked the encounter; for verily falsehood is rotten and yokefellow of obscurity.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:122
verses.text: "Every one," it is written "that doeth evil cometh not to the light lest his deeds should be reproved" by the light.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:123
verses.text: Since, therefore, after many efforts, I have failed in persuading them to recognise the truth, I have returned to my own churches, filled at once with sorrow and with joy; with joy on account of my own freedom from error; and with sorrow at the unsoundness of my members.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:124
verses.text: I therefore implore you to pray with all your might to our loving Lord, and to cry unto Him, "'Spare Thy people, O Lord and give not Thy heritage to reproach.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:125
verses.text: ' Feed us O Lord that we become not as we were in the beginning when Thou didst not rule over us nor was Thy name invoked to help us.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:126
verses.text: 'We are become a reproach to our neighbours, a scorn and derision to them that are round about us,' because wicked doctrines have come into Thy inheritance.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:127
verses.text: They have polluted Thy holy temple in that the daughters of strangers have rejoiced over our troubles.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:128
verses.text: A little while ago we were of one mind and one tongue and now are divided into many tongues.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:129
verses.text: But, O Lord our God, give us Thy peace which we have lost by setting Thy commandments at naught.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:130
verses.text: O Lord we know none other than Thee.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:131
verses.text: We call Thee by Thy name.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:132
verses.text: 'Make both one and break down the middle wall of the partition,' namely the iniquity that has sprung up.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:133
verses.text: Gather us one by one, Thy new Israel, building up Jerusalem and gathering together the outcasts of Israel.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:134
verses.text: Let us be made once more one flock and all be fed by Thee; for Thou art the good Shepherd 'Who giveth His life for the sheep ' 'Awake, why sleepest Thou O Lord, arise cast us not off forever.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:135
verses.text: ' Rebuke the winds and the sea; give Thy Church calm and safety from the waves".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:136
verses.text: These words and words like these I implore you to utter to the God of all; for He is good and full of loving-kindness and ever fulfils the will of them that fear Him.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:137
verses.text: He will therefore listen to your prayer, and will scatter this darkness deeper than the plague of Egypt.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:138
verses.text: He will give you His own calm of love, and will gather them that are scattered abroad and welcome them that have been cast out.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:139
verses.text: Then shall be heard "the voice of rejoicing and salvation in the tabernacles of the righteous".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:140
verses.text: Then shall we cry unto Him we have been "glad according to the days wherein Thou hast afflicted us and the years wherein we have seen evil," and you when you have been granted your prayer shall praise Him in the words "Blessed be God which not turned away my prayer nor His mercy from me".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:141
verses.text: Proof that after the Incarnation our Lord Jesus Christ, was one Son.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:142
verses.text: The authors of slanders against me allege that I divide the one Lord Jesus Christ into two sons.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:143
verses.text: But so far am I from holding this opinion that I charge with impiety all who dare to say so.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:144
verses.text: For I have been taught by the divine Scripture to worship one Son, our Lord Jesus Christ, the only begotten Son of God, God the Word incarnate.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:145
verses.text: For we confess the same to be both God eternal, and made man in the last days for the sake of man's salvation; but made man not by the change of the Godhead but by the assumption of the manhood.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:146
verses.text: For the nature of this godhead is immutable and invariable, as is that of the Father who begat Him before the ages.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:147
verses.text: And whatever would be understood of the substance of the Father will also be wholly found in the substance of the only begotten; for of that substance He is begotten.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:148
verses.text: This our Lord taught when He said to Philip "He that hath seen me hath seen the Father" and again in another place "All things that the Father hath are mine," and elsewhere "I and the Father are one," and very many other passages may be quoted setting forth the identity of substance.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:149
verses.text: It follows that He did not become God: He was God.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:150
verses.text: "In the beginning was the Word, and the Word was with God; and the Word was God".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:151
verses.text: He was not man: He became man, and He so became by taking on Him our nature: So says the blessed Paul—"Who being in the form of God thought it not robbery to be equal with God, but made Himself of no reputation, and took upon Him the form of a servant".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:152
verses.text: And again: "For verily He took not on Him the nature of angels; but He took on Him the seed of Abraham".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:153
verses.text: And again; Forasmuch then as the children are partakers of flesh and blood, He also Himself likewise took part of the same".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:154
verses.text: Thus He was both passible and impassible; mortal and immortal; passible, on the one hand, and mortal, as man; impassible, on the other, and immortal, as God.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:155
verses.text: As God He raised His own flesh, which was dead;—as His own words declare: "Destroy this temple, and in three days I will raise it up".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:156
verses.text: And as man, He was passible and mortal up to the time of the passion.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:157
verses.text: For, after the resurrection, even as man He is impassible, immortal, and incorruptible; and He discharges divine lightnings; not that according to the flesh He has been changed into the nature of Godhead, but still preserving the distinctive marks of humanity.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:158
verses.text: Nor yet is His body uncircumscribed, for this is peculiar to the divine nature alone, but it abides in its former circumscription.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:159
verses.text: This He teaches in the words He spake to the disciples even after His resurrection "Behold my hands and feet that it is I myself; handle me and see; for a spirit hath not flesh and bones as ye see me have".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:160
verses.text: While He was thus beheld He went up into heaven; thus has He promised to come again, thus shall He be seen both by them that have believed and them that have crucified, for it is written "They shall look on Him whom they pierced".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:161
