verses.text: We therefore worship the Son, but we contemplate in Him either nature in its perfection, both that which took, and that which was taken; the one of God and the other of David.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:162
verses.text: For this reason also He is styled both Son of the living God and Son of David; either nature receiving its proper title.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:163
verses.text: Accordingly the divine scripture calls him both God and man, and the blessed Paul exclaims "There is one God, and one mediator between God and men, the man Christ Jesus; who gave Himself a ransom for all".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:164
verses.text: But Him whom here he calls man in another place he describes as God for he says "Looking for that blessed hope and the glorious appearing of the great God and our Saviour Jesus Christ".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:165
verses.text: And yet in another place he uses both names at once saying "Of whom as concerning the flesh Christ came who is over all God blessed for ever, Amen".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:166
verses.text: Thus he has stated the same Christ to be of the Jews according to the flesh, and God over all as God.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:167
verses.text: Similarly the prophet Isaiah writes "A man of sorrows and acquainted with grief.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:168
verses.text: …Surely He hath borne our griefs and carried our sorrows," and shortly afterwards he says "Who shall declare His generation?" This is spoken not of man but of God.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:169
verses.text: Thus through Micah God says "Thou Bethlehem in the land of Judah art not the least among the princes of Judah, for out of thee shall come a governor that shall rule my people Israel, whose goings forth have been as of old from everlasting".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:170
verses.text: Now by saying "From thee shall come forth a ruler" he exhibits the oeconomy of the incarnation; and by adding "whose goings forth have been as of old from everlasting" he declares the Godhead begotten of the Father before the ages.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:171
verses.text: Since we have been thus taught by the divine scripture, and have further found that the teachers who have been at different periods illustrious in the Church, are of the same opinion, we do our best to keep our heritage inviolate; worshipping one Son of God, one God the Father, and one Holy Ghost; but at the same time recognising the distinction between flesh and Godhead.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:172
verses.text: And as we assert them that divide our one Lord Jesus Christ into two sons to trangress from the road trodden by the holy apostles, so do we declare the maintainers of the doctrine that the Godhead of the only begotten and the manhood have been made one nature to fall headlong into the opposite ravine.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:173
verses.text: These doctrines we hold; these we preach; for these we do battle.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:174
verses.text: The slander of the libellers that represent me as worshipping two sons is refuted by the plain facts of the case.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:175
verses.text: I teach all persons who come to holy Baptism the faith put forth at Nicaea; and, when I celebrate the sacrament of regeneration I baptize them that make profession of their faith in the name of the Father, and of the Son, and of the Holy Ghost, pronouncing each name by itself.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:176
verses.text: And when I am performing divine service in the churches it is my wont to give glory to the Father and to the Son and to the Holy Ghost; not sons, but Son.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:177
verses.text: If then I uphold two sons, whether of the two is glorified by me, and whether remains unhonoured? For I have not quite come to such a pitch of stupidity as to acknowledge two sons and leave one of them without any tribute of respect.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:178
verses.text: It follows then even from this fact that the slander is proved slander,—for I worship one only begotten Son, God the Word incarnate.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:179
verses.text: And I call the holy Virgin "Mother of God" because she has given birth to the Emmanuel, which means "God with us".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:180
verses.text: But the prophet who predicted the Emmanuel a little further on has written of him that "Unto us a child is born, unto us a son is given; and the government shall be upon his shoulders; and his name is called Angel of great counsel, wonderful, counsellor, mighty God, powerful, Prince of peace, Father of the age to come".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:181
verses.text: Now if the babe born of the Virgin is styled "Mighty God," then it is only with reason that the mother is called "Mother of God".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:182
verses.text: For the mother shares the honour of her offspring, and the Virgin is both mother of the Lord Christ as man, and again is His servant as Lord and Creator and God.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:183
verses.text: On account of this difference of term He is said by the divine Paul to be "without father, without mother, without descent, having neither beginning of days nor end of life".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:184
verses.text: He is without father as touching His humanity; for as man He was born of a mother alone.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:185
verses.text: And He is without mother as God, for He was begotten from everlasting of the Father alone.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:186
verses.text: And again He is without descent as God while as man He has descent.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:187
verses.text: For it is written "The book of the generation of Jesus Christ the son of David, the son of Abraham".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:188
verses.text: His descent is also given by the divine Luke.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:189
verses.text: So again, as God, He has no beginning of days for He was begotten before the ages; neither has He an end of life, for His nature is immortal and impassible.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:190
verses.text: But as man He had both a beginning of days, for He was born in the reign of Augustus Caesar, and an end of life, for He was crucified in the reign of Tiberius Caesar.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:191
verses.text: But now, as I have already said, even His human nature is immortal; and, as He ascended, so again shall He come according to the words of the Angel—"This same Jesus which is taken up from you into Heaven shall so come in like manner as ye have seen Him go into Heaven".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:192
verses.text: This is the doctrine delivered to us by the divine prophets; this is the doctrine of the company of the holy apostles; this is the doctrine of the great saints of the East and of the West; of the far-famed Ignatius, who received his archpriesthood by the right hand of the great Peter, and for the sake of his confession of Christ was devoured by savage beasts; and of the great Eustathius, who presided over the assembled council, and on account of his fiery zeal for true religion was driven into exile.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:193
verses.text: This doctrine was preached by the illustrious Meletius, at the cost of no less pains, for thrice was he driven from his flock in the cause of the apostles' doctrines; by Flavianus, glory of the imperial see; and by the admirable Ephraim, instrument of divine grace, who has left us in the Syriac tongue a written heritage of good things; by Cyprian, the illustrious ruler of Carthage and of all Libya, who for Christ's sake found a death in the fire; by Damasus, bishop of great Rome, and by Ambrose, glory of Milan, who preached and wrote it in the language of Rome.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:194
verses.text: The same was taught by the great luminaries of Alexandria, Alexander and Athanasius, men of one mind, who underwent sufferings celebrated throughout the world.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:195
verses.text: This was the pasture given to their flocks by the great teachers of the imperial city, by Gregory, shining friend and supporter of the truth; by John, teacher of the world, by Atticus, their successor alike in see and in sentiment.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:196
verses.text: By these doctrines Basil, great light of the truth, and Gregory sprung from the same parents, and Amphilochius, who from him received the gift of the high-priesthood, taught their contemporaries, and have left the same to us in their writings for a goodly heritage.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:197
verses.text: Time would fail me to tell of Polycarp, and Irenaeus, of Methodius and Hippolytus, and the rest of the teachers of the Church.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:198
verses.text: In a word I assert that I follow the divine oracles and at the same time all these saints.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:199
verses.text: By the grace of the spirit they dived into the depths of God-inspired scripture and both themselves perceived its mind, and made it plain to all that are willing to learn.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 152:200
verses.text: Difference in tongue has wrought no difference in doctrine, for they were channels of the grace of the divine spirit, using the stream from one and the same fount.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 153:1
verses.text: CLII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 153:2
verses.text: Report of the (Bishops) of the East to the Emperor, giving information of their proceedings, and explaining the cause of the delay in the arrival of the Bishop of Antioch.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 153:3
verses.text: In obedience to the order of your pious letter we have journeyed to the Ephesian metropolis.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 153:4
verses.text: There we have found the affairs of the Church in confusion, and disturbed by internecine war.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 153:5
verses.text: The cause of this is that Cyril of Alexandria and Memnon of Ephesus have banded together and mustered a great mob of rustics, and have forbidden both the celebration of the great feast of Pentecost, and the evening and morning offices.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 153:6
verses.text: They have shut the sacred churches and martyrs' shrines; they have assembled apart with the victims of their deceit; they have wrought innumerable iniquities, trampling under foot alike the canons of the holy Fathers, and your own decrees.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 153:7
verses.text: And the action has been taken in face of the order given both in writing and by word of mouth by the most excellent count Candidianus, envoy of your Christ-loving majesty, that the council must await the arrival of the very holy bishops, coming from all quarters of the Empire, and then and not till then formally assemble in obedience to your piety's commands.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 153:8
verses.text: Moreover Cyril of Alexandria had written to me, the bishop of Antioch, two days before the meeting of their synod, that the whole council was awaiting my arrival.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 153:9
verses.text: We have therefore deposed both the aforenamed, Cyril and Memnon, and have excluded them from all the services of the church.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 153:10
verses.text: The rest, who have participated in their iniquity, we have excommunicated, until they shall reject and anathematize the Chapters issued by Cyril, which are full of the Eunomian and Arian heresies, and shall, in obedience to your piety's command, assemble together with us, and shall in an orderly manner and with all exactitude, together with ourselves, examine into the questions at issue, and confirm the pious doctrine of the holy Fathers.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 153:11
verses.text: As to the delay in my own arrival be it known to your piety that, in consideration of the distance of the way by land,—and this was our route,—I have come very quickly, I have travelled forty stages without pausing to rest on the way; so your Christian majesty may learn from the inhabitants of the towns on the route.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 153:12
verses.text: Besides this I was detained many days in Antioch by the famine there; by the daily tumults of the people; and by the unusual severity of the rainy season, which caused the torrents to swell, and threatened danger to the town.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 154:1
verses.text: CLIII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 154:2
verses.text: Report of the same to the Empresses Pulcheria and Eudoxia.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 154:3
verses.text: We had expected to be able to report to your pious majesties in different terms, but we are now compelled to make known to you the following facts, forced as we are by the irregular exercise of despotic power by Cyril of Alexandria and Memnon of Ephesus.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 154:4
verses.text: The proper course to have been pursued, in accordance with the laws of the Church, and the command of your pious majesties, would have been to wait for the arrival of the godly bishops on the road, and in common with them to examine into the questions at issue concerning the true faith, and investigate the point offered for discussion, and, after exact enquiry, to confirm the doctrines of the apostles.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 154:5
verses.text: They had written to me that they would wait for our arrival.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 154:6
verses.text: They heard that we were only three stages off.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 154:7
verses.text: Then they assembled an unconstitutional council by themselves, and have ventured on proceedings iniquitous, irregular, and bristling with absurdities.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 154:8
verses.text: And this they have done though the most honourable count Candidianus, sent by your pious and Christian majesties for good order's sake, expressly charged them, alike in writing and by word of mouth, to wait for the arrival of the godly bishops who had been convened, and to attempt no innovation on the true faith, but to take their stand on the directions of our godly-minded sovereigns.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 154:9
verses.text: Now in spite of their having heard the imperial letter and the advice of the most honourable count Candidianus, they have nevertheless made naught of due order.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 154:10
verses.text: As the prophet says "They hatch cockatrice' eggs, and weave the spider's web; and he that would eat of their eggs when he breaks them findeth rottenness, and therein is a viper," Wherefore we confidently cry "Their webs shall not become garments, neither shall they cover themselves with their works".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 154:11
verses.text: They have shut the churches and the martyrs' shrines; they have forbidden the celebration of the holy feast of Pentecost; besides this they have sent the minions of their disorderly despotism into bishops' private houses, uttering shocking threats, and forcing them to affix their signatures to illegal acts.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 154:12
verses.text: We therefore considering all their preposterous conduct, have deposed the aforenamed Cyril and Memnon, and deprived them of their episcopate.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 154:13
verses.text: Their associates in irregularity, whether influenced by sycophancy or by fear, we have excommunicated, until, coming to a knowledge of their own wounds, they shall heartily repent, shall anathematize the heretical Chapters of Cyril, which are tainted with the heresy of Apollinarius, Arius, and Eunomius, shall recover the faith of the Fathers in Council at Nicaea, and, in obedience to the pious commands of our Christian sovereigns, shall, peacefully and without any tumult, assemble in synod, be willing to examine with care the questions submitted to them, and honestly protect the purity of the faith of the Gospel.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 155:1
verses.text: CLIV.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 155:2
verses.text: Report of the same to the Senate of Constantinople.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 156:1
verses.text: CLV.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 156:2
verses.text: Letter of John, Bishop of Antioch and his Supporters, to the Clergy of Constantinople.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 157:1
verses.text: CLVI.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 157:2
verses.text: Letter of the same to the people of Constantinople.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 158:1
verses.text: CLVII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 158:2
verses.text: Report of the Council of (the Bishops of) the East to the Victorious Emperor, announcing a second time the deposition of Cyril and of Memnon.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 158:3
verses.text: Your piety, which shines forth for the good of the empire and of the churches of God, has commanded us to assemble at Ephesus, in order to bring about peace and gain for the Church, rather than to confuse and disturb it.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 158:4
verses.text: And the commands of your majesty plainly and distinctly indicate your pious and peaceful intentions for the churches of Christ.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 158:5
verses.text: But Cyril of Alexandria, a man, it would seem, born and bred for the bane of the churches, after taking into partnership the audacity of Memnon of Ephesus, has first of all transgressed against your quieting and pious decree, and has so shewed his general depravity.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 158:6
verses.text: Your majesty had ordered an investigation and careful testing to be made concerning the faith, and that with the consent and concord of all.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 158:7
verses.text: Cyril, challenged, or rather himself convicting himself, on the count of the Apollinarian doctrines, by means of the letter which he lately sent to the imperial city, with anathematisms, whereby he is convicted of sharing the views of the impious and heretic Apollinarius, pays no heed to this condition of things, and, as though we were living with no emperor to govern us, is proceeding to every kind of lawlessness.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 158:8
verses.text: He ought himself to be called to account for his unsound opinion about our Lord Jesus Christ; but, usurping an authority given him neither by the canons, nor by your edicts, he is hurrying headlong into every kind of disorder and illegality.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 158:9
verses.text: Moved by these things the holy Synod, which has refused to accept his devices for the damage of the faith, for the aforesaid reasons deposes him.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 158:10
verses.text: It deposes Memnon also, who has been his counsellor and abettor through all, who has kept up constant agitation against the very holy bishops for refusing to assent to his pernicious heterodoxy; who has shut the churches and every place of prayer, as if we were living among the heathen and the enemies of God; who has brought in the Ephesian mob, so that every day we are in supreme danger, while we look not to defence, but heed the right doctrines of true religion.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 158:11
verses.text: For the destruction of these men is identical with the establishment of orthodoxy.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 158:12
verses.text: From his own Chapters your majesty can have no difficulty in perceiving his impious mind.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 158:13
verses.text: He is convicted of trying, so to say, to raise from Hades the impious Apollinarius, who died in his heresy, and of attacking the churches and the orthodox faith.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 158:14
verses.text: He is shewn in his publications to anathematize at once evangelists and apostles and them that succeeded them as forefathers of the Church, who, moved not by their own imaginations, but by the holy Spirit, have preached the true faith, and proclaimed the gospel; a faith and gospel indeed opposed to what this man holds and teaches and by inculcating which he wishes to give his own private iniquity the mastery of the world.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 158:15
verses.text: Since this is intolerable to us we have followed the proper course, relying at once on the divine grace and on your majesty's good will.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 158:16
verses.text: We know that you give to nothing higher honour than to the sacred faith in which both you and your thrice blessed forefathers have been brought up.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 158:17
verses.text: From them you have received the perpetual sceptre of empire, ever putting down the opponents of the apostolic doctrines.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 158:18
verses.text: Such an opponent is the aforesaid Cyril, who, with the aid of Memnon, has captured Ephesus as he might some fortress, and justly shares with his ally the sentence of deposition.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 158:19
verses.text: Justly: for, besides all that has been said, they have boldly tried every means of assault and every violence against us, who, to come together in council in ratification of your edict, have disregarded every claim of home and country and self.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 158:20
verses.text: We are now the prey of tyranny, unless your piety intervene and order us to assemble in some other place, near at hand, where we shall be able, from the scriptures, and from the writings of the Fathers, to refute beyond contradiction both Cyril and the victims of his ingenuity.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 158:21
verses.text: We have mercifully expelled these men from communion with the suggested hope of salvation in case they should repent; although, as if on some campaign of uncivilized soldiery, they have up to this moment furnished him with the means of his illegality.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 158:22
verses.text: Some were deposed long ago, and have been restored by Cyril.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 158:23
verses.text: Some have been excommunicated by their own metropolitans, and admitted by him again into communion.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 158:24
verses.text: Others have been impaled on various accusations, and have been promoted by him to honour.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 158:25
verses.text: All through, the main motive of his action has been the endeavour to achieve his heretical purpose by the force of numbers, for he does not reckon as he ought that in what relates to true religion, it is not numbers that are required, but rather correctness of doctrine and the truth of the doctrine of the apostles.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 158:26
verses.text: Men are needed who are competent to establish these points not by audacity and masterful self-assertion but by pious use of apostolic testimony and example.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 158:27
verses.text: For all these reasons we beseech and implore your majesty to bear prompt aid to assaulted truth, and to remedy without delay these men's masterful readiness; for, like a hurricane, it is sweeping the less moderate among us into pernicious heresy.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 158:28
verses.text: Your piety has had care for the churches in Persia and among the barbarians; it is only right that you should not neglect those which are tossed by the storm within the boundaries of the Roman empire.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 159:1
verses.text: CLVIII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 159:2
verses.text: Report of (the Bishops of) the East to the Very Pious Emperor, which they delivered with the preceding Report to the Right Honourable Count Irenaeus.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 159:3
verses.text: On receiving the letter of your piety we entertained hopes that the Egyptian storm which has lately struck the churches of God would be driven away.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 159:4
verses.text: But we have been disappointed.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 159:5
verses.text: Those men have been made even yet more daring by their madness; they have given no heed to the sentence of deposition justly and in due forth passed upon them, nor have become any more moderate in consequence of the rebuke of your majesty.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 159:6
verses.text: They have trampled down alike the laws of your piety, and the canons of the holy Fathers, and, some of them being deposed and some excommunicated, keep festivals, and celebrate communion, in Houses of Prayer.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 159:7
verses.text: And we, as we have already informed your Christ-loving majesty, on the receipt of your clemency's kindly letter, though our only desire was to pray in the church of the Apostles, have not only been prevented, but actually stoned, and chased for a considerable distance, so that we were compelled to effect our safety by flight at full speed.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 159:8
verses.text: Our opponents on the contrary think that they may act just as they please.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 159:9
verses.text: They have declined to make investigation of the questions at issue, and to undertake the defence of Cyril's heretical Chapters, rejecting the plain proofs of the impiety which they contain.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 159:10
verses.text: They are impudent from mere impudence, while the examination of the questions before us requires not impudence, but calmness, knowledge, and skill in matters of doctrine.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 159:11
verses.text: Under these circumstances we have been under the necessity of sending forward the most honourable Count Irenaeus, to approach your piety, and to explain the position of affairs.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 159:12
verses.text: He has accurate information concerning all that has occurred, and has learned from us many modes of cure, whereby it may be possible to bring about the restoration of tranquillity to the holy churches of God.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 159:13
verses.text: We beseech your clemency to grant him patient audience, and to give orders for the prompt carrying out of whatever measures may seem good to your piety, that we be not here crushed beyond all endurance.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 160:1
verses.text: CLIX.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 160:2
verses.text: Letter of the same to the Praefect and to the Master.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 161:1
verses.text: CLX.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 161:2
verses.text: Letter of the same to the Governor and Scholasticus.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 162:1
verses.text: CLXI.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 162:2
verses.text: Report presented to the Emperor by John, Archbishop of Antioch and his supporters through Palladius Magistrianus.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 163:1
verses.text: CLXII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 163:2
verses.text: Letter of Theodoretus to Andreas, Bishop of Samosata, written from Ephesus.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 163:3
verses.text: Writing from Ephesus I salute your holiness, I congratulate you on your infirmity, and deem you dear to God, in that you have known what evil deeds have been going on here by report, and not by personal experience.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 163:4
verses.text: Evil indeed! They transcend all imagination and all incidents of history; they compel a continual downpour of tears.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 163:5
verses.text: The body of the Church is in peril of dismemberment;—nay, rather I may say it has received the first incision;—unless the wise Healer restore and re-connect the unsound and severed limbs.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 163:6
verses.text: Once again the Egyptian is raging against God, and warring with Moses and Aaron His servants, and the more part of Israel are on the side of the foe; for all too few are the sound who willingly suffer for true religion's sake.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 163:7
verses.text: Ancient principles are trodden under foot.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 163:8
verses.text: Deposed men perform priestly functions, and they who have deposed them sit sighing at home.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 163:9
verses.text: Men excommunicated by the same sentence as the deposed have relieved the deposed of their deposition of their own free will.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 163:10
verses.text: Such is the mockery of a synod held by Egyptians, by Palestinians, by men from the Pontic and Asian dioceses, and by the West in their company.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 163:11
verses.text: What players in a pantomime, in the days of paganism, even in any farce so held up religion to ridicule? Indeed what farce-writer ever performed such a play? What dramatist ever wrote so sad a tragedy? Such and so great are the troubles that have beset God's Church, whereof I have narrated but a very small part.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 164:1
verses.text: CLXIII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 164:2
verses.text: First Letter of the Commissioners of the East, sent to Chalcedon, among whom was Theodoretus.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 164:3
verses.text: On our arrival at Chalcedon, for neither we ourselves nor our opponents were permitted to enter Constantinople, on account of the seditions of the excellent monks, we heard that eight days before we had appeared (behold the glory of the most pious prince) the lord Nestorius was dismissed from Ephesus, free to go where he would; whereat we are much distressed, since verily deeds done illegally and informally now seem to have some force.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 164:4
verses.text: Let your holiness however be assured that we shall eagerly join the battle for the Faith, and are willing to fight even unto death.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 164:5
verses.text: To-day, the th of the month Gorpiaeum, we are expecting our very pious Emperor to cross over to the Rufinianum, and there to hear the trial.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 164:6
verses.text: We therefore beg your holiness to pray the Lord Christ to help us to be able to confirm the faith of the holy Fathers, and to pluck up by the roots these Chapters which have sprouted to the damage of the Church.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 164:7
verses.text: We implore your holiness to think and act with us, and to abide in your ready devotion to the orthodox faith.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 164:8
verses.text: When this letter was written the lord Himerius had not yet met us, being peradventure hindered on the road.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 164:9
verses.text: But do not let this trouble you.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 164:10
verses.text: Only let your piety strenuously support us, and we trust that gloom will disappear, and the truth shine forth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 165:1
verses.text: CLXIV.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 165:2
verses.text: Second Epistle of the same to the same, expressing premature triumph in Victory.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 165:3
verses.text: Through the prayers of your holiness our most pious prince has granted us an audience, and by God's grace we have got the better of our opponents, as all our views have been accepted by the most Christ-loving emperor.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 165:4
verses.text: The reports of others were read, and what seemed unfit to be received, and had no further importance, he rejected.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 165:5
verses.text: They were full of Cyril, and petitioned that he might be summoned to give an account of himself.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 165:6
verses.text: So far they have not prevailed, but have heard discourses on true religion, that is on the system of the Faith, and that the faith of the blessed Fathers was confirmed.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 165:7
verses.text: We further refuted Acacius who had laid down in his Commentaries that the Godhead is passible.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 165:8
verses.text: At this our pious emperor was so shocked at the enormity of the blasphemy that he flung off his mantle, and stepped back.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 165:9
verses.text: We know that the whole assembly welcomed us as champions of true religion.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 165:10
verses.text: It has seemed good to our most pious emperor that anyone should explain his own views, and report them to his piety.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 165:11
verses.text: We have replied that it is impossible for us to make any other exposition than that made by the blessed Fathers at Nicaea, and so it has pleased his majesty.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 165:12
verses.text: We therefore offered the form subscribed by your holiness.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 165:13
verses.text: Moreover, the whole population of Constantinople is continually coming out to us to implore us to fight manfully for the Faith.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 165:14
verses.text: We do our best to restrain them, to avoid giving offence to our opponents.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 165:15
verses.text: We have sent a copy of the expositing, that two copies may be made, and you may subscribe them both.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 166:1
verses.text: CLXV.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 166:2
verses.text: Letter of the same to the same.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 166:3
verses.text: To the very pious bishops now in Ephesus: Johannes, Himerius, Paulus, Apringius, Theodoretus, greeting.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 166:4
verses.text: For the fifth time an audience has been granted us.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 166:5
verses.text: We entered largely into the question of the heretical Chapters, and swore again and again to the very pious emperor that it was impossible for us to hold communion with our opponents unless they rejected the Chapters.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 166:6
verses.text: We pointed out moreover that even if Cyril did abjure his Chapters he could not be received by us, because he had become the heresiarch of so impious a heresy.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 166:7
verses.text: Nevertheless we gained no ground, because our adversaries were urgent, and their hearers could neither restrain them in their insolent endeavour, nor compel them to come to enquiry and argument.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 166:8
verses.text: They thus evade the investigation of the Chapters, and allow no discussion concerning them.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 166:9
verses.text: We, however, as you entreat, are ready to insist to the death.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 166:10
verses.text: We refuse to receive Cyril and his Chapters; we will not admit these men to Communion till the improper additions to the Faith be rejected.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 166:11
verses.text: We therefore implore your holiness to continue to show at once our mind and our efforts.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 166:12
verses.text: The battle is for true religion; for the only hope we have,—on account of which we look forward to enjoying, in the world to come, the loving-kindness of our Saviour.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 166:13
verses.text: As to the very pious and holy bishop Nestorius, be it known to your piety that we have tried to introduce a word about him, but have hitherto failed, because all are ill-affected toward him.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 166:14
verses.text: We will notwithstanding do our best, though this is so, to take advantage of any opportunity that may offer, and of the goodwill of the audience, to carry out this purpose, God helping us.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 166:15
verses.text: But that your holiness may not be ignorant of this too, know that we, seeing that the partisans of Cyril have deceived everyone by domineering, cheating, flattering, and bribing, have more than once besought the very pious emperor and most noble princes both to send us back to the East, and let your holiness go home.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 166:16
verses.text: For we are beginning to learn that we are wasting time in vain, without nearing our end, because Cyril everywhere shirks discussion, in his conviction that the blasphemies published in his Twelve Chapters can be openly refuted.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 166:17
verses.text: The very pious emperor has determined, after many exhortations, that we all go every one to his own home, and that, further, both the Egyptian and Memnon of Ephesus are to remain in their own places.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 166:18
verses.text: So the Egyptian will be able to go on blindfolding by bribery.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 166:19
verses.text: The one, after crimes too many to tell, is to return to his diocese.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 166:20
verses.text: The other, an innocent man, is barely permitted to go home.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 166:21
verses.text: We and all here salute you and all the brotherhood with you.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 167:1
verses.text: CLXVI.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 167:2
verses.text: First Petition of the Commissioners, addressed from Chalcedon, to the Emperor.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 167:3
verses.text: It had been much to be desired that the word of true religion should not be adulterated by ridiculous explanations, and least of all by men who have obtained the priesthood and high office in the churches, and who have been induced, we know not how, by ambition, by lust of authority, and by certain poor promises, to despise all the commandments of Christ.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 167:4
verses.text: Their only motive has been the desire to pay court to a man who has the presumption to hope that he and his abettors will be able to manage the whole business with success; I mean Cyril of Alexandria.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 167:5
verses.text: Of his own frivolity he has intruded into the holy churches of God heretical doctrines which he believes himself able to support by argument.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 167:6
verses.text: He expects to escape the chastisement of sinners by the sole help of Memnon and the bishops of the aforesaid conspiracy.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 167:7
verses.text: We are lovers of silence; in general we advise a philosophic course of action.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 167:8
verses.text: Now, however, sensible that to be silent and to cultivate philosophy would be to throw away the Faith, we turn in supplication to you who, next to the Goodness on high, are the sole preserver of the world.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 167:9
verses.text: We know that it specially belongs to you to be anxious for true religion, as having, up to this present day, continually protected it, and being in turn protected by it.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 167:10
verses.text: We beg you therefore to receive this treatise, as though our defence were to be pleaded in the presence of the most holy God; not because we are less active in the sacred cause, but because we are devoted to true religion, and are speaking in its behalf.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 167:11
verses.text: For in Christian times the clergy have no more bounden duty than to bear testimony before so faithful a prince, however ready we might have been to yield our bodies and to lay down our lives a thousand times in the battle for the faith.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 167:12
verses.text: We therefore beseech you by God who seeth all things, by our Lord Jesus Christ who will judge all men in righteousness, by the Holy Ghost by whose grace you hold your empire, and by the elect angels who are your guardians and whom one day you shall see standing by the awful throne, and ceaselessly offering unto God that dread doxology which it is now sought to corrupt; we beseech your piety, besieged as you now are by the craftiness of certain men who are forbidding access to you, and are supporting the introduction into the faith of heretical Chapters, utterly at variance with sound doctrine, and tainted with heresy, to order all who subscribe them, or assent to them, and wish, after your promised pardon, to dispute further, to come forth and submit to the discipline of the Church.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 167:13
verses.text: Nothing, sir, is more worthy of an emperor than to fight for the truth, for which you hurried to join battle with Persians and other barbarians, when Christ granted you to win fair victories in acknowledgment of your zeal towards Him.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 167:14
verses.text: We beseech you that the questions at issue may be put before your piety in writing, for thus their purport will be more easily perceived, and the transgressors will be convicted for all future time.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 167:15
verses.text: If however anyone, heedless of the utterances for which he shall be at fault, shall wish by his teaching to prevail over the right faith, it will be the part of your justice and judgment to consider whether the very name of teachers has not been thrown away by men who are reluctant to run any risks concerning the doctrines which they introduce, refusing to be obedient to your orders, that they may escape conviction for having done wrong; nor reckoning them worth refutation, that their mutual conspiracy be not proved fruitless.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 167:16
verses.text: For now it is clear, from those that have been ordained by them that some of them, in return for this impiety, have bethought them of obliging certain persons by the concession of dignities and have devised certain other means.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 167:17
verses.text: This will become still more clear; and your piety will soon see that they will distribute the rewards of their treachery, as though they were the spoils of the faith of Christ.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 167:18
verses.text: But we, of whom some were long ago ordained by the very pious Juvenal, bishop of Jerusalem, have kept silence, although it was our duty to contend for the canon, that we might not seem to be troubled for our own reputation's sake.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 167:19
verses.text: We are now perfectly well aware of his active trickery through Phoenicia Secunda and Arabia.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 167:20
verses.text: We really have not time to attend to such things.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 167:21
verses.text: We are men who have preferred rather to be deprived of the very places of which the ministry has been entrusted to us, and so of our life, than of our ready zeal for the faith.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 167:22
verses.text: To the attempts of those men we will oppose the sentence of God and of your piety.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 167:23
verses.text: Now also we beg that true religion may be your one and primary care, and that the brightness of orthodoxy, which at length with difficulty blazed forth in the days of Constantine of holy name, was maintained by your blessed grandfather and father, and was extended by your majesty among the Persians and other barbarians, be not allowed to grow dim in the very innermost courts of your imperial palace, or, in your serenity's days, to be dispersed.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 167:24
verses.text: You will not send, sir, a divided Christianity into Persia; nor here at home will there be anything great, while we are distressed by disputes, and while there is no one existing on their side to settle them; no one will take part in a divided Word and Sacraments; no one without loss of faith will cut himself off from such famous fathers and saints who have never been condemned.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 167:25
verses.text: No imperial successes will be permitted to a people at variance among themselves; a burst of derision will be roused from the enemies of true religion; and all the other noxious consequences of their malignant controversy are too numerous to reckon.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 167:26
verses.text: If there is anyone who thinks little of the science of theology, let that one be any one in the world rather than he to whom the Lord has given the supreme government of the world.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 167:27
verses.text: Our petition is that your piety will give judgment, for God will guide your intelligence into exact comprehension.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 167:28
verses.text: Finally, should this be impracticable (and all the engagements of your piety we cannot know) we beseech your serenity to give us leave to travel safely home.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 167:29
verses.text: We are aware that to the dioceses entrusted to us cause of offence is given by so protracted a delay, on account of those men who even in sacred matters look out for opportunities of dissension whence no advantage can be derived.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 168:1
verses.text: CLXVII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 168:2
verses.text: Second Petition of the same, sent from Chalcedon to Theodosius Augustus.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 168:3
verses.text: Your piety has been informed on several occasions, both by ourselves in person and by our emissaries, that the doctrine of the true faith seems to stand in danger of being corrupted, and that the body of the Church is apparently being rent asunder by men who are turning everything upside down, trampling upon all church order, and all imperial law, and throwing everything into confusion that they may confirm the heresy propounded by Cyril of Alexandria.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 168:4
verses.text: For when we were first summoned by your piety to Ephesus, to enquire into the question which had arisen and to confirm the evangelic and apostolic faith laid down by the holy Fathers, before the arrival of all the bishops who had been convened, the holders of their own private Council confirmed in writing the heretical Chapters, which are at one with the impiety of Arius, Eunomius and Apollinarius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 168:5
verses.text: Some they deceived; some they terrified; others already charged with heresy, they received into communion; and others who had not communicated with them were bribed into so doing; others again were fired with the hope of dignities for which they were unfit; so these men gathered round them a great crowd of adherents, as though they had no idea that true religion is shewn not by numbers, but by truth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 168:6
verses.text: The dispatch of your piety was read a second time by the most honourable Count Candidianus, ordering that the questions recently raised be examined in a quiet and brotherly manner.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 168:7
verses.text: When however all the pious bishops were assembling, the reading had no effect.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 168:8
verses.text: Then came the noble Palladius Magistrianus, bringing another dispatch from your majesty, to the effect that all enactments passed privately and apart must be rescinded; that the Council must be assembled afresh and the true doctrine ratified; but, as usual, this your pious mandate was treated with contempt by these unscrupulous persons.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 168:9
verses.text: Then again arrived the right honourable Master John, at that time "Comes Largitionum," bringing another pious letter to the effect that the depositions of the three had been decreed, that the offences which had sprung up were to be removed, and the faith laid down at Nicaea by the holy and blessed Fathers was to be ratified by all.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 168:10
verses.text: As usual these universal mockers transgressed this law too.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 168:11
verses.text: For after hearing the letter they did not change their mode of action; they held communion with the deposed; spoke of them as bishops, and refused to allow the Chapters, which had been propounded to the loss and corruption of the pious faith to be rejected; notwithstanding their having been frequently summoned by us to discussion.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 168:12
verses.text: For we had ready to hand a plain refutation of the heretical Chapters.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 168:13
verses.text: In evidence of these statements we have the right honourable Master, who when both sides had been summoned a third and a fourth time, not venturing to make this conduct an excuse on account of their disobedience, thought it worth while to summon us hither.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 168:14
verses.text: We came at once; on our arrival we allowed ourselves no rest making our petition, both before your piety and before the illustrious assembly, that they would take up the quarrel for the Chapters and enter into discussion concerning them, or on the other hand reject them as contrary to the right faith, abiding by the faith as laid down by the blessed fathers in council at Nicaea.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 168:15
verses.text: They refused to do anything of the kind; they persisted in their heretical procedure; yet they were allowed to attend the churches, and to perform their priestly functions.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 168:16
verses.text: We, however, alike at Ephesus and here, have been for a long time deprived of communion; alike there and here we have undergone innumerable perils; and while we were being stoned and all but slain by slaves dressed up as monks, we took it all for the best, as willingly enduring such treatment in the cause of the truth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 168:17
verses.text: Afterwards it seemed good to your majesty that we and the opposite party should assemble once again, that the recalcitrant might be compelled to examine the doctrines.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 168:18
verses.text: While we were waiting for this to come to pass your piety set out for the city, and ordered the very men who were being accused of heresy and had been therefore some of them deposed by us, and others excommunicated and thereafter to be subjected to the discipline of the Church, to come to the city and perform priestly functions, and ordain.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 168:19
verses.text: We however who in the cause of true religion have undertaken a struggle so tremendous; we who have shrunk from no peril in our battle for right doctrine, have neither been bidden to enter the city to serve the cause of the imperilled Faith and strive for orthodoxy; nor have we been permitted to return home; but here we are in Chalcedon distressed and groaning for the Church oppressed by schism.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 168:20
verses.text: Wherefore since we are in receipt of no reply we have thought it necessary to inform your piety by this present letter, before God and Christ and the Holy Ghost, that if any one shall have been ordained (before the settlement of right doctrines) by these men of heretical opinions, he must necessarily be cut off from the whole church, as well from the clergy as the dissentient laity.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 168:21
verses.text: For none of the pious will endure that communion be granted to heretics, and their own salvation be nullified.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 168:22
verses.text: And when this shall have come to pass, then your piety shall be compelled to act against your will.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 168:23
verses.text: For the schism will grow beyond all expectation, and thereby the champions of true religion will be saddened, unable to endure the loss of their own souls, and the establishment of those impious doctrines of Cyril which the contentious are desirous of defending.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 168:24
verses.text: Many indeed of the supporters of true religion will never allow the acceptance of Cyril's doctrines; we shall never allow it, who all are of the diocese of the East of your province, of the diocese of Pontus, of Asia, of Thrace, of Illyricum and of the Italies, and who also sent to your piety the treatise of the most blessed Ambrose, written against this nascent superstition.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 168:25
verses.text: To avoid all this, and the further troubling of your piety, we beg, beseech, and implore you to issue an edict that no ordination take place before the settlement of the orthodox faith, on account of which we have been convened by your Christ-loving highness.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 169:1
verses.text: CLXVIII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 169:2
verses.text: Third Demand of the same, addressed from Chalcedon to the Sovereigns.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 169:3
verses.text: We never expected the summons of your piety to meet with this result.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 169:4
verses.text: We were honourably convoked, as priests by prince; we were convoked to ratify the faith of the holy Fathers; and therefore, in due obedience to a pious prince, we came.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 169:5
verses.text: On our arrival we were no less faithful to the Church, not less respectful to your edict.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 169:6
verses.text: From the day of our arrival at Ephesus till the present moment we have without intermission followed your behests.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 169:7
verses.text: As it seems, however, our moderation, in these times, has not been of the slightest use to us; nay, rather, so far as we can see, it has stood very much in our way.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 169:8
verses.text: We indeed who have thus behaved have been up to the present time detained in Chalcedon; and now we are told that we may go home.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 169:9
verses.text: They however who have thrown everything into confusion, who have filled the world with tumult, who are striving to rend churches in twain, and who are the open assailants of true religion, perform priestly functions, crowd the churches, and as they imagine have authority to ordain, though in truth it is illegally claimed by them, stir up seditions in the church, and what ought to be spent upon the poor they throw away upon their bullies.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 169:10
verses.text: But you are not only their emperor; you are ours too.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 169:11
verses.text: For no small portion of your empire is the East, wherein the right faith has ever shone, and, besides, the other provinces and dioceses from which we have been convened.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 169:12
verses.text: Let not your majesty despise the faith which is being corrupted, in which you and your forefathers have been baptized; on which the Church's foundations are laid; for which most holy martyrs have rejoiced to suffer countless kinds of death; by aid of which you have vanquished barbarians and destroyed tyrants; which you are needing now in your war for the subjugation of Africa.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 169:13
verses.text: For on your side will fight the God of all if you struggle on behalf of His holy doctrines and forbid the dismemberment of the body of the church: for dismembered it will be if the opinion prevail which Cyril has introduced into the Church and other heretics have confirmed.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 169:14
verses.text: To these truths we have often already borne testimony before God both in Ephesus and in this place.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 169:15
verses.text: I have furnished information to your holiness, giving an account as before the God of all.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 169:16
verses.text: For this is required of us, as is taught in the divine Scripture both by prophets and apostles; as says the blessed Paul "I give thee charge in the sight of God, who quickeneth the dead, and of Lord Jesus Christ, who before Pontius Pilate witnessed a good confession;" and as God charged Ezekiel to announce to the people, adding threats and saying, "when thou givest him not warning,…his blood will I require at thine hand".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 169:17
verses.text: In awe of this sentence, once again we inform your majesty that they who have been permitted to hold churches, and who teach the doctrines of Apollinarius, Arius, and Eunomius, perform all sacred functions irregularly and in violation of the canons, and destroy the souls of all who approach them; if, indeed, any shall be found willing to listen to them.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 169:18
verses.text: For by the grace of God whose Providence is over all, and who wishes all men to be saved, the more part of the people is sound, and warmly attached to pious doctrines.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 169:19
verses.text: It is on their account that we grieve.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 169:20
verses.text: And in our anguish and alarm lest the plague creeping on by little and little should attack more, and the evil become general, we thus instruct your serenity, and continue to give you exhortation; we implore your majesty to yield to our prayers and to prohibit any addition to be made to the Faith of the holy Fathers assembled in council at Nicaea.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 169:21
verses.text: And if after this our entreaty your piety reject this doctrine, which was given in the presence of God, we will shake off the dust of our feet against you, and cry with the blessed Paul, "We are pure from your blood".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 169:22
verses.text: For we cease not night and day from the moment of our arrival at this distinguished council to bear witness to prince, nobles, soldiers, priests and people, that we hold fast the Faith delivered to us by the Fathers.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 170:1
verses.text: CLXIX.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 170:2
verses.text: Letter written by Theodoretus, Bishop of Cyrus, from Chalcedon to Alexander of Hierapolis.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 170:3
verses.text: We have left no means untried, of courtesy, of sternness, of entreaty, of eloquence before the most pious emperor, and the illustrious assembly, testifying before God who sees all things and our Lord Jesus Christ who shall judge the world in justice, and the Holy Spirit and his elect angels, lest the Faith be despised which is now being corrupted by the maintainers and bold subscribers of heretical doctrines: and that charge be given for it to be laid down in the same terms as at Nicaea and for the rejection of the heresy introduced to the loss and ruin of true religion.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 170:4
verses.text: Up to this time however we have produced not the slightest effect, our hearers being carried now in one direction and now in another.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 170:5
verses.text: Nevertheless all these difficulties have not been able to deter me from urging my point, but by God's grace I have pressed on.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 170:6
verses.text: I have even stated to our pious emperor with an oath that it is perfectly impossible for Cyril and Memnon to be reconciled with me, and that we can never communicate with any one who has not previously repudiated the heretical Chapters.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 170:7
verses.text: This then is our mind.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 170:8
verses.text: The object of men who "seek their own not the things which are Jesus Christ's" is to be reconciled with them against our will.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 170:9
verses.text: But this is no business of mine, for God weighs our motives and tries our character, nor does He inflict chastisement for what is done against our will.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 170:10
verses.text: Be it known to your holiness that if ever I said a word about our friend either before the very pious emperor or the illustrious assembly, I was at once branded as a rebel.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 170:11
verses.text: So intensely is he hated by the court party.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 170:12
verses.text: This is most annoying.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 170:13
verses.text: The most pious emperor, especially, cannot bear to hear his name mentioned and says publicly "Let no one speak to me of this man".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 170:14
verses.text: On one occasion he gave an instance of this to me.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 170:15
verses.text: Nevertheless as long as I am here I shall not cease to serve the interests of this our father, knowing that the impious have done him wrong.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 170:16
verses.text: My desire is that both your piety and I myself get quit of this.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 170:17
verses.text: No good is to be hoped from it, in as much as all the judges trust in gold, and contend that the nature of the Godhead and manhood is one.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 170:18
verses.text: All the people however by God's grace are in good case, and constantly come out to us.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 170:19
verses.text: I have begun to discourse to them and have celebrated very large communions.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 170:20
verses.text: On the fourth occasion I spoke at length about the faith and they listened with such delight that they did not go away till the seventh hour but held out even till the midday heat.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 170:21
verses.text: An enormous crowd was gathered in a great court, with four verandahs, and I preached from above from a platform near the roof.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 170:22
verses.text: All the clergy with the excellent monks are on the contrary utterly opposed to me, so that when we came back from the Rufinianum, after the visit of the very pious emperor, stone throwing began and many of my companions were wounded, by the people and false monks.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 170:23
verses.text: The very pious emperor knew that the mob was gathered against me and coming up to me alone he said, "I know that you are assembling improperly".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 170:24
verses.text: Then, said I, "As you have allowed me to speak hear me with favour.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 170:25
verses.text: Is it fair for excommunicated heretics to be doing duty in churches, while I, who am fighting for the Faith and am therefore excluded by others from communion, am not allowed to enter a church?" He replied "What am I to do?" I said, "What your comes largitionum did at Ephesus.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 170:26
verses.text: When he found that some were assembling, but that we were not assembling, he stopped them saying, 'If you are not peaceful I will allow neither party to assemble.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 170:27
verses.text: ' It would have become your piety also to have given directions to the bishop here to forbid both the opposite party and ourselves to assemble before our meeting together to make known your righteous sentence to all".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 170:28
verses.text: To this he replied "It is not for me to order the bishop;" and I answered "Neither shall you command us, and we will take a church, and assemble.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 170:29
verses.text: Your piety will find that there are many more on our side than on theirs".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 170:30
verses.text: In addition to this I pointed out that we had neither reading of the holy Scripture, nor oblation; but only "prayer for the Faith and for your majesty, and pious conversation".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 170:31
verses.text: So he approved, and made no further prohibition.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 170:32
verses.text: The result is that increased crowds flock to us, and gladly listen to our teaching.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 170:33
verses.text: I therefore beg your piety to pray that our case may have an issue pleasing to God.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 170:34
verses.text: I am in daily danger, suspecting the wiles of both monks and clergy, as I witness alike their influence and their negligence.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 171:1
verses.text: CLXX.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 171:2
verses.text: Letter of certain Easterns, who had been sent to Constantinople, to Bishop Rufus.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 171:3
verses.text: To our most godly and holy fellow-minister Rufus, Joannes, Himerius, Theodoretus, and the rest, send greeting in the Lord.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 171:4
verses.text: True religion and the peace of the Church suffer, we think, in no small degree, from the absence of your holiness.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 171:5
verses.text: Had you been on the spot you might have put a stop to the disturbances which have arisen, and the violence that has been ventured on, and might have fought on our side for the subjection of the heresies introduced into the orthodox Faith, and that doctrine of apostles and evangelists which, handed down from time to time from father to son, has at length been transmitted to ourselves.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 171:6
verses.text: And we do not assert this without ground, for we have learnt the mind of your holiness from the letter written to the very godly and holy Julianus, bishop of Sardica, for that letter as is right charged the above named very godly bishop to fight for the Faith laid down by the blessed fathers assembled in council at Nicaea, and not to allow any corruption to be introduced into those invincible definitions which are sufficient at once to exhibit the truth and to refute falsehood.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 171:7
verses.text: So your holiness rightly, justly, and piously advised, and the recipient of the letter followed your counsel.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 171:8
verses.text: But many of the members of the council, to use the word of the prophet, "have gone aside," and have "altogether become filthy," for they have abandoned the Faith which they received from the holy Fathers, and have subscribed the twelve Chapters of Cyril of Alexandria, which teem with Apollinarian error, are in agreement with the impiety of Arius and Eunomius, and anathematize all who do not accept their unconcealed unorthodoxy.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 171:9
verses.text: To this plague smiting the Church vigorous resistance has been offered by us who have assembled from the East, and others from different dioceses, with the object of securing the ratification of the Faith delivered by the blessed Fathers at Nicaea.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 171:10
verses.text: For in it, as your holiness knows, there is nothing lacking whether for the teaching of evangelic doctrines, or for the refutation of every heresy.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 171:11
verses.text: For the sake of this Faith we continue to struggle, despising alike all the joys and sorrows of mortal life, if only we may preserve untouched this heritage of our fathers.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 171:12
verses.text: For this reason we have deposed Cyril and Memnon; the former as prime mover in the heresy, and the latter as his aider and abettor in all that has been done to ratify and uphold the Chapters published to the destruction of the Church.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 171:13
verses.text: We have also excommunicated all that have dared to subscribe and support these impious doctrines till they shall have anathematized them, and returned to the Faith of the Fathers at Nicaea.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 171:14
verses.text: But our long-suffering has done them no good.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 171:15
verses.text: To this day they continue to do battle for those pernicious doctrines and have impaled themselves on the law of the canon which distinctly enacts "If any bishop deposed by a synod, or presbyter or deacon deposed by his own bishop, shall perform his sacred office, without waiting for the judgment of a synod, he is to have no opportunity for defending himself, not even in another synod: but also all who communicate with him are to be expelled from the church".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 171:16
verses.text: Now this law has been broken both by the deposed and the excommunicate.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 171:17
verses.text: For immediately after the deposition and the excommunication becoming known to them, they performed sacred functions, and they continue to do so, in plain disbelief of Him who said "Whatsoever ye shall bind on earth shall be bound in heaven".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 171:18
verses.text: With this we have thought well to acquaint your holiness at once, but in expectation of some favourable change, we have waited up to the present time.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 171:19
verses.text: But we have been disappointed.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 171:20
verses.text: They have continued to fight for this impious heresy, and pay no attention to the counsels of the very pious emperor.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 171:21
verses.text: On five separate occasions he has met us, and ordered them either to reject the Chapters of Cyril as contrary to the Faith, or to be willing to do battle in their behalf, and to shew in what way they are in agreement with the confession of the Fathers.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 171:22
verses.text: We have our proofs at hand, whereby we should have shewn that they are totally opposed to the teaching of orthodoxy, and for the most part in agreement with heresy.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 171:23
verses.text: For in these very Chapters the author of the noxious productions teaches that the Godhead of the only begotten Son suffered, instead of the manhood which He assumed for the sake of our salvation, the indwelling Godhead manifestly appropriating the sufferings as of Its own body, though suffering nothing in Its own nature; and further that there is made one nature of both Godhead and manhood,—for so he explains "The Word was made flesh," as though the Godhead had undergone some change, and been turned into flesh.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 171:24
verses.text: And, further, he anathematizes those who make a distinction between the terms used by apostles and evangelists about the Lord Christ, referring those of humiliation to the manhood, and those of divine glory to the Godhead, of the Lord Christ.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 171:25
verses.text: It is with these views that Arians and Eunomians, attributing the terms of humiliation to the Godhead, have not shrunk from declaring God the Word to be made and created, of another substance, and unlike the Father.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 171:26
verses.text: What blasphemy follows on these statements it is not difficult to perceive.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 171:27
verses.text: There is introduced a confusion of the natures, and to God the Word are applied the words "My God, my God, why hast thou forsaken me;" and "Father, if it be possible let this cup pass from me," the hunger, the thirst, and the strengthening by an angel; His saying "Now is my soul troubled," and "my soul is exceeding sorrowful, even unto death," and all similar passages belonging to the manhood of the Christ.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 171:28
verses.text: Any one may perceive how these statements correspond with the impiety of Arius and Eunomius; for they, finding themselves unable to establish the difference of substance, connect, as has been said, the sufferings, and the terms of humiliation, with the Godhead of the Christ.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 171:29
verses.text: And be your reverence well assured that now in their churches the Arian teachers preach no other doctrine than that the supporters of the "homousion" at present hold the same views as Arius, and that, after long time, the truth has now at last been brought to light.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 171:30
verses.text: We on the contrary abide in the teaching, and follow in the pious footprints, of the blessed Fathers assembled at Nicaea, and of their illustrious successors, Eustathius of Antioch, Basil of Caesarea, Gregory, John, Athanasius, Theophilus, Damasus of Rome, and Ambrose of Milan.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 171:31
verses.text: For all these, following the words of the apostles, have left us an exact rule of orthodoxy, which all we of the East earnestly desire to preserve unmoved.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 171:32
verses.text: The same is the wish of the Bithynians, the Paphlagonians, of Cappadocia Secunda, Pisidia, Mysia, Thessaly, and Rhodope, and very many more of the different provinces.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 171:33
verses.text: The Italians too, it is evident, will not endure this new-fangled doctrine; for the very godly and holy Martinus, bishop of Milan, has written a letter to us, and has sent to the very pious emperor a work by the blessed Ambrose on the incarnation of the Lord, of which the teaching is opposed to these heretical Chapters.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 171:34
verses.text: And be it known to your holiness that Cyril and Memnon have not been satisfied with corrupting the orthodox Faith, but have trampled all the canons underfoot.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 171:35
verses.text: For they have received into communion men excommunicated in various provinces and dioceses.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 171:36
verses.text: Others lying under charges of heresy, and of the same mind as Celestius and Pelagius, (for they are Euchitae, or Enthusiasts) and therefore excommunicated by their diocesans and metropolitans, they have, in defiance of all ecclesiastical discipline received into communion, so swelling their following from all possible quarters, and shewing their eagerness to enforce their teaching less by piety than by violence.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 171:37
verses.text: For when they had been stripped bare of piety they devised, in their extremity, another sort of force,—walls of flesh, with the idea that by their showers of bribery they might vanquish the faith of the Fathers.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 171:38
verses.text: But so long as your holiness puts forth your strength, and you continue to fight, as you are wont, in defence of true religion, none of these devices will be of the least avail.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 171:39
verses.text: We exhort you therefore, most holy sir, to beware of the communion of the unscrupulous introducers of this heresy; and to make known to all, both far and near, that these are the points for which the thrice blessed Damasus deposed the heretics Apollinarius, Vitalius, and Timotheus; and that the Epistle in which the writer has concealed his heresy and coloured it with a coating of truth, must not in simplicity be received.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 171:40
verses.text: For in the Chapters he has boldly laid bare his impiety, and dared to anathematize all who disagree with him, while in the letter he has vilely endeavoured to harm the simpler readers.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 171:41
verses.text: Your holiness must therefore beware of neglecting this matter, lest when, too late, you see this heresy confirmed, you grieve in vain, and suffer affliction at being no longer able to defend the cause of truth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 171:42
verses.text: We have also sent you a copy of the memorial which we have given to the most pious and Christ-loving emperor, containing the faith of the holy Fathers at Nicaea.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 171:43
verses.text: wherein we have rejected the newly-invented heresies of Cyril, and adjudged them to be opposed to the orthodox faith.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 171:44
verses.text: Since in accordance with the orders of the very pious emperor only eight of us travelled to Constantinople, we have subjoined the copy of the order given us by the holy synod, that you may be acquainted with the provinces contained in it.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 171:45
verses.text: Your holiness will learn them from the signatures of the metropolitans.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 171:46
verses.text: We salute the brotherhood which is with you.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 172:1
verses.text: CLXXI.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 172:2
verses.text: Letter of Theodoret to John, Bishop of Antioch, after the Reconciliation.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 172:3
verses.text: God, who governs all things in wisdom, who provides for our unanimity, and cares for the salvation of His people, has caused us to be assembled together, and has shewn us that the views of all of us are in agreement with one another.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 172:4
verses.text: We have assembled together, and read the Egyptian Letter; we have carefully examined its purport, and we have discovered that its contents are quite in accordance with our own statements, and entirely opposed to the Twelve Chapters, against which up to the present time we have continued to wage war, as being contrary to true religion.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 172:5
verses.text: Their teaching was that God the Word was carnally made flesh; that there was an union of hypostasis, and that the combination in union was of nature, and that God the Word was the first-born from the dead.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 172:6
verses.text: They forbade all distinction in the terms used of our Lord, and further contained other doctrines at variance with the seeds sown by the apostles, and outcome of heretical tares.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 172:7
verses.text: The present script, however, is beautified by apostolic nobility of origin.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 172:8
verses.text: For in it our Lord Jesus Christ is exhibited as perfect God and perfect man; it shews two natures, and the distinction between them; an unconfounded union, made not by mixture and compounding, but in a manner ineffable and divine, and distinctly preserving the properties of the natures; the impassibility and immortality of God the Word; the passibility and temporary surrender to death of the temple, and its resurrection by the power of the united God; that the holy Spirit is not of the Son, nor derives existence from the Son, but proceeds from the Father, and is properly stated to be of the Son, as being of one substance.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 172:9
verses.text: Beholding this orthodoxy in the letter, we have hymned Him who heals our stammering tongues, and changes our discordant noises into the harmony of sweet music.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 173:1
verses.text: CLXXII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 173:2
verses.text: Letter of Theodoretus to Nestorius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 173:3
verses.text: To the very reverend and religious lord and very holy Father, Nestorius, the bishop Theodoretus sends greeting in the Lord.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 173:4
verses.text: Your holiness is, I think, well aware that I take no pleasure in cultivated society, nor in the interests of this life, nor in reputation, nor am I attracted by other sees.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 173:5
verses.text: Had I learnt this lesson from no other source, the very solitude of the city over which I am called to preside would suffice to teach me this philosophy.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 173:6
