verses.text: It is not indeed distinguished only for solitude, but also by very many disturbances which may check the activity even of those who most delight in them.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 173:7
verses.text: Let no one therefore persuade your holiness that I have accepted the Egyptian writings as orthodox, with my eyes shut, because I covet any see.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 173:8
verses.text: For really, to speak the truth, after frequently reading and carefully examining them, I have discovered that they are free from all heretical taint, and I have hesitated to put any stress upon them, though I certainly have no love for their author, who was the originator of the disturbances which have agitated the world.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 173:9
verses.text: For this I hope to escape punishment in the day of Judgment, since the just Judge examines motives.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 173:10
verses.text: But to what has been done unjustly and illegally against your holiness, not even if one were to cut off both my hands would I ever assent, God's grace helping me and supporting my infirmity.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 173:11
verses.text: This I have stated in writing to those who require it.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 173:12
verses.text: I have sent to your holiness my reply to what you wrote to me, that you may know that, by God's grace, no time has changed me like the centipedes and chameleons who imitate by their colour the stones and leaves among which they live.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 173:13
verses.text: I and all with me salute all the Brotherhood who are with you in the Lord.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 174:1
verses.text: CLXXIII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 174:2
verses.text: Letter to Andreas, Monk of Constantinople.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 174:3
verses.text: "God is faithful who will not suffer you to be tempted above that ye are able; but will with the temptation also make a way to escape that ye may be able to bear it," and convicts falsehood,—although now refuted assertion of the falsehood is approved,—and the power of truth has been shewn.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 174:4
verses.text: For, lo, they, who by their impious reasoning had confused the natures of our Saviour Christ, and dared to preach one nature, and therefore insulted the most holy and venerable Nestorius, high priest of God, their mouths held, as the prophet says, with bit and bridle and turned from wrong to right, have once again learnt the truth, adopting the statement of him who in the cause of truth has borne the brunt of the battle.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 174:5
verses.text: For instead of one nature they now confess two, anathematizing all who preach mixture and confusion.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 174:6
verses.text: They adore the impassible Godhead of Christ; they attribute passion to the flesh; they distinguish between the terms of the Gospels, ascribing the lofty and divine to the Godhead, and the lowly to the manhood.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 174:7
verses.text: Such are the writings now brought from Egypt.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 175:1
verses.text: CLXXIV.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 175:2
verses.text: To Himerius, Bishop of Nicomedia.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 175:3
verses.text: We wish to acquaint your holiness that on reading and frequently discussing the letter brought from Egypt we find it in harmony with the doctrine of the Church.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 175:4
verses.text: Of the twelve Chapters we have proved the contrary, and up to the present time we continue to oppose them.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 175:5
verses.text: We have therefore determined, if your holiness has recovered the churches divinely entrusted to you, that you ought to communicate with the Egyptians and Constantinopolitans and others who have fought with them against us, because they have professed to hold our faith, or I should rather say the faith of the apostles; but not to give your consent to the alleged condemnation of the very holy and venerable Nestorius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 175:6
verses.text: For we hold it impious and unjust in the case of charges in which both appeared as defendants to lavish favour on the one and shut the door of repentance on the other.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 175:7
verses.text: Far more unjust and impious is it to condemn an innocent man to death.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 175:8
verses.text: Your holiness should be assured that you ought not to communicate with them before you have recovered your churches.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 175:9
verses.text: For this not only I but all the holy bishops of our district decreed in the recent Council.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 176:1
verses.text: CLXXV.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 176:2
verses.text: To Alexander of Hierapolis.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 176:3
verses.text: I have already informed your holiness that if the doctrine of the very holy and venerable bishop, my lord Nestorius, is condemned, I will not communicate with those who do so.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 176:4
verses.text: If it shall please your holiness to insert this in the letter which is being sent to Antioch so be it.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 176:5
verses.text: Let there then, I beseech you, be no delay!.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 177:1
verses.text: CLXXVI.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 177:2
verses.text: Letter to the same Alexander after he had learnt that John, Bishop of Antioch, had Anathematized the Doctrine of Nestorius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 177:3
verses.text: Be it known to your holiness that when I read the letter addressed to the emperor I was much distressed, because I know perfectly well that the writer of the letter, being of the same opinions, has unwisely and impiously condemned one who has never held or taught anything contrary to sound doctrine.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 177:4
verses.text: But the form of anathema, though it be more likely than his assent to the condemnation, to grieve a reader, nevertheless has given me some ground of comfort, in that it is laid down not in wide general terms, but with some qualification.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 177:5
verses.text: For he has not said "We anathematize his doctrine" but "whatever he has either said or held other than is warranted by the doctrine of the apostles".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 178:1
verses.text: CLXXVII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 178:2
verses.text: Letter to Andreas, Bishop of Samosata.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 178:3
verses.text: The illustrious Aristolaus has sent Magisterianus from Egypt with a letter of Cyril in which he anathematizes Arius, Eunomius, Apollinarius and all who assert Christ's Godhead to be passible and maintain the confusion and commixture of the two natures.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 178:4
verses.text: Hereat we rejoice, although he did withhold his consent from our statement.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 178:5
verses.text: He requires further subscription to the condemnation which has been passed, and that the doctrine of the holy bishop Nestorius be anathematized.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 178:6
verses.text: Your holiness well knows that if any one anathematizes, without distinction, the doctrine of that most holy and venerable bishop, it is just the same as though he seemed to anathematize true religion.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 178:7
verses.text: We must then if we are compelled anathematize those who call Christ mere man, or who divide our one Lord Jesus Christ into two sons and deny His divinity, etc.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 179:1
verses.text: CLXXVIII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 179:2
verses.text: Letter to Alexander of Hierapolis.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 179:3
verses.text: I think that more than all the very holy and venerable bishop, my lord John, must have been gratified at my refusing either to give my consent to the condemnation of the very holy and venerable bishop Nestorius or to violate the pledges made at Tarsus, Chalcedon and Ephesus.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 179:4
verses.text: He remembers also what was frequently received from us at Antioch after our departure.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 179:5
verses.text: Let no one therefore deceive your holiness into the belief that I should ever do this, for God is without doubt on my side and strengthening me.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 180:1
verses.text: CLXXIX.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 180:2
verses.text: Letter of Cyril to John, Bishop of Antioch, against Theodoret.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 181:1
verses.text: CLXXX.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 181:2
verses.text: Letter of Theodoretus, as some suppose, to Domnus, Bishop of Antioch, written on the Death of Cyril, Bishop of Alexandria.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 181:3
verses.text: At last and with difficulty the villain has gone.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 181:4
verses.text: The good and the gentle pass away all too soon; the bad prolong their life for years.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 181:5
verses.text: The Giver of all good, methinks, removes the former before their time from the troubles of humanity; He frees them like victors from their contests and transports them to the better life, that life which, free from death, sorrow and care, is the prize of them that contend for virtue.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 181:6
verses.text: They, on the other hand, who love and practise wickedness are allowed a little longer to enjoy this present life, either that sated with evil they may afterwards learn virtue's lessons, or else even in this life may pay the penalty for the wickedness of their own ways by being tossed to and fro through many years of this life's sad and wicked waves.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 181:7
verses.text: This wretch, however, has not been dismissed by the ruler of our souls like other men, that he may possess for longer time the things which seem to be full of joy.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 181:8
verses.text: Knowing that the fellow's malice has been daily growing and doing harm to the body of the Church, the Lord has lopped him off like a plague and "taken away the reproach from Israel".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 181:9
verses.text: His survivors are indeed delighted at his departure.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 181:10
verses.text: The dead, maybe, are sorry.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 181:11
verses.text: There is some ground of alarm lest they should be so much annoyed at his company as to send him back to us, or that he should run away from his conductors like the tyrant of Cyniscus in Lucian.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 181:12
verses.text: Great care must then be taken, and it is especially your holiness's business to undertake this duty, to tell the guild of undertakers to lay a very big and heavy stone upon his grave, for fear he should come back again, and show his changeable mind once more.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 181:13
verses.text: Let him take his new doctrines to the shades below, and preach to them all day and all night.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 181:14
verses.text: We are not at all afraid of his dividing them by making public addresses against true religion and by investing an immortal nature with death.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 181:15
verses.text: He will be stoned not only by ghosts learned in divine law, but also by Nimrod, Pharaoh and Sennacherib, or any other of God's enemies.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 181:16
verses.text: But I am wasting words.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 181:17
verses.text: The poor fellow is silent whether he will or no, "his breath goeth forth, he returneth to his earth, in that very day his thoughts perish".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 181:18
verses.text: He is doomed too to silence of another kind.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 181:19
verses.text: His deeds, detected, tie his tongue, gag his mouth, curb his passion, strike him dumb and make him bow down to the ground.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 181:20
verses.text: I really am sorry for the poor fellow.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 181:21
verses.text: Truly the news of his death has not caused me unmixed delight, but it is tempered by sadness.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 181:22
verses.text: On seeing the Church freed from a plague of this kind I am glad and rejoice; but I am sorry and do mourn when I think that the wretch knew no rest from his crimes, but went on attempting greater and more grievous ones till he died.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 181:23
verses.text: His idea was, so it is said, to throw the imperial city into confusion by attacking true doctrines a second time, and to charge your holiness with supporting them.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 181:24
verses.text: But God saw and did not overlook it.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 181:25
verses.text: "He put his hook into his nose and his bridle into his lips," and turned him to the earth whence he was taken.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 181:26
verses.text: Be it then granted to your holiness's prayers that he may obtain mercy and pity and that God's boundless clemency may surpass his wickedness.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 181:27
verses.text: I beg your holiness to drive away the agitations of my soul.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 181:28
verses.text: Many different reports are being bruited abroad to my alarm announcing general misfortunes.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 181:29
verses.text: It is even said by some that your reverence is setting out against your will for the court, but so far I have despised these reports as untrue.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 181:30
verses.text: But finding every one repeating one and the same story I have thought it right to try and learn the truth from your holiness that I may laugh at these tales if false, or sorrow not without reason if they are true.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 182:1
verses.text: CLXXXI.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 182:2
verses.text: Letter to Abundius, Bishop of Como.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 182:3
verses.text: To my dear lord and very holy brother Abundius Theodoretus sends greeting in the Lord.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 182:4
verses.text: I have discovered that your piety religiously preserves the true and apostolic faith; and I have thanked Almighty God that the truth which was in peril has been renewed and brought to light by your holiness.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 182:5
verses.text: Of old, after the flood, it came to pass that Noah and his sons were left for seed of the human race.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 182:6
verses.text: Just so in our own day are reserved the fathers of the West, that by them the holy churches of the East may be able to preserve that true religion which has been threatened with devastation and destruction by a new and impious heresy.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 182:7
verses.text: Well may we quote those words of the prophet "Except the Lord of hosts had left unto us a very small remnant we should have been as Sodom and we should have been like unto Gomorrah".

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 182:8
verses.text: So upon us from this impious heresy the wrath of God has fallen like a flood and invasion.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 182:9
verses.text: Now we acknowledge the presence of our Saviour in a human body, and one Son of God, His perfect Godhead and His perfect manhood.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 182:10
verses.text: We do not divide our one Lord Jesus Christ into two sons for He is one; but we recognise the distinction between God and man; we know that one is of the Father, the other of the seed of David and Abraham, according to the divine Scriptures, and that the divine nature is free from passion, the body which was before subject to passion being now itself too free from passion; for after the resurrection it is plainly delivered from all passion.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 182:11
verses.text: This we have learnt from the letter of the very holy and religious Archbishop our lord Leo.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 182:12
verses.text: For we have read what he wrote to Flavianus, of holy and blessed memory, and have thanked the loving-kindness of the Lord because we have found an advocate and defender of the truth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 182:13
verses.text: To this letter I have given my adhesion, and have subjoined a copy of it to my present epistle, which I have also subscribed and have thereby proved that I obey the apostolic rules, that is true doctrines; that I abide in them to this day, and am suffering in their cause.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 182:14
verses.text: Assent has also been given by my lord Ibas and my lord Aquilinus against whom the inventors of the new heresy have armed the imperial power.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 182:15
verses.text: It remains for you with your very holy colleagues to bring aid to the sacred Church, and to drive away the war that threatens it.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 182:16
verses.text: Banish the impious party which has been roused against the truth; give back the churches their ancient peace; so will you receive from the Lord, Who has promised to grant this boon, the fruits of your apostolic labours.

verses.name: Theodoret: Letters 182:17
verses.text: All the very religious and godly presbyters and reverend deacons and brethren by your holiness I greet; and I and all who are with me salute your reverence.
